Fans of CS Lewis's book can rest easy.

Intelligent, funny and moving.

Woody Allen's gem of comic kvetching.

A stirring lament for good human beings caught in the crossfire of history.

Important and vital -- if a little heavy-handed.
mont doesn't hate his characters; he just thinks they're stupid: no one thinks, no one learns, everyone acts. It's the most Godless film you'll see all year.

It's messy and unusual, not always gratifying, sometimes frustrating, always compelling.

'W.' is neither coruscating nor edifying - but without the benefit of hindsight, it's probably the best we can hope for.

A real gem.

Not a good film by a long stretch, but there's something so harmless about this debut directorial effort (from a script by Aschlin 'Scenes of a Sexual Nature' Ditta) that to pull it apart would be like savaging a child's first attempt at storywriting.
A film that brilliantly and sensitively buzzes with life and offers its very own take on our world and our city. It delivers in spades attitude, humour, sadness, love, anger and hope.

Thoughtful, funny, slightly sad and superbly crafted.

You couldn't call this audacious British debut a success; it's too arch, awkward and over-extended for that. But, oddly, it's those very same qualities which make it arresting to watch and which mark out its two directors as talents to keep an eye on.

It's a film that is both insanely funny and a desperate cry for sanity.

Spielberg still manages to surprise and impress.
It can be to mix a strange city with devastating loss. It's at once a deeply sad film and a deeply truthful and optimistic one.

A sparkling, clever work whose ensemble cast impresses, surprises, wrongfoots and disappoints you in exactly the same fashion a class might its teacher.
Its issues are infinite and moveable. It's a bold and challenging work.
The script is witty and playful, the casting just right.

Russell Crowe as a troubled Pulitzer Prize-winning author is just one of a long list of unconvincing things about this corny, old-fashioned drama.

A look beneath its lushly romantic surface reveals a dark, complex sensibility, and that surface, rendered in the somber tones of British Technicolor, reflects a fantastically rich cinematic inventiveness.

If Pasolini had something more than grubby fantasy on his mind -- and presumably he did -- it isn't immediately apparent.
Ousmane Sembene's 1977 Senegalese film was attacked for daring to depict life in precolonial Africa as something less than paradisiacal.
Kon Ichikawa's 1956 antiwar film was widely hailed at the time of its release for its power and commitment, though by today's standards it's likely to appear uncomfortably didactic.
Too dull even to function as camp.
By no means a bad film, just a disappointingly bland and superficial one.

Slightly above average 50s science fiction (1958), enlivened by a nearly literate script by James Clavell.
Ulmer never again had the budgetary resources granted him by Universal (at the time, Karloff and Lugosi were two of the studio's biggest stars), and he makes the most of them.
No one seems to know what to do with the allegorical undertone of Jerzy Kosinski's script, but as a whole this 1979 film maintains a fine level of wit, sophistication, and insight.
The Stevenson story serves as the premise for an early (1921) appearance by John Barrymore, who plays the transformation scene -- very effectively -- without the aid of trick photography.
For all its shoddiness, the film manages, just barely, to achieve its ignoble goals -- it delivers what it promises.
It isn't artistically adroit, but if success in this genre is counted by squirms, it's a success.

movie_review_blurb: Paul Schrader's hammering, art-porno remake of Jacques Tourneur's deft little thriller.
Spasmodically effective.
Sembene keeps his metaphors under control, and the result is a message movie with an unusual depth of characterization.
Some of it is disturbing, some of it is embarrassingly flat, but all of it shows a degree of technical accomplishment far beyond anything else on the midnight-show circuit.

Jack Arnold has a flair for this sort of thing, and if there really is anything frightening about a man dressed up in a rubber suit with zippers where the gills ought to be, Arnold comes close to finding it.

Means middle-class angst covered with a thin veneer of snappy one-liners and presented in the most anonymous directorial style imaginable.
Stunningly unfunny.

This 1948 effort is probably the last of their watchable films, though it's a long way from their best.

One of the most daring and thoroughly perverse works of art ever to come out of Hollywood.

This is clearly breaking no new ground. But it does what it does with some skill and likeability.

It's a curiosity, perhaps, but it's nicely made, beautifully acted and well worth seeking out.

A western, most likely different from any western you'll have seen before, it is by turns funny, sad, tragic, comic and drily witty - it's a gem of the genre.
Sideways stays resolutely life-size. And that, in this age of hype and hyperventilation, may be the most radical thing about it.
If you're trying to make us believe we're watching 'reality' by using a faux documentary style, you need actors who never look like they are acting, and this is where Redacted stumbles.
The first feel-good movie made out of fecal matter.

Here -- in a Jerry Bruckheimer-produced high-seas adventure that incorporates roaring cannons, oddball comedy, a love story and more than a touch of the supernatural -- Depp unleashes his theatrical bravado. He's hilarious.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: There are signs that a lot has been cut, and in trimming his film Brooks may have squeezed too tight: his movie needs breathing space.

It may be a movie about movies, but the artifice doesn't contradict the movie's plangent emotional realism. Moore's stunning, subtle performance as a woman trapped in the conventions of her time encapsulates the film's brave, double-edged beauty.
Its dark, dog-eat-dog vision of the world we live in may give you geopolitical nightmares.
This astonishing film, shot in the Antarctic, captures sights never seen before.
The filmmaker knows how to seduce an audience without making it feel had. When a movie's this likable, it would take a very tough crowd not to be pleased.
Hirsch, who carries the film on his increasingly emaciated shoulders, performs heroically, but there's an edge missing.
It transformed the way I looked at the world.
This almost-great epic has one foot in legend: it's a vision of an American titan that could have sprung from the insides of Hughes's own obsessive, perfectionist head.
Refreshingly subtle.
With this film it becomes clear that Sofia Coppola is a filmmaker with eyes all her own.
[It] may be too airbrushed for its own good, but in the end nothing can stop this story from putting a lump in your throat.

For all its grit, style and atmosphere, Gangster never sweeps you away. It has neither the lurid bravado of De Palma's "Scarface" nor the intimate grasp of the criminal lifestyle you find in Scorsese or Coppola.
Peaks early, then descends into portentous nonsense.
By the tepid ending, the movie appears to have been sedated.
Zemeckis has been seduced by the siren call of motion capture... Memo to Zemeckis: come back to earth!
Baumbach's closely observed tale of dysfunctional family relationships has the microscopic texture of a New Yorker short story and the darting, spontaneous style of a French New Wave movie.
This bittersweet X-ray of American family dynamics may not be a Hallmark-card notion of a holiday movie, but it's one any son or daughter can take to heart.
The Diving Bell and the Butterfly keeps opening up, its structure mimicking the awakening of its extraordinary protagonist's mind.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Watching director Paul Greengrass's explosive Bloody Sunday, you have to remind yourself at moments that you're not looking at a documentary.
No two-hour film could ever capture all the riches of McEwan's masterly novel. But Wright and Hampton's Atonement comes tantalizingly close, while adding sensual delights all its own.

This delicious, seriocomic tale of four friends in affluent, liberal, west L.A. grappling with midlife crises, metrosexual spouses and household remodeling takes on an avoided subject: money, and how it affects our relationships.
Few films have shown so powerfully the slashing double edge of sports fever.

Both discordant and disingenuous, this faux-profound final note suggests that Berg and screenwriter Matthew Michael Carnahan don't know what kind of movie they've actually made -- or would like to pretend they've made another kind.
Unless you're 15 at heart, you may need anger management yourself after sitting through this aggressively crass comedy, which alternates between mean-spirited slapstick and arbitrary uplift.
Stirring, likable and unashamedly formulaic.
One of the pleasures of Blitz's film is that it immerses us in the fraught, competitive pressures of the high-school debate world-like Spellbound, it gets the details right.
Decent-enough entertainment, though it's hardly going to breathe new life to a genre whose demise has been reported for at least 30 years.
This flamboyant, Peckinpah-ish ode to male bonding has a melancholy, fin de siècle splendor.
The considerable power of the film is contained in Jones's hard-bitten, movingly understated performance.
For all its hothouse passions and sometimes brutally explicit sex scenes, the storytelling seems curiously stolid, the style too movie-ish for its own good.
Directed with patient, low-key sensitivity, it never goes for a cheap laugh at its protagonist's expense.
Rendition manages to take an urgent, important topic and turn it into standard Hollywood melodrama. What a waste.
A visual marvel, every frame packed to the gills with clever details, Finding Nemo is the best big-studio release so far this year.

As unexpected as some of its plot twists is the fact that this unapologetic genre movie was directed by Spike Lee, who has never sold himself as Mr. Entertainment. But here it is, a Spike Lee joint that's downright fun.
You want to know more about their private lives than you get. But most viewers may be too stoked by the sheer adrenaline rush of the subject to care.
The backlash just proves how deep a nerve the faux Kazakh journalist has hit.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This may be a less than ideal "Earnest," but it still has delights...
Zatoichi is a mix-and-match crowd-pleaser that shouldn't add up, but delightfully does.
Howard's movie skillfully delivers that primal, heart-pounding satisfaction that is the promise of all boxing tales.
...this snappy installment is a marked improvement over John Woo's surprisingly dull sequel, though the set pieces lack the elegance and visual coherence of the Brian de Palma original.
The vivid clarity of the images, the compressed fury of the tale, are impossible to get out of your head.
Elegantly shot by Bojan Bazelli and designed by Tom Duffield, with a chilling Hans Zimmer score, this visually stunning movie serves up generous dollops of designer creepiness.
So disarmingly eager to please that only a stone-faced kung fu purist could object.

With Saraband, the great writer-director has stepped back into the ring for one last epic wrestle with his demons. There is, as always, no easy outcome. But no one ever fought for higher emotional and spiritual stakes.
These whispered ruminations are beautifully written, but whose voice are we hearing?
Kong is a showy, state-of-the-art popcorn movie, faithful to the spirit of the 1933 original but generously adrenalized with the best effects money can buy.
School of Rock made me laugh harder than any movie I've seen this year.
At its best, 8 Mile illuminates the culture out of which rap springs, at once an art form, provocation and survival mechanism.
The first big studio movie of 2002 I didn't want to end.
It's a romantic comedy on the verge of a nervous breakdown.
It's Almodovar's most mature and mysterious movie.
Not to be missed in any language. In a year that has given us such marvelous animated movies as Ratatouille and Paprika, this vibrant, sly and moving personal odyssey takes pride of place.

Lucidly, dramatically and without resorting to partisan rhetoric, Charles Ferguson's not-to-be-missed documentary "No End in Sight" lays out in convincing, appalling detail the disastrous missteps of the U.S. occupation of Iraq.
[A] work [of] blistering intensity -- and filmmaking that can make your jaw drop.
The urban Maori milieu, however, is something we haven't seen before, and the images stay with you.
No matter how well you know this tale, it still packs a wallop.
So chic, studied and murky it resembles a cross between a Nike commercial and a bad Polish art film.
Obviously this is not everybody's cup of weird tea: you must have a taste for the esthetics of disgust. For those up to the dare, it's one clammily compelling movie.
Instead of cool twenty-something irony, Smith startles us with raw emotional honesty.
A twisted comedy for twisted times, this movie made me happy. Go figure.
The unfussy, tossed-off quality actually helps give this original story zippy irreverence some of Disney's plusher cartoons lack.
Hoop Dreams has shown us that the rules of the game are stacked against kids like Gates and Agee. Even better, it shows us how they fight back, with the inside moves of hope.
Fluff with an edge, Four Weddings brings a venerable old genre delightfully up to date.

This movie is about giving us a privileged glimpse of the Stones in action. It's a record of an astonishing musical chemistry that has been evolving, with no signs of calcification, for nearly five decades.
Leatherheads is laid-back, amiable and terminally tepid.

The good news: there are many twists, turns, subplots and surprises that the coming attractions don't even hint at. The bad news: these twists and turns are so preposterous, or so irrelevant, that they undermine the movie they're meant to tart up.

Working within the constraints of a big studio film has brought out Gilliam's best: he's become a true storyteller and a wonderful director of actors. This time he delights not only the eye but the soul.
Chen's remarkable movie uses an unusual love triangle to telescope more than 50 years of tumultuous Chinese history.
movie_title: Farewell My Concubine (Ba wang bie ji) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: This is a very skillfully made corporate product, but I wonder who, exactly, will be fully satisfied.
As a Revenge of the Nerds redux, Superbad isn't perfect. But it's super close.
A comedy, romance and supernatural thriller rolled into one, Ghost is a zippy pastiche that somehow manages to seem fresh even though it's built entirely out of borrowed parts.

Hancock's surface-skimming script is too formulaic for the job. There's enough material here for a crisp 90-minute entertainment. At 2+ hours, the leisurely, mildly engaging A Perfect World barely sputters across the finish line.
First-time director Frank Marshall has long been Steven Spielberg's producer, and he's learned the master's lessons well.
Lee is in fine form.
Forget the hype. Now for the real question: How's the damn movie? Answer: Pretty darn swell.
I've rarely laughed so much at a movie I generally disliked.
You have to pay close attention to follow the double-crossing intricacies of the plot, but the reward for your work is dark and dirty fun.
It has a generosity toward all its characters that rescues it from predictability.
...Hunt, in her directorial debut, can't seem to decide whether she'd rather make a spicy ethnic dish or bland comfort food.
Watching the movie work itself into an operatic frenzy, one remains curiously detached: the grand gestures are there, but where's the music?
Torn between celebration and sendup, CB4 misses its big target as often as it hits.
Conceptually, this savage cartoon ends up as trapped in surfaces as its shallow antihero: it's all dressed up with nowhere to go.
Though Parker's heart, and his facts, are in the right place, he's succeeded in reducing a powerful story of institutional racism into an unforgivably dull film.
Forster's solid, unpretentious movie hits its marks squarely, and isn't afraid to wear its heart on its sleeve.
The performances are pitched at just the right scale: theatrically exaggerated but untainted by "Broadway" bombast. Who knew Burton would have such an uncanny feel for how to film a musical?
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sergio Sanchez's richly ambiguous screenplay allows you to interpret what you are watching on both a supernatural and a psychological level, and either way is equally unnerving.
Titanic is big, bold, touchingly uncynical filmmaking.
Out of each of these uprooted characters are spun stories of love, loyalty and betrayal.
A smart and wicked delight
If I were a 10-year-old boy, I'd probably think it was the coolest movie going.

That this relentless barrage of psychological and physical torture is extremely well made and powerfully performed -- Watts hurls herself into her physically demanding role with heroic conviction -- somehow makes it worse.
Boldly self conscious, Poison switches channels among its three stylistically varied but thematically linked tales with cumulative, claustrophobic power.
A Bronx Tale is a deliciously well-observed memory piece about growing up in the '60s that marks the vital debut of director Robert De Niro.
This arty melodrama is not likely to make teenage America get down with Shakespeare.

The talented Glazer keeps things crisp, clean and purposeful. The only flab on this film is around the waist of its sybaritic hero, a working-class crook who has finally gotten a taste of the good life, and doesn't want to lose it.
Hoffman brings out the best in Hanks -- they riff off each other with delicious comic teamwork.
Makes up for its gaps in logic with its breezy tone and its technological razzledazzle.
It seemed like a good idea, but the more you think about it, the clearer it becomes that The Avengers should never have been turned into a movie.
The semifunny Semi-Pro is amiable enough, but you never feel there's much at stake.
Glimcher's movie knows how to let down its hair and live for the night.

Reservoir Dogs is a bad boy's movie, show-offy and more than a little decadent. Its saving grace, and its limitation, is in its cool cartoonishness. It never invites any real emotional identification with these crooks.
One can make excuses for a 23-year-old writer's misunderstanding of human behavior, but how could Mike Nichols look at himself in the mirror when he directed such dumbfounding scenes.

It is, first and foremost, a visual delight, a Victorian picture book come to life, from its brief prologue in India through its darkly enchanted recreation of Misselthwaite Manor on the Yorkshire moors.
It's Whoopi and the girls who keep this confection tasty.
Happily, the world is now discovering what a small but ardent cult has known all along-that Jane Campion is one of the most splendid filmmakers around.
The prickly, conservative, jacket-and-tie iconoclasm of Barcelona is like nothing else around.

A real artist could make something incisive or darkly hilarious out of this moral tightrope act. Schumacher, veering recklessly between social satire, kick-ass fantasy and damsel-in-distress melodrama, plays the game for opportunistic cheap thrills.
I wouldn't dream of giving away the ending, but it's not likely to satisfy either the action crowd or Matheson fans.
It's not the actors' fault that no one is able to break through the film's gorgeous but chilly surface. You watch Casino with respect and appreciation, reveling in its documentary sense of detail.
Kipling purists may not cotton to Disney's new live-action version of The Jungle Book, but it's hard to think of anyone else who won't be enchanted.
The movie goes down easy, but there's a thin line here: is this an homage or a parasite?
Take the movie's first words to heart: watch closely. You'll be well rewarded.
It's bravura filmmaking in the jittery, handheld, frenetically edited Paul Greengrass style.
On so many levels, a risibly bad movie.
The journey itself is more charming, and less sentimental, than you might suspect.
Cusack is a master at playing smart, frazzled, self-flagellating hipsters, and the movie, propelled by his arias of angst, lets him strut his best stuff.
Superbly marketed, Pearl Harbor is the very model of a modern blockbuster. Will it matter that almost nothing about its human drama rings true?
A.I. exhilarates, frustrates and provokes: it's the most ambitious Hollywood movie in sight.
Gets most of the book's events in, but loses much of the lightness and charm of Rowling's vision.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Field exhibits a mastery of his craft many filmmakers never acquire in a lifetime.
It has real passion, real emotion, real terror, and a tactile sense of evil.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A decidedly mixed bag.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A refreshing summer movie.
This road movie gives you emotional whiplash, and you'll be glad you went along for the ride.
What's remarkable is how immediately, after a full year, The Two Towers seizes your attention, and how urgently it holds you through three seamless, action-packed hours.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A delicious cat-and-mouse game flecked with intriguing Oedipal undertones.
Renee Zellweger and Catherine Zeta-Jones put on quite a show in Rob Marshall's dazzling cinematic rethinking of the 1975 Kander and Ebb musical directed by Bob Fosse.
In going home to tell Szpilman's story Polanski seems reborn: once again he's become a filmmaker who matters.
You have to honor its mad ambition. But sadly, it feels like a dream too long deferred.
Before it degenerates into Indiana Potter and the Chamber of Doom, the movie holds promise.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Reloaded is more of a straight-ahead action movie than the original, and it's filled with spectacular mayhem.
Cold Mountain is a movie of episodes, and Minghella pulls off dazzling set pieces: he knows how to infuse violence with emotion, so it never seems gratuitous.
There are pleasures to be had in the handsome, heroic The Last Samurai. But they're all on the surface.
The second installment was better than the first, and this one is best of all.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of being moved by Christ's suffering, or awed by his sacrifice, I felt abused by a filmmaker intent on punishing an audience, for who knows what sins.
[A] chilly, caustic, foul-mouthed anatomy of modern romance.
Lucas manages to turn the audience's familiarity to his advantage: like a jigsaw puzzle whose final form has always been known, the fun is in discovering how the last pieces fit.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A minimalist almost-love story told with epic flourishes.
They've managed to avoid the usual asylum-movie cliches.
Many of the scenes feel shapeless and flat-they're not ended, but abandoned.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: There is something wonderfully improbable, anachronistic and quixotic about Chicken Run.
Gibson gives the part his all, but he can't create a coherent character: the movie won't let him.
As well-crafted and sensitive as it is, the movie remains one step removed from inspiration.
Like people who compulsively giggle whenever they tell you bad news, the movie runs for cover in lame, comic shtick.
A swirling, fluid retelling of the tale that packs an impressive cargo of laughs, thrills and wonders into a watertight 88 minutes!
A lumbering, self-important three-hour melodrama that defies credibility at every turn.
Anyone with a taste for high-risk filmmaking won't want to miss it.
If ever there was an example of a director's getting in the way of a story, this is it.
On many levels, Keeping the Faith is a fine film.
A rousing, hugely entertaining movie.
A likable, lively little ditty -- one theme, some clever variations -- that never wears out its welcome.
Wonder Boys doesn't hit you over the head--its wackiness as well as its humanity slips up on you, catches you off guard.
South Park has a gag-to-laugh ratio even higher than the new Austin Powers.
I don't know how a movie this original got made today, but thank God for wonderful aberrations.

Ron Howard and screenwriter Akiva Goldsman struggle mightily to cram as much as possible of Dan Brown's labyrinthine thriller into a 2-hour-28-minute running time, resulting in a movie both overstuffed and underwhelming.
A film whose tone is out of sync with the simple, ribald conceit and is only mildly amusing at best.
Kaufman always wanted to keep us guessing, and this movie respects his wishes.
Charismatic!
As in the original, the superrealist images beguile us with their bold wit, and the storytelling is so tight, urgent and inventive there doesn't seem to be a wasted moment.
American Beauty is a very funny film that packs an unexpected emotional wallop.
The heat generated by these two attractive stars barely rises above room temperature.
This is a movie afraid of its own shadows.
[Stone's] most entertaining movie in years.
Relentless without being overbearing, this is one likely blockbuster that doesn't feel too big for its britches. It's a friendly juggernaut.

Magnolia's flaws are sins of excess. It's all too much-too much emotion, too much intensity, too many climaxes. Still, why complain in the face of so much bounty? At its best, Magnolia towers over most Hollywood films this year.
Silly as it is, The Contender has a lurid zest that keeps you hooked, and a rambunctiously good cast.
Jedi is downright repetitive!
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: The Empire Strikes Back is a technological triumph, a cornucopia of intergalactic tchotchkes.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: A film of brilliant pieces and dazzling shots!
Vaughn, who made the enjoyably tricky gangster movie Layer Cake, gets points for ambition, but this antic fantasy eludes his grasp.
Cars inspires more admiration than elation. It dazzles even as it disappoints.
...the film's urgency can tilt toward shrillness, but nobody else has made the disaster of Guantánamo so painfully vivid.
The Namesake illuminates the immigrant experience in ways that feel at once exotic and deeply familiar.
The tale is filled with funny, gritty Tarantino lowlife gab and a respectable body count, but what is most striking is the film's gallantry and sweetness.
The Wind that Shakes the Barley is dense, brutal, with moments of shattering emotional power, and the cast performs with fierce conviction.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Touching the Void leaves you emotionally and physically spent, and grateful it was only a movie, not a mountain, you had to endure.

As the political rhetoric between Washington and Tehran becomes dangerously overheated, Offside offers an intimate antidote: an affectionate glimpse into the cultural schisms that young Tehranis face every day.
A provocative and blackly comic portrait of a con artist who is ultimately a pawn in a much larger and more intricate conspiracy than even he can fabricate.
[A] jolly, oddly compelling and genuinely suspenseful documentary.
Kasdan has made a winning if overly pat first feature notable for its keen ear, its preference for character over plot and its refreshing modesty.
Summer hasn't arrived, but the funniest riff on a summer movie genre has already landed.
Zoo avoids any taint of exploitation, but it errs on the opposite extreme. I came away from it wanting a little less Art and a lot more simple reportage.
It's absolutely mesmerizing.

Spider-Man 3 is nothing if not eclectic, but somehow this ambitious mishmash works. Action-packed, with all the digital fireworks that a $250 million (or more) budget can buy, it's both the most grandiose chapter and the nuttiest.
Polley gets great work from the entire cast.
28 Weeks Later delivers jolts of fright with alarming regularity.
Paprika expands your notion of what animation can achieve. You wake from it as if from a dream: spooked, provoked and exhilarated.

The plot is not only hard to follow, there seems to be nothing real at stake. Half the characters are already dead, and half the movie seems to involve swordfights with dead people who can't be killed with swords.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Judd Apatow is making the freshest, most honest mainstream comedies in Hollywood.

There's actually a coherent script, and there are some real laughs. Not big laughs, mind you, but a fairly steady stream of smiles and chuckles. And their newest caper is, as expected, fiendishly complex and outlandishly executed.
Winterbottom's aversion to sentimentality doesn't mean you won't be moved by A Mighty Heart.

A film as rich as a sauce béarnaise, as refreshing as a raspberry sorbet, and a lot less predictable than the damn food metaphors and adjectives all us critics will churn out to describe it. OK, one more and then I'll be done: it's yummy.
As taut and exciting as many edge-of-your-seat Hollywood escape movies.

The storytelling seems occasionally disjointed, but...for all the special-effects wizardry, that touch of film magic never surfaces. There's fireworks and action and much swooshing about, but this interim installment seems stuck in one nightmarish gear.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This bright, bouncy movie musical is a happy surprise, a candy-colored ode to outsiders that left me with a big grin.
Brilliant, alcoholic and self-destructive, Greene is the fascinating subject of Kasi Lemmons's funky, R&B-driven biopic -- a vital entertainment that struts confidently between comedy and drama.
There is something to be said for a movie that may end up preaching, for a change, to the unconverted. If only the laughs were bigger, smarter and more frequent than they are.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie holds you in its grip from start to finish.
Zbanic's deeply personal saga allows us to see the savage price that women paid in the Balkan wars.
It isn't often a movie has the power to force a country to do the right thing.
Avenue Montaigne is a tasty specimen of Gallic comfort food: it's well-sauced, it goes down easy and it satisfies.
Dramatically anorexic.
This indie, a sweet, tart and smart satire about a family of losers in a world obsessed with winning, is an authentic crowd pleaser. There's been no more satisfying American comedy this year.
Miami Vice delivers the thrills, atmosphere and romance it promises, but it doesn't resonate like major Mann.
Piercingly moving and utterly unpolitical, World Trade Center holds us in a fierce grip.
Forest Whitaker, uncorking the power that he usually holds in check, gives a chilling, bravura performance as Ugandan tyrant Idi Amin.
Wilson's overgrown adolescent, Winslet's bored, discontented wife and Haley's creepy, self-loathing sex offender are complex, deeply flawed characters -- they're the 'little children.'
The Departed is Scorsese's most purely enjoyable movie in years.
If the brush strokes are sometimes a bit sloppy, the grand design of Shortbus endears.
An epic both raw and contemplative.
If Babel were a football game, I'd flag it 15 yards for piling on. Others may want to give it an Oscar. To each his own.
Almodóvar's generous vision isn't just unique, it's color-coordinated.
Though it lacks Wallace and Gromit's charm, its mile-a-minute inventiveness is impressive.
Next to Singer's champagne, most recent superhero adventure movies are barely sparkling cider.
It's preposterous, but never dull: Scott whips the action into a taut, tasty lather.
The movie belongs to Hudson as the proud, self-destructive Effie. When she's center stage, Dreamgirls transports you to movie musical heaven.
The harder Apocalypto works to shock and excite you, the less shocked and excited you become, until you may find yourself beset by the urge to giggle.
Soderbergh's skill, intelligence and love for the genre are never in doubt. But, as it turns out, you can't play it again, Sam.
Children of Men leaves too many questions unanswered, yet it has a stunning visceral impact. You can forgive a lot in the face of filmmaking this dazzling.
Pan's Labyrinth unfolds with the confidence of a classical fable, one that paradoxically feels both timeless and startlingly new.
Superbly acted, unblinking and unhysterical, it looks beyond politics into the hearts and minds of the men we needed to call 'the enemy,' and lets us see ourselves.
Even if the movie's vast reach exceeds its grasp, it's a spellbinding history lesson.
...A heartbreaking comedy that is simultaneously funny and sad, raunchy and sweet, funky and elegiac.
Notes on a Scandal is a wicked delight.
[An] honorable but dogged effort.
It's hard to believe this is von Donnersmarck's first feature. His storytelling gifts have the novelistic richness of a seasoned master.
A wonderfully taut cat-and-mouse thriller. It features a performance by Chris Cooper, as the eccentric, contradictory Hanssen, that ought to be remembered as one of the year's best come December.
All the actors get their Big Moments, but verisimilitude goes out the window.
Iron Man may not be distinguished enough to convert you to the cause. But Downey and Favreau give the movie a quirky flavor it can call its own. For that we can be grateful.
Baby Mama is formulaic, but this broad odd-couple girl comedy has the advantage of knowing what it is.
It succeeds in bringing O'Barr's comic-book vision to life, but there's little else going on behind the graphic razzle-dazzle and the moody, ominous soundtrack.
What's remarkable is how much of City of Hope's epic ambition pays off, with a power that never becomes grandiloquent.

Despite quirky, fresh moments and a watchful, touching performance from Hann-Byrd, the movie lurches unsteadily from scene to scene, punctuated by odd bursts of irrelevant melodrama and culminating in an ending that is frankly baffling.
Billy Bathgate isn't an embarrassment, but it's a puzzle. Watching it, you can't locate the passion that drew the filmmakers to it in the first place.

It gives you a pumped-up, thrill-happy ride (assuming you have a stomach for violent pulp) but it doesn't linger in the mind as Scorsese's richest movies do. It's a swell B movie dressed in haute cinematic couture.
For a big, glitzy Hollywood entertainment, Rydell's movie opens a surprising number of wounds, and warns us to suspect the very glamour it revels in. It's no small accomplishment.
Kasdan's movie doesn't succeed, but see it: it's the season's most fascinating failure.
What begins as an intoxicating champagne cocktail goes flat. Ultimately, surprisingly, the film's wildly beating heart is cold.

Designed to get the audience rooting for this upper-class underdog, the movie accomplishes its task with military efficiency. But since the deck is stacked and the cards well worn, it hardly seems a victory to cherish.

if you can overlook the obvious flaws--a bumpy beginning, a villain whose motive is both too obvious and hard to swallow--The Bodyguard has its flashy, shallow pleasures. There's some wit in Kasdan's script, and dread in the Oscar-ceremony climax.
A teasing, seductive intimacy immediately develops....The Crying Game is a very good movie indeed. It leaves one giddy.
The Lover's rarefied sensibility takes getting used to; once its spell is cast, you won't want to blink.

Coppola's remake throws so much fancy technique at its story that the usually foolproof drama at its core gets drowned in a tide of images. It's not scary, it's not suspenseful and its eroticism is largely theoretical.

Sometimes Zebrahead spells things out too neatly, and the talk at the end gets a little didactic. But Drazan's clear-eyed affection for his characters is contagious. His heartfelt, plain-spoken movie achieves real, unforced power.
Shot in Brooklyn in 12 days on a $38,000 budget, this flawlessly acted movie about two dead-end thieves owes an obvious debt to Mean Streets, yet it finds an urgent, hyperreal style all its own.
This $50 million spectacle must be one of the least entertaining epic films ever made.

The Last of the Mohicans gets off to a bumpy start, gathers feeling and momentum and comes roaring into the homestretch at full gallop. When this historical adventure kicks in, it's thrilling in the way old-fashioned epics used to be.
After a summer in Hollywood fantasyland, at last we have an American movie that rattles our cage-and pokes a sharp spear into the body politic. Now that's entertainment.

A Brief History of Time is an elegant, inspirational and mysterious movie. Morris turns abstract ideas into haunting images, and keeps them spinning in the air with the finesse, and playfulness, of a master juggler.

Give credit where credit is due: Ritchie and screenwriter Steven McKay know how to turn their crowd-pleasing tricks. It's one sucker punch after another, but you'd have to be a rock not to fall for it.
The formula betrays the fine work of Leigh and Fonda, whose characters are much too interesting to find themselves stranded in a tony but ultimately tired slasher movie.
As a comedy, "Buffy" is a horror show, and vice versa.
Zemeckis has always relished technical challenges; once again he pulls them off with high style.

It's a novel, and zany, romantic dilemma, and though Lucas gets plenty of laughs out of this preposterous situation, what's singular about Prelude to a Kiss is the depth of feeling it wrests from this whimsical conceit.
Much of Patriot Games is routine: good guys and bad guys running around with heavy artillery. But at its best moments, Noyce and Ford snap the genre back to life.
Just at the point when Alien 3 should kick into high terror gear, it becomes clear that this hushed, somber sequel doesn't know how to deliver the goods.
The Rapture is far from perfect, but it's a riveting act of provocation.

Solomon's screenplay treads a delicate line between wit and preciousness; at its weakest, Zwick's direction goes for the canned poignance of TV. Beut there's a lot to relish in this funny, bittersweet, sharply written comedy.
The intimate rhythms these two superb actors work up together capture a lifetime of marriage. Duvall and Ladd are the true heart and soul of Rambling Rose.
The movie oversells its whimsy and fits its quirkiness into a sitcom formula that's as preordained as the hero's moral rejuvenation.

Hereafter confronts a topic that could have descended into mawkish, mystical hokum, but not in Eastwood's no-nonsense, uncynical hands. He looks at death, and beyond, with clear, open, inquisitive eyes.
Baron Cohen is, without doubt, the ballsiest comic of his generation-and one of the brightest. But it's hard to imagine him taking the guerrilla shock tactics of Borat and Brüno any further.

Some will call his Woodstock naive, but that's what he intends: the movie is a sweet, anecdotal, comic embrace, a gentle reminder that it was once possible to overcome the cynicism of the times and believe that "the flow" leads in a benign direction.
This is fun, but it turns Boris's doomsday neurotic rants into mere cartoon caterwauling. Levant, who never got a happy ending, would no doubt sneer.
Hilarious, satirical and melancholy, "Rudo y Cursi" may not go as deep as "Y Tu Mamá También," but it has a similar vivacity.

Penn may be the main attraction, but this is very much an ensemble piece. Emile Hirsch, as cheeky street kid turned activist Cleve Jones, Diego Luna as Milk's annoyingly needy, unstable second lover and James Franco's Scott, add to the communal spirit.

"Australia" is a shameless-and shamelessly entertaining-pastiche. It works because Luhrmann, a true believer in movie-movie magic, stamps it all with the force of his own extravagant, generous personality.

"The Edge of Heaven"'s intricate, almost melodramatic plot shamelessly employs coincidences-much the way "Babel" did-but where that movie's tragic events seemed gratuitous and strained, Akin has a richer, deeper sense of character.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's details like that-too bizarre not to be true-that give "The Counterfeiters" its bitter wallop. It's an astonishing tale of cunning, compromise and survival.
The understated passion of The Long Walk Home sneaks up on your emotions.
These doomed grifters deserve instant admission into the film noir pantheon.
More to the point, L.A. Story is giddy fun.
This is both recommendation and warning: Once Around is easy to take but hard to swallow.
But ultimately it's [Bruce] Willis who makes this loopy action movie so endearing...Nobody dies it better.
Duke keeps this tangled tale of lust and larceny bouncing with a disreputable, funloving B-movie energy that's hard to resist.

Whether you regard her as a symptom or a cure for a culture still locked in its eternal battle between the puritanical and the prurient, Madonna's at the barricades. In Truth or Dare, she's at her button-pushing best.
Soderbergh's talent is not in doubt; you can see, in the often elegant images shot by Walt Lloyd, a real filmmaker at work. But his choice of material is dubious.
Genuine escapism may be the true lost art of movies, which is all the more reason to celebrate the unexpected charm of the English/Irish comedy Hear My Song.

Masterfully edited, the film combines footage the band made for its Web site and footage shot by Kopple and Peck over the last two years. The filmmakers are clearly in awe of the Chicks' fighting spirit.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Still, the multicultural cast is fun, the images have a painterly beauty and there are some beguiling comic touches before the story sinks into a swamp of solemn metaphysical glop.

Poised halfway between the action conventions of New Jack City and the personal grit of Straight Out of Brooklyn, Juice doesn't have the pizzaz or the insight, to satisfy as either exploitation or art.
The twins are played by 19-year-old real-life brothers Luke and Harry Treadaway. They're sexy, touching and macabre, and you can't keep your eyes off them.
This is the most personal, deeply felt film from the gifted director of "Under the Sand" and "Swimming Pool." Ozon leaches his melodrama of all sentimentality, and moves us all the more.

Shot with startling dream sequences, punctuated by surreal circus imagery, propelled by Anne Dudley's sublimely moody score, The Miracle creates a world charged with youthful romanticism yet tempered by the comic tranquillity of recollection.
The Doctor is that rare specimen--a big studio movie that treats the audience (and its own characters) with intelligence and respect. It cuts close to the bone.
Be grateful for the genuine amusement Dead Again supplies. It may be cotton candy, but it's well spun.
Stylishly balancing thrills, mysticism and political outrage, Apted's produced his most absorbing movie since Coal Miner's Daughter.

Shelton's strength is character, streetwise wit and funky, lived-in sexuality. Snipes, one of our most versatile young actors, gets to demonstrate his wonderful comic chops, and Harrelson, whose goofiness is part of his scam, partners him beautifully.

It unavoidably loses some of its brilliance on film: much of the fun was the suspense of seeing live actors survive the demands of the slapstick. But Bogdanovich's frenetic transplant supplies so many belly laughs it seems ill-spirited to complain.
Go Fish is a blithe and funkily stylish celebration of community -- a twentysomething girl-meets-girl comedy whose charm is in its matter-of-fact disregard for what a straight audience might think.
I kept wondering how the filmmakers mustered up the energy to go to work every morning.
movie_title: City Slickers 2 - The Legend of Curly's Gold (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Lee seems to confuse noise with drama: the bickering Carmichaels create quite a racket, but we're seldom moved by their plight. In his most desperate moment, Lee shoots a long sequence through a distorted lens.
It's crude and sometimes exhausting, but when You So Crazy is cooking, it takes you to the other, liberating side of embarrassment.
Get back, get back to where you once belonged, you want to shout. But the movie is stuck in the wrong groove.
Fleming's vision may be less tony than the overrated Best Foreign Film, but it's truer. And a lot more fun.

You keep rooting for Jimmy Hollywood, because it has the bittersweet, unexpected flavors of a personal vision. It may not be Hollywood's idea of a socko entertainment, but, unlike many a hit, it follows you home.
The greatest actors in the world can't overcome a script that boils everything down to the Esperanto of cliche.
Recklessly perched on the edge of the ludicrous, this examination of a destructive erotic passion unfolds with an unsettling mixture of steam and mordant iron.
Jim Sheridan tells his gripping tale with a fury that stokes up an audience the way early Costa Gavras movies used to do.
movie_title: In the Name of the Father (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Apted's Blink walks a fine line, but if you're willing to accept it on its frankly formulaic terms, it delivers some good jolts.
Intersection pretends to be a movie of grown-up, middle-aged concerns, but it plays like a rather dull and pointless soap opera.
Written with verve and played with grace, Reality Bites is too smart to pass itself off as a definitive statement, but it gets the details delightfully right.
Aileen Wuornos is raw, fascinating and less than ideally organized. But as a portrait of a world obsessed with cashing in on tragedy, it couldn't be more timely.
movie_title: Aileen Wuornos - The Selling of a Serial Killer (1993)

movie_review_blurb: The humanity is spread around with a quirky, generous hand, reason enough to distinguish this quiet, low-tech comedy in a season of big-bang juvenilia.
Waterworld is a pretty damn good summer movie. There, I've said it...it's a breezy, clever entertainment with stirring effects.
[Nine Months] threatens to turn an interesting actor into a self-parodying commodity.

Kids is stunningly anti-erotic, though not untainted by sensationalism. By condensing all this inflammatory material into a 24-hour time frame, Clark and Harmony Korine create an overwrought narrative that's sometimes tedious in its relentlesshess.
There's no moment in Jefferson in Paris when you can feel why the filmmakers had to tell this story. All dressed up, this elegant movie has nowhere to go.
Kids will be bored, the rest of us baffled.
Minghella puts us inside Ripley's head, inviting us to share his envy and giddy excitement even as we recognize his warped need to be someone he's not.
You may find yourself holding your breath through much of The Boys of St. Vincent. It's a shock to see this level of emotional honesty on TV.

Priest shouldn't be missed -- much of it is strong and moving. My reservation is not that it bites off more than it can chew (these days, big teeth are welcome) but that there's something mechanical about its mastication.
Higher Learning sells its soul (and its brain) for overwrought melodrama.
Hollywood has been in love with mobsters since the beginning of movies. But the other side of the equation has seldom been considered. That is, until now.
John Hughes's subjects have become increasingly puerile. So, alas, have his movies.
The movie is enlightening, not because it transmits new information, but in the way that movies enlighten, through a synergy of images and rhythms that makes us sense the world in a new way.
Though well acted, and handsomely shot by veteran Adam Holender, Fresh sacrifices real emotion for thriller contrivances. It's a tourist's drive through inner-city hell.
Quiz Show is superbly shot (by Michael Ballhaus), and the acting ensemble could hardly be better.
Belgian director Jaco Van Dormael makes his dazzlingly inventive debut with this intricately constructed tale of an old man.
Pakula's always had a cool style, tending toward solemnity, but let's face it, All the President's Men this movie is not. You wish he'd have a little more fun with the pulpy material.
Demolition Man is a movie that should have been fun, and isn't.

The Man Without a Face is such a noble, well-intentioned little film that one feels like an ogre picking on it. Alternately poky and melodramatic--and occasionally witty and insightful--the uneven screenplay too often strains credibility.
The story he is telling--about parenting, teachers and students, and the nature of competition--is a rich one, and Zaillian tells it with warmth, humor and zest. The cast is first-rate.
The good news is that once the gears of the plot kick in, Allen's expert comic timing proves as beguiling as ever.
Generously exciting, In the Line of Fire is mercifully free of that artificial energy that makes so many new movies look as if they were created with steroids.
A summer genre movie for grown-ups, The Firm helps restore faith in Hollywood professionalism.
Last Action Hero loses control of itself.

Self-consciousness infects Nora Ephron's sweet but perilously thin love story, Sleepless in Seattle...such are the perils of these postmodernist times: even our love stories feed off borrowed emotion.

Cliffhanger does its damnedest to see that the audience gets its money's worth of thrills. But for all the state-of-the-art stunt work, the movie has little personality; it's ice cream without flavor.
It's the spritely comic timing of the fine Hollywood ensemble that keeps Dave percolating. This affable, well-built comedy is Reitman's best since Ghostbusters.
See it for [Ryan] Gosling and [Michelle] Williams, but be advised: if you take a date, you'll be sorry.
This fierce, smart jape gets you shaking with laughter, then leaves you simply shaking.

The beauty of This Boy's Life is in the details: this meticulously observed story gets the look of the late '50s down pat and, more important, captures the dissonance between the era's ideals of nuclear-family life and painfully deracinated reality.
Like Water For Chocolate is an extravagant, playful romantic fable that celebrates passion, liberation and the spirit of women but never forgets that unbridled ecstasy comes at a cost.
movie_title: Like Water for Chocolate (Como Agua para Chocolate) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Part fairy tale, part psychodrama, Olivier Olivier is strong, unsettling stuff. Holland is a filmmaker who looks deep into the twisted heart of love and won't settle for easy answers.
Body of Evidence won't be remembered for classic plotting or brilliant legal gambits. But give it its due: it holds one's attention.
Marshall is a good technician, but there's no sense of artistic adventure in his sometimes exciting, sometimes draggy movie. He's content to scratch the surface of a great and harrowing story.

It's to Malle and his gifted company's credit that this posh bodice-ripper often comes close to achieving its tragic ambitions. But the stylish Damage is a lot easier to enjoy if one doesn't feel compelled to take it seriously.

The questions this movie raises about the medical establishment, drug testing and the clash between science and compassion cannot fail to evoke the battles raging over AIDS. Lorenzo's Oil is strong medicine indeed.
The clever, facile Peter's Friends doesn't bear much scrutiny, and its attempts at pathos are more opportunistic than earned. Still, Branagh knows how to put on a lively show.
Big and portentous, Hoffa feels like a series of acting exercises inflated to epic proportions. But as a portrait of unionism's most controversial figure, it offers only flickering illumination.
The failure of Barry Levinson's Toys is of a different order: it's the kind of folly only a very fine filmmaker could make, a labor of misguided love.
The movie is lively but half-baked: it dribbles away its promising subject. Some Christmas feast this has turned out to be: it's like munching on leftovers.
A comedy that can make you cry, Used People is the season's most pleasant surprise.
More than anything, Fonda gives this glossy, reasonably entertaining rerun an American raison d'etre.
It's an engrossing tale, and Costner directs with the confidence of a Hollywood veteran well aware that entertainment comes before earnestness.

Not once in the whole silly exercise does he approximate a genuine emotion. Unable to dramatize marital love, he sells it, as if he were pitching perfume. Having nothing credible to play, Moore and Harrelson strike poses of love and anguish.
[An] earnest but misbegotten adaptation, which reduces a moving tour de force to a dull and homiletic house of frenetically shuffled cards.
A sweet pipe dream, Enchanted April won't bear much scrutiny; just bask in it indulgently like a spring sun.
The Freshman has a preposterous plot even the writer's mother couldn't believe, and it strains and creaks down the runway, but when this baby gets off the ground, we're talking seriously funny.
As the plot grows more intricate, strangely the tension dissipates, until finally the movie just seems to run out of breath.

The problem is not simply that Lone's drag wouldn't fool a baby. In the magnified intimacy of the camera's eye, it's clear Hwang doesn't really know who these unlikely lovers are. Metaphors can't carry a movie-flesh and blood is what's required.
Again the Coens take familiar movie tropes and twist them into something new. This may be their most haunting movie.
A movie like this has only one not-so-noble reason to exist: to make us sob. And it just doesn't deliver the goods.
This is the grandest guignol Hollywood has produced in years.

It doesn't suffer from the compulsive tidiness of some of Allen's later movies -- the juices are flowing, the hysteria is closer to the surface -- and in this looser, more volatile atmosphere his extraordinary cast gets to soar.
When was the last time you saw a movie that was quiet, intimate, tender? That let you explore your feelings about the characters without hanging moral signposts around their necks?

Peyton plays upon Claire's deepest anxieties -- her sexual insecurity, her fear of child molesters -- to vicious effect. Hanson and Silver manipulate our anxieties no less adeptly, but a good deal more playfully.
movie_title: The Hand that Rocks the Cradle (1992)

movie_review_blurb: A good half hour too long, and badly in need of some scares, Hook is a huge party cake of a movie, with too much frosting. After the first delicious bite, sugar shock sets in.
It's about seduction, and either you succumb to its inky entrapments or you resist. When its mojo was working, I was happy to be had.
Lee and company have performed a powerful service: they have brought Malcolm X very much to life again, both as man and myth.
Given these fundamental caveats, Deceived is diverting, if disposable, fun. Director Damian Harris knows how to keep an audience's attention.
Hilarious and deadly, this may be Altman's most completely realized film since his glory days in the '70s.
The movie has a comfy, lived-in feel; it doesn't beat you over the head for laughs, or take its horrors-of-New York theme too seriously. Smile and enjoy.
Eastwood tells his haunting, sorrowful saga with such a sure, steady hand, only a very hardened cynic could fail to be moved.
Eastwood's disturbingly human in Unforgiven, a stunning, dark Western that may stand as the actor/director's summation of the form.
The didacticism is, for the most part, gracefully meshed with the storytelling, and the special effects never take over the show.

Fearless is the rare commercial movie that raises more questions than it answers. You leave it in an altered state yourself--moved, not quite satisfied, but certain you've seen something out of the ordinary.

Quantum of Solace isn't frivolous or cheesy, but it isn't all that much fun either. Craig is still the right guy for the job, but for his boiling-on-the-inside performance to work, he needs more to play with.
The Reader asks tough questions, and, to its credit, provides no easy answers.
Doubt stirs up a lot of stormy theatrical weather, but the stolid transfer from stage to screen does Shanley's play no favors.
Lyrical, original, misshapen and deeply felt, this is one flawed beauty of a movie.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: On Broadway, Peter Morgan's Frost/Nixon made for a deliciously smart and dramatic mano a mano. The surprising news is that Frost/Nixon works even better on screen.
My Own Private Idaho is a far cry from seamless, but I would gladly trade a dozen well-made studio movies for one of its vital parts.
W. might have had some impact had it been made four years ago. But it's both too late and too early for a movie about our sitting president.
Rachel Getting Married takes a familiar subject -- the raw nerves of American family life with -- and draws fresh blood.
[Director] Sollett is able to take familiar teen tropes and transform them into low-key magic.
Pakula's strong suit has always been his work with actors, and he's got a lot of good ones at his disposal. Ford gives a smart, self-effacing performance.

Speed Racer creates a timeless, visually seductive world suspended somewhere between the pop '60s and the sci-fi future. Its biggest disappointment, strangely enough, is its raison d'être -- the races themselves.
For all its ambition, the movie ends up using great historical events in the service of a dubious sentimentality.
It'll shake up your beliefs not just about steroids but about competition, hypocrisy, body obsession and American notions of masculinity.
Its familiar genre pleasures are all on the surface.
In this distressingly generic spy spoof, it's not Maxwell who's clueless, but the filmmakers.
As the body count rises, so does the portentous tone, and the relentlessness of Bekmambetov's overamped style becomes oppressive.

A brave, spectacularly entertaining -- and unexpectedly stirring -- account of Flynt's life that asks us to regard the publisher of Hustler magazine as an invaluable champion of our First Amendment freedoms.
The superhero genre screams for a makeover, or at least a smart deconstruction, but Hancock isn't that movie. It just ups the foolishness ante.
You'd have to be a machine for your heart not to melt.
Nolan wants to prove that a superhero movie needn't be disposable, effects-ridden junk food, and you have to admire his ambition.
There's room for more than one Brideshead in this far less glamorous day and age.
Revolutionary Road is impressive, but it feels like a classic encased in amber.
Though McKay and his cast make the most of the material, Step Brothers is constrained by its one-joke concept.
Jurassic Park doesn't have organic flow; it can't disguise its clunky, B-movie soul.
Nair's stereotype-shattering movie -- like the polymorphous culture it illuminates -- borrows from Bollywood, Hollywood and cinema verite, and comes up with something exuberantly its own.
Maybe it's only adults who'll get teary-eyed -- kids just wanna have fun. And they will.
Why is this movie Hitchcock's masterpiece? Because no movie plunges us more deeply into the dizzying heart of erotic obsession.
A winning animated feature that has something for everyone on the age spectrum.
A glorious rebuke to all this summer's recycled, effects-ridden, laboriously "fun" Hollywood disappointments piled along the wayside like so many crashed cars.
The violence in Boyz N the Hood is neither gratuitous nor melodramatic; its aftermath is shattering. Singleton's powerhouse movie has the impact of a stun gun.
Director Charles Herman-Wurmfeld's movie knows what it wants, what its limits are, and delivers its delights accordingly.
Burn After Reading is a blackly comic illustration of Murphy's Law, set in the Washington world of CIA espionage, and populated with a cast of delusional dunces who are a wonder to behold.
To say this is a great comeback for an actor whose talent was exceeded only by his self-destructiveness is obvious.
It's elegantly mounted and never dull -- and always easy on the eyes.
Pellington knows, as did the 1940s master of horror Val Lewton, that what you don't see can raise far more goose bumps than what you do.
Tropic Thunder is the funniest movie of the summer -- so funny, in fact, that you start laughing before the film itself has begun.
For all its state-of-the-art pyrotechnics and breathtaking thrills, this bruisingly exciting movie never loses sight of its humanity. That's its point, and its pride.
A vampire movie like no other.
How do you literalize heaven? It's a problem moviemakers have struggled with forever, and Jackson hasn't solved it.
As an actor, Eastwood has rarely taken on a character as complex as Frankie Dunn.
Slick and violent and reasonably tense, Ransom holds your attention without being the least bit interesting.
Screenwriter Akiva Goldsman's clever solution is to turn the story of a troubled academic into a Hollywood thriller. How? He makes things up.
Tenenbaums doesn't quite jell, but it's a beautiful near miss.

Wes Anderson transports his arch, pristine, melancholic sensibility to India, where three estranged brothers meet after their father's death and hop a train in a quixotic attempt to heal their spiritual wounds.

Just when it seemed that the only hope for crime movies lay in the postmodernist artifice of films like Pulp Fiction, Mann reinvests the genre with brooding, modernist conviction. This one sticks to your gut.
This may sound like a suspense movie, but it's not. There's no mystery (we know who the bad guys are) and the damsel-in-distress angle generates zero tension.

Though it's hard to deny the fierce purity of Gainsbourg's performance, Antichrist plays like an incoherent mix of Gothic horror claptrap and Bergmanesque power struggle. I was more bored and puzzled than shattered and provoked.
This is not exactly standard children's fare, but kids (and their parents) should be smitten by its wit and wisdom.
Kloves has streamlined J. K. Rowling's 700-plus-page opus into cinematic fighting form. And the special effects, which threatened to overwhelm the first two movies, are seamlessly integrated.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An antidote to forced holiday cheer, this scabrously funny misanthropic comedy is not for the whole family.
Ferrell is a hoot. So is much of this witty holiday family entertainment, which, up until the end, when the "true spirit of Christmas" must be reaffirmed, happily favors slapstick over treacle.
Desplechin is an inspired impurist. His Christmas Tale is untidy, overstuffed and delicious: a genuine holiday feast.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Watching this lost soul's flaming descent is a disturbing yet exhilarating experience. Leigh makes art out of his own ambivalence.
As warm and lived-in as an old pair of boots, The Snapper is an honorable feel-good movie.
Some of the parts are undeniably gripping; what gets lost are the characters themselves.
Philadelphia may not be the film Demme's fans expect--its emotionalism is unfiltered by cool. But it has the power to open more than a few blinkered hearts.
Entropy, the inexorable running down of an energy system, may have overtaken the Bond saga.

Hughes may deserve more plaudits as a social worker than a filmmaker, but you have to admit his hokey situation plays. The reason is the five terrific young actors, who bring more conviction to these parts than they perhaps deserve.

It's a funny/scary vision, with a manic edge -- which is why, when you come down from the high of the filmmaking, you may be left with the taste of ashes in your mouth. Altman's artistry can make you happy even when his art offers cold comfort.
We've been down this path of self-discovery with Cruise before, but Crowe's movie is a lot less predictable than you'd expect.
... loses steam when the catfighting abruptly gives way to grim realpolitik.
... hilariously wrongheaded.
Only a snob could resist such a generous level of lunacy.
The filmmakers know the audience is challenging them to top themselves, and they've risen to the bait. Harlin and company build suspense the old-fashioned way. They earn it.
You may never know whether Murphy has completely turned into a machine, but you know the movie has, and boredom sets in.
Depp is subtly winning as a man-child oblivious to his own pent-up rage. But the performance that will take your breath away is DiCaprio's.
Jumpy and ironic, Downey is a quicksilver delight and Kilmer is funny as the gay Perry.
Noisy, campy, overproduced, it's abdicated all solemnity in pursuit of a boom-kaboom videogame esthetic.

Scene by scene, screenwriter Hillary Seitz follows director Erik Skjoldbjaerg's original closely, but this remake deepens and improves upon the Norwegian film by giving Dormer a more complex relationship with Eckhart.
The Last Station slides gracefully between comedy and pathos (it aims for tragedy, but doesn't quite get there).
In its funny, rueful way, Up in the Air touches contemporary American notes few Hollywood movies acknowledge.
Crazy Heart gets to you like a good country song -- not because it tells you something new, but because it tells it well. It's the singer, not the song.
You'll see why, in animation circles, Miyazaki himself is considered one of the gods.
The lapses fade in the face of such a soul-stirring story -- one that would be hard to believe if it were fiction.
It doesn't take long to figure out that Shrek is not going to be your ordinary animated fairy tale.
Just when you thought the last thing the world needed was another violent, self-conscious, hipster homage to film noir, along comes Tarantino to blow away your deja vu.
These depictions of the dementia of war have a hallucinatory power that can stand alongside those of Apocalypse Now.
Even at its most generic, Raimi's amiable movie doesn't forget its human scale.
Ferociously intense, furiously kinetic, it's expressionist film noir science fiction that, like all good sci-fi, peers into the future to shed light on the present.
Never before has Ivory's filmmaking seemed so fluid and confident.
Something about the filmmaker's eccentric, surreal, childlike images seems to strike a deep chord in the mass psyche: he makes nightmares that taste like candy.
The movie has a hushed, sensual intensity and formal elegance that leaves no doubt Ford knows what he's doing behind the camera.

I recommend Hytner's movie highly, but a part of me resists a work that makes the audience feel as noble in our moral certainty as the characters it invites us to deplore. Some part of its power seems borrowed from the thing it hates.
Relish the movie's snappy, low-life high spirits.

The tale's mournful B-movie romanticism-and Pesci's introspective, crablike performance gets under your skin. In its moody, daffy way, The Public Eye gives off an authentic reek of artistic compulsion.
This cautionary fable (Be True to Your Ghoulish Self) may be a little too twisted for little kids but anyone 8 or older will spot the friendly glint behind jack's empty eye sockets.
Let's face it: Culkin's self-reliant suburban warrior has entered a whole generation's pop mythology. He's their Knight in Shining Parka, safely beyond criticism.
movie_title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Casting the less-than-charismatic Dorff may bolster Coppola's thesis, but it's dramatically self-defeating. How can we feel for Johnny, when there's no there there?
The Long Kiss Goodnight is the fall's best summer movie.
The suspense isn't just about who's going to win the big fight, but who's going to emerge from Ward's big, fierce jungle of a family with their lives intact.

Haggis shows a lot of promise as a director: his film is never dull. But he needs to unlearn some of the bad lessons he picked up working in TV, which demands that everything be neat, symmetrical and underlined.
Sillier than the Singer versions, Ratner's movie is also -- for this less-than-reverent X-Men fan -- more satisfying.

Redford does an honorable job emulating the author's unsentimental, laconically witty style. A River Runs Through It is made with reverence and taste, but it only fitfully comes fully alive as a film.
How do you patch together a relationship that has been sundered by grief? The answers it gives, tentative and hard-won, may not be surprising, but they feel right.
Torn between moody grandiosity and cartoonish mayhem, Daredevil tries to have it both ways, and succeeds at neither.

You can do a lot with black comedy: show dead bodies, show naked bodies, juxtapose irony and fear, strike cultural poses, tell jokes -- and you don't need a big budget. You just need attitude. And, hopefully, skill.
The movie is strongest when Lee keeps his eye on the prize: the experiences of ordinary people in an extraordinary time.
The names are big, but the payoff is small.
It is an impressive first feature for its director, Lee Tamahori, and a splendid dramatic vehicle for its stars, especially Rena Owen.
Quaid and Caviezel establish a firm emotional connection in moments that are by turns funny, affecting and eerie.
The movie is decidedly old-fashioned, aiming to send kids and their parents out of the theater feeling good about themselves.
Energetic, uneven but engaging.
A compulsively watchable, well-crafted feature...
Ali didn't fumble often, and neither do Gast and Hackford. This is a love-match of filmmakers and subject. Together, they go the distance.
Wilde is, laudably, not presented as a simple icon or martyr of the gay movement, but as a flawed, admirable, attractive, disappointing human being.
The year's smartest and spikiest date-movie so far.

The simple truth is, any comedian could take Gervais' place in the film, and you probably wouldn't notice. For a comic who likes to put his fingerprints on everything he does, it feels like he's playing it safe.
To the Wonder is visually deep and beautiful, but the characters and story are complete non-factors for the film.
The single most ambitious film since Avatar is stunningly beautiful to look at, but an absolute pain to analyze and admire.
A hilarious, romantic and heartfelt crowd pleaser with genuinely great performances makes for one of the first must-see films of the Fall.
lengthy and dense film packed with a handful of great performances, The Place Beyond the Pines has great ambition but not nearly enough accomplishment.
There is clearly a lot of ambition to The Loved Ones and the near-brilliant leading performances help make the film a unique and terrifying experience.
Compliance will leave you shocked and offended, but it misses out on any opportunity to be anything outside of a dramatization.
I wanted to love it, but Seven Psychopaths is merely a clever film chock full of wasted potential. It looks and acts a lot better than it actually is.
Smashed has great performances and a worthwhile story, but it is overshadowed by bizarre tones and a really disappointing finale.
While The Dictator may appear different than Borat and Brüno, it is very much the same idea as both films, packed with the same jokes and new ones that are more disturbing than they are hilarious.
The Sessions is startlingly bold and just as emotionally mature, with a wonderful story and even better performances.
A stunning, must-see performance by Jude Law helps propel Dom Hemingway into one of the first must-see films of 2014.
Antiviral is an interesting idea for a social satire, but the plot, story, and acting are all weak, and the film owes way too much to David Cronenberg.
Imogene does not set out to be anything important, but it delivers some genuinely hilarious performances from every single one of the lead performances.
Despite having acclaimed director Johnnie To at the helm, this mash-up of the romantic comedy, buddy cop and thriller genres is a total mess from beginning to end.
Mandela: Long Walk To Freedom's story and plot are flawed, but are easily overshadowed by the lead performances by Naomie Harris and an Oscar-worthy Idris Elba.
Escape Plan is an action film with no edge, no real thrills and no reason to exist. Skip it, unless you are a diehard Schwarzenegger fan.
Vince Vaughn does what he can to shine in Ken Scott's Delivery Man, but the film's lack of heart and soul is too much to overcome.
Enemy is a mysterious and strangely atmospheric thriller, but outside of an exceptional dual performance by Jake Gyllenhaal, its enigmatic and nonsensical nature offer very little reason to watch.
While it is impressive that Play The Film was made for $1000, it is a total mess that could have done with less characters and tighter editing.
Spring Breakers is a mainstream art film that is ludicrous amounts of fun, even if the plot is absolutely preposterous and downright silly.
A 2 1/2 -hour tour-de-force of personal style that (with the help of an extraordinary cast) creates more memorable characters than any other movie this year.

It contains four or five humorous, intricately choreographed action sequences that -- while not as riveting as similar episodes in True Lies or Die Hard With a Vengeance -- are enjoyable on that idiot level that even critics possess.
If this movie were a sandwich, it'd be ham on white bread.
Remarkably well-directed and played, the crisp images perfectly framed by cinematographer Jürgen Jürges for maximum effect.
The problem here is pretty much everything.
The writers have sausaged the story (really just a situation) into simple and simplistic sitcom formula, which delivers some laughs.
Director Tom Shadyac and screenwriter Steve Oedekerk have sleekly outfitted a sudsy feel-good formula into an entertaining holiday comic tear-gusher.
Not only do we not care about Bean, we want him to just go away and not bother us anymore.
Species II may be notable only in that it is an extreme, sadly robust example of the troubling trend of modern horror films to give sex a bad name.
Gains little visually from big-screen exposure.
movie_title: Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life (1998)

movie_review_blurb: A scream but no Scream, I Know is a clean, efficient horror picture out at the perfect box-office time.
movie_title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)

movie_review_blurb: What's interesting is pretty much unintentional, centering in the film's performances, which are excellent indeed.
It suffers, too, from what plagues the big, brawny action engines: The mechanics of the generic thrills and spills override the logic of the narrative.
Whatever one thinks about Woody Allen, you'll probably find it in here, except why Americans don't much turn out to see his movies.
Boston has written some excellent characters, and under Antonio Tibaldi's astute direction, the actors are uniformly superlative, right down to the walk-ons.
Turns into the narrowest of unsatisfying melodramas.
Not much of the humor works at all, and there aren't many sparks generated by the putative, last-reel lovers Wheeler-Nicholson and McCaffrey.
Unfortunately--no offense, now--this is mainly a case of the Old Couple, given the mediocre direction of Howard Deutch and, mostly, the surprisingly bland script by Neil Simon.
Even in an 'off' picture like Mr. Nice Guy, it is impossible not to like [Chan]; he's so open and good-natured and takes pride in what he does.
movie_title: Mr. Nice Guy (Yat goh hiu yan) (1997)

movie_review_blurb: With the local premiere of the 3D space movie L5: First City in Space, IMAX has not-so-boldly crossed a new frontier.
The transfer to the IMAX screen diminishes none of the film's drama, which was always much more about human emotions than technology.
This is armchair travel at its most visually spectacular.
movie_title: Kilimanjaro: To The Roof of Africa (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Explores coral reefs around the Pacific Ocean with a dazzling and sometimes irritating variety of computer graphics, brilliant nature photography and jarring sound effects straight out of Finding Nemo.
Both a triumph of photographic technique and a rousing good time.
The polemical nature of the film undermines any possibility of satire, as the posturing grows more ludicrous by the scene.
Despite its size and subject matter, Wild Safari 3D is pretty tame and two-dimensional.
movie_title: Wild Safari: A South African Adventure (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It opens up a little corner of the world that even casual observers had long ago heard about but have rarely seen.
PBS' documentary on the life of Jackie Robinson gets most interesting when the gloves and bats are put away for good.
Documentaries don't get more compelling than The Cove, a film that plays out more like a thriller than environmental advocacy.
If a dramatic action occurs in Lake Tahoe, a new film from Mexican director Fernando Eimbcke, you probably won't see it.
The film succeeds as more than mere propaganda. Unlike the processed products it criticizes, Food, Inc. is ready for consumption.
Moana's animation and soundtrack are masterful, the best that the studio have done in two decades. [Full review in Spanish]
Its originality radicates in its execution: frantic rhythm, a detailed script, brilliant design, and emotional hits strategically placed with a bunch of new characters. [Full review in Spanish]
A film that is antiquated, predictable and inane. Smurf blue has become an outdated color. [Full review in Spanish]
... is very good as a family product. [Full review in Spanish]
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Nut Job was profitable enough to have this sequel that no one has asked for... [Full review in Spanish]
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The worst installment of the worst Pixar franchise. [Full review in Spanish]
It's wolves against sheep in this barely original Russian animation. [Full review in Spanish]
movie_title: Sheep & Wolves (Volki I Ovtsy: Be-ye-ye-zumnoye Prevrashcheniye) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Not content with mere metaphorical forces of nature, Sturla Gunnarsson's latest documentary dives headfirst into one of our most impressive literal ones, the torrential rains that in many ways define Indian culture.
The Intruders would like to be more clever than it is, but it's hamstrung by a script that's a bit of a fixer-upper.
This is a movie that treats everyone like grey specters in a faceless corporation. Not that you would expect much else from a movie that openly admits its premise is boring.
For a film that has pulled a reasonably overqualified cast with solid dramatic chops, it is regretfully short on any characters that stick out in any way whatsoever.
