Where Bianca and Wesley are going is obvious from the outset, but it builds naturally through a pal-ship with a genuine spark.
I fault no one for whatever it is that gets their crank turning, but if this movie is working you need to take that thing out for a spin far more often.
As it is, it's an underdog story that follows the obvious track, though it should get there just fine if you're pulling for it.
Almost deliberately stripped of humour (and, incidentally, vigour), Rosewater is an odd choice for Stewart the satirist, a mushy, carefully sincere story that lets its message smother its delivery.
[Smith] gets at the essential inward journey of most of her subjects, and she makes the concept of walking 800 kilometres seem remarkably appealing.
movie_title: Walking The Camino: Six Ways To Santiago (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It succeeds because it manages to fill every frame with the stuff of life, suffuse every scene with the wonderful horror of being.
It still deserves credit for fore fronting the latter's story, but as with any issue, it's never really just enough to acknowledge that you're looking at it.
Moss and Duplass do a nice, natural job of putting these characters at odds with each other with neither really spoiling for a fight.
Señoritas has its moments, but never really manages to make them more.
Thanks to some of the shoddiest henchmannery this side of Super Mario Brothers, Sly is able to escape and round up the old (figuratively and literally) team, plus a few new recruits.
Say what you will about the rubber-suited '90s films, at least they explored the dynamic a little.
We get a lot of what happened to James Brown without a lot of who he was, or even really why he mattered.
Merchants is full of incredibly telling interactions and visuals to help make its case.
Horrifyingly hypnotic.

If Get Hard isn't quite the biting satire that its premise would imply - though it's more unabashedly eat-the-rich than some critics have given it credit for - it's consistently ridiculous enough to be funny more often than not.
Helped along by a sharp visual style, Bastard is slightly slow and enigmatic, but surefooted enough to keep you intrigued right up to its surprisingly sincere finale.
A documentary that's interesting both as sociological study and as a bit of advice.

The two sides of the documentary more often exist alongside each other, rather than supporting them. Still, especially for people who aren't going to be throwing out chutes any time soon, it's a thrilling ride.
The overarching mood is self-congratulation, which no doubt helps the sugary medicine of lifestyle fantasy go down.

Though it is shaggy and loose, Welcome to Me wants to confront us with how casually and confusingly we tend to treat mental illness, laughing in its face or vaguely romanticizing it or tightly stigmatizing it.
Its overarching point is incisive.
88 is so bafflingly convinced it has a breakneck pace and a rat's maze of twisting plots that it can't make it five minutes without flashing back to something that happened just moments ago.
It dawdles and meanders a little too much in the getting there, but at least once Martha and Stan are in the same house, Big Muddy starts livening up its beat-up setting.
If Danny Collins the film did a little more getting down to earth, and a little less hamhandedly reminding you that that's what it was trying to do, it'd really be something to sing about.
Cohen's not trying to do anything resembling a serious examination of the country, of course, but even wink-nudge examinations of identity could at least use a few new jokes.

For a story that's all about choice and consequence, the way it rips through plot points in the latter half makes the ending feel more like an inevitable contrivance than a maturation. Although, in fairness, the scenery always stays just as beautiful.
Tragically for the film's momentum, there's no sense of drama or tension to the heist.

This is truly a story about the wounds that wars leave even on those who don't fight in them -- and all the lengths to which Crowe will go to convince you that strong men also cry, sir. Strong men also cry.

There's plenty you haven't actually seen in The Dead Lands, a blood-spurting martial arts epic that sets its ultraviolence amongst warring Maori tribes... It's a shame that everything else about it follows such a strict action movie template.
This is one script that no doubt read a lot better than it was ever going to look or sound.
The actual antics feel as tonally dated as the story, school-boyish shtick that went corny even before M*A*S*H married screwball shenanigans to wartime bleakness.

It's not always a perfect movie, but it really knows what it feels like to be alive, and there's a good chance it will push you out the theatre door reverberating with its potent and particular energy.
Much of the satire is drained out, practically and formally, by a turn toward the rom-com.
The very blatant set-up makes the gags feel a bit like vaudeville punchlines, coming from miles away and that much duller for their inevitability.
Gibney does a good job of relating [the] viciousness to Armstrong's powerful will to win - or at least his will to beat people.

Gray is one of the most deliberate of American filmmakers, capable of turning an underground beating by the cops into a scene of two-toned aesthetic beauty, and never letting a frame go by with deep, moody meaning.

Given that we're not even sure of the effects that always being connected have on the world, it feels somewhere between premature and panic-y to make the children the primary cause of our hand-wringing.
Starting from a place of ignorance and never going much further, Seifert omits anything that might hurt his obvious anti-GMO thesis.
This is a film that's trying for a lot of things, and accomplishes exactly none of them.

There's a reason candid camera stuff has been with us since we figured out how to hide cameras, and Knoxville's grinning rambunctiousness is enough to keep it far away from Just for Laughs Gags territory.
There is nothing you wouldn't expect, but at least it's all done with flair.

[The Shadowhunters are] a bunch of half-angelic beings tasked with fighting demons and watching over the "mundanes," which I swear is actually what they call humans, I guess because "boring poo-poo stupidheads" might be a touch on the nose.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: At times maudlin and at other times just smug, dabbed with just enough humour to keep from being insufferable, it's like a victory lap that serves to dull and distress the hard-earned footsteps that came before it.
This is a national history that feels like your great uncle trying to remember the time he went to Disneyland's Hall of Presidents.
Jobs is nothing but a collection of moments, with no particular aim, no attempt to really explain the man, even reductively.

It's a shame the story couldn't carry some of the heft of the hulking battlebots, but then I guess when the giant Gundam starts battling Godzilla, no one's curious about how they feel. You just stare, mouth agape, at the impressive display in front of you.

It would like to be high concept, maybe even darkly philosophical, but it mistakes recognizing questions with trying to understand them, and then it clubs you in the face with that recognition with twice the zeal of any of its purging characters.
Like an addled six-year-old, though, what the sixth film in the franchise has going for it is a playful imagination not even aware, much less bound, by anything resembling reality.
The arch and resolution are some indication of how utterly lifeless Peeples is, both in the sense of lacking vitality and having no real connection to how people think, feel and react to situations.
My Awkward Sexual Adventure is a genial and funny, if slightly conventional, date.
There are myriad problems with Bert Stern: Original Mad Man -- not the least of which is a title that shamelessly and needlessly gropes for relevance by attempting to cozy up with Don Draper and co.

There isn't a character here... who doesn't feel like a low-res scan of a shaky photocopy of a faded polaroid of a character in a better crime drama, none of which is helped by a plot that's too simple to generate tension even from its narrative tricks.
It's less a movie than a 92-minute bet that children will be amused by/willing to purchase anything with googly eyes slapped on it.
In short, then, there are no major missteps, although it's missing some of the life that animated its subject (though only a touch of the length).
A buddy cop-ish movie that would need a healthy dose of inspiration to even count as boring.
If you don't know anything about the case, Devil's Knot is too shallow to do it much justice; if you do know about the case, Devil's Knot is too aimless to offer any new perspective.

More than anything Tom at the Farm is a rippling pool of grief, a dark parable about what it means to accept loss and move on, with the main group of three passing through states of denial, self-abnegation and aggressively bitter confrontation.
Amongst the flying robots and the claws coming out and the ceaseless wisecracks, there isn't really much of a human story to grab on to.
This may be the exceedingly rare American remake of a movie that is at its best when it isn't trying to engage with the original's legacy.

The extreme contrivance of the scenario extends to a lot of Locke's lines to the people he's on the phone with. It may never leave the car, but it wants to stuff that car full of as much meaning and drama as it can.
It lacks some of the left-field comic surprise of last year's This Is The End, but if you're the kind of person who's happy to watch Rogen do his thing, he fits into fatherhood surprisingly well.
If your way of dealing with grief is basically to decide that anything you do is fine as long it gets you back on your feet, you are essentially a sociopath.

Given how established their roles are, Don't Legalize It could really use some sort of narrative pull, but it is mostly just content to stand in the middle and watch everyone circle in their fitfully funny ruts.
movie_title: Trailer Park Boys: Don't Legalize It (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The other flavours in A Haunted House 2's neapolitan ice cream are people getting hurt and sex jokes.
It has a mawkish streak a quarter of the film wide.
Few of us get to change the world, but fewer still have the vision and ambition of Jodorowsky, and it's a heady thrill just to be in his orbit for a little while.
If [Butt] could make the serious bits feel bigger, as opposed to just windrow dressing to his jokes, he'd have a parody worth really taking seriously.
For a film aimed squarely at dyed-in-the-lamb believers, it sure treats the audience like first-timers.
This is the stuff of pure nonsensical romance, almost nothing resembling what we might understand adolescence or love to be.
The movie is built like a child's game (on a few levels), the sheer chaos of pieces spread out across the screen and assembled with a furious kind of fun.
As is it is a pleasant enough little diversion where the life lessons come on far too strong.
Labor Day is too often stifling rather than steamy, and a lot of that, curiously, has to do with the way people talk.
It's pretty much just trekking through the territory that got written up in all those game day reviews.

It's not like every biography needs to be a takedown, but in this case it misses something significantly deeper. Part of why Gordon is so interesting is because he's a bit of a good guy gone bad, or at least living in a dark world.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a simpler experience, but then doesn't everyone (or everywoman) need a little mindless worship now and again?
[It] does a fine job of laying out how much more complicated this issue is in the digital age, when even what corporations do is as ephemeral as the way they treat their money

This survey of second-wave feminism has considerably more verve than your standard talking-heads doc, thanks mostly to its engaging front-line fighters, most of whom are still animated with the fire of smashing the patriarchy.

As the title would imply, this gang of people predate the actual country they live in, and even just through relating their life manage to speak to the rather profound changes that have hit in that time.
[A] feckless fantasy.
When things get absurd, which is never far around the corner, it is downright grating.

A documentary with no easy antecedents, The Russian Woodpecker is at once a glance inside a wondrous mind, a journey back into the twisted mire of the Cold War and an experience that can't stop provoking questions.
[The Club] works through not just guilt and our impressive ability to bury it, but the very precarious path of anyone walking a moral high ground.
It finds real grief tucked next to bitingly dark humour, splattering the muddled desires of the living right next to the requests of the dead.
Most of the moments of either comedy or romance feel a bit too manufactured to really land, although certainly if you're a fan of these things, being manufactured has never been much of an issue.

The quartet makes unbelievably dumb decision after unbelievably dumb decision, and get a few assists from some very conveniently tension-filled happenstance, before everything really goes to frozen-over hell.

Watching Deadpool feels a bit like downing a shot of something stiff, while simultaneously having the same again thrown in your face. It's bracing, and if you're not ready for it, it can rock you back on your heels.

It isn't backwards or hateful so much as inexplicable: these 2016 dudes (playing early 20s but looking early 30s) act like their only exposure to gay life is someone else telling them about a Will & Grace episode.
At a certain point in Mojave, a shady film producer played by Mark Wahlberg makes a looping, passionate and not entirely persuasive case for making a movie about a rich person's problems.

If you can stomach a metaphorical climax where a parade of hippies create a colourful phoenix with the power of music, but it loses a battle with an evil raven created by the military's black procession, you will probably be downright touched.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Buddy comedies usually need two people willing to do something for a laugh to really work - one guy trying twice as hard really isn't enough.
As Perfect as Black is for Po, Kung Fu Panda 3 is a pretty good indication that everything runs its course. Time to let the bear live on as another actor's impression on Saturday morning TV.
Pointedly and joylessly explaining everything turns out to be this movie's favourite thing, I guess because aliens tend to struggle with our human emotions.
Honestly, if this wasn't a remake, it's a fair bet you might not have any idea of what exactly was supposed to be going on.
No movie about such a wild and trailblazing figure has any right to be this wilfully prosaic.
Everything here is roughly that plodding, managing to make what actually should be a life-and-death issue into something with all the nuance and depth of a Law and Order courtroom capper.
As the man says, Barney Thomson is nasty, brutish and short, but not quite funny enough to always get away with it.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The danger of being a wanted man is only compounded by his inability to speak the language, and his sticking out like a sore thumb, making him increasingly desperate as he tries to reach the embassy and get back home.
Beatriz at Dinner works well beyond both lecture or lesson because of the care and attention everyone has put into the people that play them out.
Terse and devastating.
Before I Fall would do better to understand its corrupted little angels before it tries to teach them something.
This is ultimately a movie about the very bad things that can happen when we don't address our unease, when we just try to brush it off, whether that's to fit in or to preserve our self-image.
There is a world of charm and wisdom in the film, much as there is in the man himself.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You've got to be pretty savvy to come across as completely clueless.
It all adds up to something rare and gorgeous, a slice of life that appreciates the amount of wear and tear life can inflict.
The Chet Baker of Born to Be Blue would say he's just trying to live a little. Budreau and Hawke are smart enough to find someone who was running from life as much as trying to live it.
It's all a little too pat, though, reducing Davis rather than expanding on him, simplifying him to a driving impulse.
The thing that consistently holds this latter kind of movie back is McCarthy's inability, or unwillingness, to give anyone else anything interesting to do.
I Saw The Light meanders aimlessly from then on, not even really grasping at things to say about Williams so much as ignorant of the fact it might need to.
Some subcultures stay buried for a reason, although it can be fun to trace their ruins.
Maybe I could say that if Christopher Guest rounded up his usual troupe and did a verbatim, shot-for-shot remake, it would be one of the funniest films of the year.

The effect of this thriller... is ultimately one of a particularly tense (and well-acted) roundtable: a lot of very good ideas about what to think, but rarely does it ever succeed at hitting below the neck.
Credit where it's due: The Bronze does not waste any time diving into how aggressively unpleasant former Olympic bronze medalist Hope Ann Gregory (Melissa Rauch) really is.
It kind of reduces all those questions of faith to a self-help book.
Combined with some stiff performances (even for fake talking heads), it's hard not to feel like No Men Beyond This Point is just one long "men are from Mars, women be shopping" joke.

There are, I guess, some decently staged fight scenes, including clever use of some pool balls, but they in no way make up for having to sit there and watch Lutz garble out warmed-over tough guy dialogue.
Reed and Shepherd do a reasonable job of injecting some level of balance into their straightforward retelling.

Carol is the rare film that couldn't just get away with being silent, but could probably also be just as engrossing completely still -- just sitting there, watching Mara and Blanchett watch each other.

There isn't a lot of anything to latch onto in Turbo Kid beyond warm nostalgia, but there's something to be said for gripping hold of even a flimsy premise and squeezing it until it explodes in a flurry of goopy blood.
The result is 90 straight minutes of rising tension, never so much relieved as occasionally back-pedalled to take another mad run at Alex and Jenn and us.
It does still feel a bit odd that we whizz by what must amount to hundreds of people without so much as a subtitle reflecting their thoughts of what's going to be a major change for their lives.

What begins as a sort of fitfully cute small town musical parody mutates into a decidedly more unique cartoon of feeling trapped; the lesson seems to be that, if you're going to go Lynch, its best to follow him all the way into the darkness.
As an action movie Ultra is essentially a gory blur, both frantic and airless.
Fundamentally, Teen Lust is a sex comedy that feels the need to broadcast its sex and comedy at every available opportunity -- a desperation that's a sure-fire way to kill the mood for either.
Sexiness and fading nostalgia have powered far worse things than a bubbly, refreshing late-summer spy comedy.

It's neither really a story of reconciliation nor a particularly gripping thriller, just a chance to join the kill club as they wade through misery and miserable people under the guise of puzzle-solving.

The second feature by Pavan Moondi and Brian Robertson, Diamond Tongues lives in its careful attention to detail, the meticulous but breezy way it captures Edith's meandering life as much as her increasingly destructive disenchantment.
As an introduction to a pivotal moment in how the media frames politics, it's essential stuff: this is the moment when pundit culture was born.
There's little comfort here, no easy way to reconcile anything.
It mostly fails to acutely capture the careful observations and shaggy, handmade structure that makes a movie still feel animated and close to the heart.
Following the mystery injects some welcome momentum into what's otherwise the standard laundry list of end-of-school projects, and Green does have a way with the mildly pathetic drama of geeky youth.

His Macbeth does at times fall into that all-too-common trap of Shakespeare: more concerned with cleverly - or, in this case, gorgeously - playing with well-known themes than actually making us feel them.

The Tribe builds to a revolution in your attention, forcing you to change not just how you watch the film but how you feel its characters, but director Miroslav Slaboshpitsky is sly enough to ease you in.
There's plenty of space for cynicism in this bitter, cold world, but Batkid Begins makes a fine case for an authentically rare mass moment of everyone acting like a decent person.
Little about this script -- stuffed with dudebro jokes, wacky accents and "funny" rapping that would have seemed tired in the days of Sir Mix-a-Lot -- seems thought out beyond the premise.
It's like a soft-pedalled self-help version of Grumpy Old Men: Genial Old Men Face Their Decline With Chipper Goodwill But an Inevitable Sense of the Tragedy of Decay, Plus Bears.

Whatever [Shyamalan's] intent, he has at least succeeded in producing a film that, in its wild hodgepodge of absurd emotion, hammy jokes and jumping creeps, is unlike anything else you're likely to see.
It's all that talk that makes [Loach's] latest, Jimmy's Hall, more than just a particularly dour, Depression-era remake of Footloose.

Though Wolf Totem is notable for being a Chinese-scripted-and-shot film that actually offers some kind of critique of the communists, it nevertheless falls into a fairly well-worn story of an outsider growing to appreciate a culture he's come to change.
You might be better served by taking your own long, slow walk through the scenes your local museum has set for you.
How you start with an epic crime tale and Tom Hardy at his most Hardy and end up with something this tepid might even be a more interesting story than the movie itself.
It's safe to say there's never been many like Peggy Guggenheim.

Honestly it would be nice if on occasion a film like this at least tried harder than making the main character somewhat dissatisfied and assuming that would be enough to get everyone identifying with her.
The Night Before is loose and wild enough that it's easy to forget the backstory and just revel in ridiculousness.
For a story of such monumental scope, which asks some awfully big questions about what constitutes good, writer/director Tom McCarthy seems finely attuned to minor, but infinitely human, moments.
There is just so much lived-in luxury and poorly borrowed Euro art-film grandeur and repressed nothing that you half expect some French narrator to intone "Dépression. By Clinique."
When Our Brand actually pops its head into the real nuts and bolts of shaping a candidate, it feints toward something resembling satire without ever quite biting.
McAvoy might be able to make himself froth at the mouth while screaming "It's alive!" but no one concerned ever manages to make the movie feel like the same thing can be said of it.

I say from some experience that there's a lot to recommend in a good ol' game of Dungeons and Dragons, especially if you have a little imagination. There's absolutely no reason to sit down and watch someone else do it, though.
Sleeping With Other People has plenty of bad habits, but at its core is a refreshing and sometimes downright sad look at what love can do to people, dressed up with the sweet hope of new love.
Klein and husband/director Avi Lewis can't make a rhetorically strong enough case for the central idea... so they fire up the waterworks and hope you'll feel bad enough to let them have their way.
Unfortunately, all of this has to work against writing that is chokingly self-conscious, starting with the well-worn set-up and extending to dialogue that always sounds like screenwriter-y tics.

movie_review_blurb: Shults has crafted a very admirable and challenging piece of cinema. But it's also one that enthralls while never truly ensnaring the audience or their fears.

While it never quite enters the realm of horror, Coppola knowingly conjures something supernatural about what drives these women in the shaded margins of America's bloodiest war.
Matt Reeves' film makes no bones about being anything less than its aspirations: a patient, deliberate, and occasionally devastating drama about an ape of mythic quality.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is very effective at creating adoration for a pig made of ones and zeroes. There might be a few tears in there too.
Most impressive is that it's a blast to watch, harkening back to the sugar rush that accompanied flipping through Stan Lee and Steve Ditko's earliest comic adventures .
As a purely psychedelic space opera, Valerian is indeed hard to beat for genre fans desiring a new take on the future. Like the Devil, Valerian's quality is in the details.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Nolan challenges everything you might expect from the subject matter: be it in terms of narrative, plot structure, or even the basic notions placed on war films in general, and World War II movies in the main.
Thomas laments to his old school neighbor that maybe this boy's young life isn't that interesting. Bridges convinces him otherwise, but we think Thomas got it right the first time.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even though a young girl's soul might lie in the balance between Heaven and eternal damnation, the conflict seems as moot as taking a piece of rubbish to the nearest trash can.
Adam Wingard's adaptation of the Death Note manga is a narrative clutter, every bit as impenetrable as a stack of Japanese comics scattered across a teenager's bedroom floor.
With so much madness stuffed into its sizable 141-minute running time, Kingsman: The Golden Circle is a little manic itself.

With no desire to explore the political dynamics, the film is prevented from achieving anything more than a slight comedy of manners. But how mannered they look in those impeccable costumes and with the occasional self-effacing wink.
Despite almost never getting out of bed, Netflix's Gerald's Game might be the most haunting Stephen King adaptation of the year.
Ben Wheatley's Free Fire is so persuasively arrogant that it convinces you style can bury substance in a hole six feet deep.
Through it all, Maguire remains the ideal actor to play the conflicted superhero. Earnest and vulnerable, you see why he delights in the transformation to superhero. And why he also feels its burden.
[A] tiresome burlesque of spoofs that is too coyly absurd for its own good.
The radiance of My Brother The Devil should also work as an audition tape for Letitia Wright.
Leslye Headland's directorial debut, adapting her own stage play, runs on nastiness with a dose of romance. It doesn't reinvent anything, but it keeps the bile flowing.
In a deft interplay of dogged investigation and randomness, Bendjelloul shows how facts surface to dispel a persistent myth that Rodriguez shot himself on stage.
If the film intends to show that any of the Siegels have gained any wisdom from hardship, we don't see it.
It's an auspicious beginning for a young director. Watch for the fireworks once Circumstance reaches Iran.
In HERE, the landscape doesn't become a character, as the boilerplate cliché would have it, but the brief-encounter romance becomes a proto-documentary.
Watching the lazy surreal odyssey unfold, you might be tempted to see The Catechism Cataclysm as a metaphor about telling a story, or about the futility of telling a story.
Lord Byron is best seen as an experiment in telling the simplest of stories with the simplest of means.
The epic film is a breakthrough in transforming a painting into a moving picture, but sadly the drama doesn't rise to the level of its novelty and ambition.
In Calvin Lee Reeder's unsentimental feature, nature is a place where you get lost, and where there's a threat around every corner.
The key product on the screen here is Morgan Spurlock, with plenty of style and attitude.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a heist-and-hostage comedy that reminds you that criminals, under pressure, are as neurotic as anyone else.
Chandor's script fuels intensity by packing the drama into a tight window.
Gavin Wiesen is cooking with a recipe in his screenplay, and it's a bland reheated one.
Paul Rudd makes this ordinary comedy something special.
Ingenious [and] warmhearted.
[The filmmakers] infuse originality into the one-against-all tale by thinking outside the horror toolbox.
Despite its cast, I Melt With You, with all its explosive tactility, doesn't offer much that you won't get from watching anything by Danny Boyle, who seems one of its stylistic roadmaps.
Tully is comfortable enough with his own material that he doesn't overplay gags. His parodies are odd enough to have a comic freshness, even in the well-traveled field of gothic mockery.
Juno Temple is particularly appealing as a 15 year old who's fragile, but bored enough to do almost anything bad.
Weak production values don't matter in this fascinating look at the making of an art charlatan. Unwittingly, it seems, Banksy met and filmed his match.
Culkin and Roberts hit the right balance of savviness and clumsiness as teenagers who are smart enough to see what their parents try to conceal.
A vivid period piece, The Runaways is anything but an extended music video.
Chef is harmless fun with a likeable cast, and enough suggestibility in the food on the screen to boost sales at the concessions stand.
Lisecki directs deftly and lightly, and spreads the jokes around his strong cast.
Sara Colangelo's sombre drama is a promising first feature.
God Help The Girl has a soft whimsy that connects to a time before video clips put editing rhythms into overdrive.
Bar Lev's scenes of crowd melees are frightening, but his film contains intimate poignant testimony that is equally troubling.
Caustically wry and cloyingly sentimental, The Skeleton Twins is a crowdpleaser.
The story is off the rack, but the plotters' suits are well-tailored.

Rather than surrender his story to the crime or the courtroom, Krokidas scrutinises the ensemble of friends that galvanised the young men into literary vocations and kept the brooding Kammerer at a distance.
The look of this Mitty turns panoramic, but it's generic compared to the 1947 Technicolor version, in which colour and Kaye bounce out from the screen in a then-novel product.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: On a budget that could barely get you on the subway, Madeleine Olnek gets laughs and style out of interplanetary love.
movie_title: Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon," the directorial debut of Mike Myers, is a vaudeville celebrity remembrance of mega-manager Shep Gordon by stars who might have starved without Gordon's help.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Kristen Wiig is a revelation as a timid love-deprived victim who turns a tawdry prank into an opportunity.

With a sympathetic and not too heavy hand, Fruitvale Station takes its audience through the constant challenges to black family life - poverty, debt, crime, and the prospect that an encounter with the police can have deadly consequences.
If its dialogue is tepid, its physical comedy is lively, sometimes with real imagination in its colour palette and the odd animals that populate its 3-D landscapes.
Bio-pics always tailor memories. Yet the welcome surprise here is Kutcher, as the barefoot rebel who brought the spirit of psychedelia to technology.
The tone in Sweetwater is as heavy as that firepower, and the film can feel like stiff medicine.
A costumed pageant and the wild spoof of a costumed pageant, Austenland is a clever romp for Jane Austen fans and for those who see Jane Austen mania as an infinitely expanding punchline.

The promise of adventure and fun in an exotic land seemed like a good idea, but the result was an uncomfortable jolt.
With lesser voices, Manhunt might have lagged, but personalities and skillful intercutting of archival images fuel its momentum.
In this retreat from Park's earlier wildness (Old Boy), there is a sureness to his directing here, most of the time, as he modulates the volatile family tensions which risk exploding in the house.
This lively documentary breaks no new ground cinematically, yet its mix of discovery and befuddlement should bring more than sports fans to a basketball story.
As a 74-minute snapshot of an American at the low end of the struggling 99%, it speaks far more eloquently than poverty statistics.
Any Day Now spices a sentimental family drama into a comedy with the cynical stiletto wit of a drag queen played by Alan Cumming.
Natali's experiment works.
Even with some fine acting, this film can be a long tiring ride.
Welcome To The Rileys has its heart in the right place, but the drama falters as it tends towards the solemnly earnest.

This film packed with political cliches is unlikely to make a difference to American political culture or its distributor's bottom line, despite a dependable cast of stars including Kevin Costner, Kelsey Grammer, and Dennis Hopper.
[Director Chico] Texeira's ordinary characters have a quiet genuineness and clarity that is rare anywhere in movies these days.
The only thing that differentiates this 'movie' from an infomercial is its unbearable feature length. If you have to sit through it, bring plenty to drink.
Blackburn has assembled a solid cast that pivots from folly into fear with a frightful believability.
Boaz Yakin's dark drama is about the legacy of pain.

[This] story of retreat and redemption, while deeply personal, may mean more to Pellington than to the audience. The miraculous elements in Albert Torres's script that offer hope also strain credulity.

After sitting down with lots of friendly people everywhere he goes, and a few nasty extremists, Spurlock is optimistic. He finds friendship and some real laughs, but the mastermind of the 9/11 attacks eludes him.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Make no mistake: Smiley Face, true to its title, is a silly movie, but not one that's stuck in hammy predictability.

Since Sweeney Todd premiered in 1979, screen serial killers have multiplied like so many disposable razors. Making the audience feel something more than the thrill of watching movie stars is the challenge here, and Sweeney Todd somehow cuts itself short.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There Will Be Blood is a vivid, sprawling parable about greed and moral corrosion.

The dazzling images speak eloquently for themselves, even without the director's witty deadpan voice-over.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't break enough rules of the mid-1990's Sundance coming-of-age buddy template to bring any new insights to the bonds of male friendship.
Clever and far more than competent.
As an adaptation of an adaptation, Hairspray beats the odds against turning a musical based on a film into a credible movie.
I haven't seen any recent film about American teenagers in crisis with this kind of economy.
If anything saves this movie, it's the acting.
Yang ties a dozen strands together elegantly with a mostly amateur cast.
Stick with the film, accept the rules of the time and the meditative rhythm of the language that Davies has woven into his story, and you won't be disappointed.
A string of cliches, clearly intended for a season that sells those cliches.
Brawls and bravado aside, Pollock has the stiffness of an official biography.
This version of Bangkok Dangerous is a respectable genre movie, but not much more.
Sentimental but remarkably compelling, the saga of a little man's victory over a corporate giant will ensure that you'll never see your windshield wipers the same way.

Daring and potentially offensive, this hilarious satire may be too biting for its own good.
Audiences up to their ears in serial killers may enter this film, thinking they already know them all. Winterbottom will prove them wrong.
The documentary, edited down from some 400 hours, is packed with crowd-pleasing moments.

Austere and grimly realistic.
Characters become real enough to draw you in, yet are not deeply drawn enough to make you care.

Neither terrifying nor inspiring.
The real test of endurance is on the shoulders of an audience challenged to sit through more than two hours of predictable plot turns and recycled sentimentality.
Morris's distillation of long talks with young ex-soldiers and the female general who commanded prisons all over Iraq is among the best documentaries on the Iraq war.

A wildly funny parody of low-budget horror cinema.
A tender evocation of youth that turns ponderous as it crawls towards a company's revenge on one of its executives.
If crossbows, strange creatures, and a squeaky-clean young cast are the right elements for a fantasy sequel, then this naive epic is your movie.

This one has nothing extraordinary about it to compensate for seven years' staleness.
Trust Me is a title that trumpets its own falsehood, and a story true to its subject in scenes that mix grimaces with laughs.

This chilling documentary revisits the fate of the poet Federico Garcia Lorca, executed in 1936, and of others who are known only to their families.

movie_review_blurb: Philippe's tribute to Hollywood's most famous stabbing is an archival feast.

Revelatory and troubling.

Theron will put to rest any doubts about her feel for comedy; the darker the better.

[Director Assayas] may have something serious to say about the brutal impersonality of global capitalism, yet he's caught somewhere between insight and exploitation.

Although it falls off precipitously, it's better to have Julie Taymor's The Tempest than not: The first half-hour is nearly as unfettered as Shakespeare's language.
With a million times more computing power at its disposal than its 1982 predecessor, Tron: Legacy still looks like Disco Night at the jai alai fronton.
The sad part is that How Do You Know is nowhere near as dumb as it looks. A couple of comic set pieces are inspired -- or would be, if Brooks's timing weren't off.
The Kidman in Rabbit Hole is a revelation.
Blue Valentine leaves you with the shattering vision of its truest victim -- the one who'll someday look for safety in places it might not be. And the psychodrama will go on and on ...
Another year, another Mike Leigh gem...
Coppola's poor-rich-girl vision is certainly consistent, although you sometimes wonder if she knows that hers is not the universal human condition.
The Green Hornet doesn't seem worth the outrageous 3-D-glasses surcharge. In all senses, there's little that jumps out at you.

Perhaps the late Blake Edwards could have found a balance between slapstick and psychodrama, but Ron Howard can't get the pacing right, and Allan Loeb's script is even wordier than the one he wrote for Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps.

No Strings Attached is so palpably calculated that you know if the camera had pulled back a foot from the bed in which Portman and Kutcher were pretending to have sex, you'd have seen their agents standing by beaming: proud parents, proud pimps.
Kaboom might be borderline camp, but there's no spillover. Or perhaps it's the other way around. Perhaps Araki's vision of human sexuality is so fluid that the borders are always expanding.
It comes together neatly, perhaps too neatly to be ... poetry. But it's not prosaic, either. It has a lucid grace.
It helps that Reilly is the opposite of a slob-comic. With his hangdog melancholy, he makes even the nonstop cunnilingus allusions poignant -- the product of emotional longing.
The movie is cunningly woven to show the tension between his insane success and his determination to remain a sane, normal 16-year-old.

I find him such a bland, pious, profoundly unthreatening little Furby of a pop idol, but little girls' celebrity crushes are not to be trifled with. And this sensationally engineered promo film makes Justin Bieber look like a true force of nature.

Wild-eyed, long-haired Brits leap atop the Romans' shields as the soldiers blindly hack away, the bodies so close that you can barely tell the victor from the vanquished. The battles in the fog and rain have a hallucinatory power.
The doughy Damon and aristocratic Blunt don't match up physically, and they never get any Hepburn-Tracy rhythms going that might create some current.
A gross-out comedy about the perpetual immaturity of the American male that has, amazingly enough, a mature perspective.
It's a prizewinning combination, terribly English and totally Hollywood, and Firth is, once more, uncanny: He evokes, in mid-stammer, existential dread.
Uncle Boonmee is entrancing-and also, if you're not sufficiently steeped in its rhythms, narcotizing.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Made in Dagenham is perfectly shameless but shamelessly perfect.
Morning Glory isn't terrible. It has a lot of craft, a lot of star power, and a fair number of laughs. What irks me is that the filmmakers settle for so little.
It becomes a meditation on the dual nature of film, on a "reality" at once true and false, essential and tainted.
It takes you back to an era of arty, angst-ridden European existential pulp movies that were like abstract essays on the genre.
The movie is ham-handed, repetitive, and rhythm-less -- a mess that's uglier than its hero and nowhere near as likable.
There's a thrilling madness to Phoenix's Method.
A haunting duet for two great actors who haven't lost a step and have gained the most exquisite lyricism.
Everyone in The Town shines, even Blake Lively, but it's Chris Cooper as MacRay's imprisoned dad who astounds.

Although Catfish is opportunistic, even borderline exploitive, it gets at -- by indirection, through the back door -- the magic-carpet aspect of this scary new medium. Real people are so complicated and irreducible, you know?

The movie belongs to Stone, that gorgeous, husky-voiced redhead. When most actors deliver nonstop patter, their mouths get ahead of their minds, but Stone's brain works so fast that her mouth can barely keep up.
As with many recent Stone projects, it's hard to tell what the focus is supposed to be.
This is one of the most galvanizing documentaries I've ever seen.
In his mid-70s and working mostly abroad, Allen has settled into a new groove. But it's not a deep or enlivening one. His despair has finally become weightless -- a reflexive shrug.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's lustrous, deep-focus frames and headlong pace are difficult to resist. Its an entertainingly cynical small movie.
The poetic Swedish vampire picture (with arterial spray) Let the Right One In has been hauntingly well transplanted to the high desert of Los Alamos, New Mexico, and renamed Let Me In.
You say Inside Job is a bit like a classroom documentary? Its a class you need to take.
Hereafter occupies some muzzy twilight zone, too woo-woo sentimental to be real, too limp to make for even a halfway decent ghost story.
Shot by shot, scene by scene, it's a fluid and enthralling piece of work. I wasn't bored for a millisecond.
Swank is overeager and humorless, and I got tired of looking at her big choppers, but for all that I liked her.

Larsson is renowned for his attention to marginal details, which gives his prose a rambling, one-thing-after-another pace that many readers find soothing. Onscreen, the lack of acceleration makes for one of those long Scandinavian winter nights.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ken Hixon's script contrives a lot of mutual-healing set pieces and then sadly but shrewdly aborts them...
As in his pithy, tuneful songs -- many written from different perspectives, in different styles -- Merritt is committed to stylizing his misery instead of boring you with it.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Exposed, abandoned, branded as traitors, the Wilsons finally have no choice but to tell their story, the latest chapter of which is this potent Hollywood melodrama starring Sean Penn and Naomi Watts.
It's probably easier for an ex-prosecutor known for macho threats to say he got caught screwing than for him to say he got screwed. But folks, he was reamed.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For Colored Girls is so shamelessly terrible it would make a great midnight hoot-fest, if you had the stomach to laugh at Shange or some of the best (and most underused) actresses of their generation...
Hallows's first hour is deadly, all right.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Blessed is the go-for-it movie that can make room for dissonances and weirdness.
Wasikowska's Jane is as watchful as only a damaged soul can be, and, when challenged, frighteningly fast.
The movie has none of the smugness of American Beauty: You could dream of living in a world like this.
Marsh's documentaries are inspired fusions of content and style, and here, the artistry intensifies the pain.
HPATDH 2 works like a charm. A funereal charm, to be sure, but then, there's no time left for larks.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tabloid is candy for voyeurs. We laugh like mad at a nut whose only mistake was being born in the last century, too early to have made real money.
It's a straight hagiography, without nuance or ambiguity or the admission of opposing viewpoints, even those meant to be dismantled.
The movie looks wonderful.
July is working as hard as any artist alive to find new forms to express the dread of formlessness.
The movie has an unexpectedly high proportion of delights to groaners, and it's full of actors you'll want to see...
Cowboys & Aliens is an agreeable time-killer, but I'll bet a couple of clever kids could make a livelier movie with a Woody puppet and a Predator doll.
It's wall-to-wall sci-fi pop-culture bric-a-brac, yet it feels organic. There's something more at stake than the fate of a movie-ish Earth.
You can study it, like a painting, and then realize, with a gasp, that it has got hold of you like a fever.
The Help belongs to Viola Davis.
Norton is an amazing actor, a hot-dog whose delight in transformation is infectious.
There's bad acting all around, but you can't fully blame the performers. The dialogue needed a writer to come in and punch it up - the lines sound like placeholders.
It's 80 minutes of dead air.
The movie is flushed with hope, wonder, heartbreak.
After a gripping first half, turns into one howler after another. And yet it's still gripping.
It's too corny to live. But the picture is a slam dunk. I mean a ground-and-pound double-leg takedown. It's really gripping.
Contagion is compelling.
Why would Gosling, a fascinatingly cerebral actor, take a role so far inside his comfort zone? Does he long to strike action-icon poses -- to be the new Nic Cage?
Parker reminds you what a dizzy, all-in, high-risk comic actress she can be when she's not too busy showing off the couture.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The movie doesn't quite come together, but it's full of smart, cynical talk, and it's very entertaining.
I hate to damage so fragile a work with overpraise, but, gay or straight, if you don't see yourself in this movie, you need to get a life.
Katie Galloway and Kelly Duane's nonfiction account is eerily suggestive -- and alarming.
The film is sometimes gentle to the point of blandness, but it's never flimsy.
It's well and good to hear Buck and others tell his story, but the film wouldn't come to much if you didn't feel the connection between his present and past in every frame.
Apart from having no particular reason to exist onscreen, especially at these prices, it's not half bad.

It would be easy to dismiss as 100 percent ersatz if it didn't rekindle at least some of the old excitement -- and if the magic of Spielberg's older movies didn't filter through, like light from a distant galaxy.
The CGI alien is very well articulated, and Rogen is a virtuoso at mixing motormouthed rudeness with a hint of tenderness to take off the edge.
Bier dramatizes our ambivalence so earnestly that it's tempting to give her awards rather than admit that the movie is a crushing bore.
It's a crackerjack ride, shot and edited for maximum discombobulation.
The thing is scary as hell when it's all creaks and thumps and doors swinging open. Then come the explanations, the special effects, and the inevitable feeling of been-there-been-bombarded-by-that.
American Psycho is nearly perfect for what it is, but before we go on, we should ask what that actually amounts to. Can something with so rigid a thesis be a real work of art?
A cunning weave of low and high, regal and smutty, splendiferous and splattery.

What keeps us hooked is Ronan, a young actress of seemingly limitless abilities, and the tension she creates between Hanna's inhumanly agile body and quizzical eyes, which turn cold only when she pulls the trigger.
Redford does a fine, economical job re-creating the horror of the assassination, the dying president barely glimpsed but the bowls of blood carried from his deathbed all too vivid.
Russell Brand gives a career-killing performance.
Reichardt's westward-ho is a world of confusion, geographical and moral, a dislocation beyond the remedy of water or Bibles.
The movie doesn't quite jell, but you'll feel its sting for hours.
Try not to hoot when the gaunt Roberts makes a bring-on-the-flab speech to persuade the equally slender Tuva Novotny to eat pizza, even if they get "muffin tops."
It's surprising that The Greatest Movie Ever Sold plays so entertainingly, given that Spurlock's quest is essentially beside the point.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cave of Forgotten Dreams is sometimes frozen by Herzog's awe. But it's hard not to love him for always trying to look beyond the surface of things, to find a common chord in the landscape of dreams.

The movie's glumness is in synch with Foster's performances over the last decade: It's as if she's decided that acting is something you mature beyond. Which I suspect had a dampening effect on Gibson's performance.
There's something appealing about the movie's unpretentious carnival of carnage, although I could have done without the flamethrower assault on a school bus to raise the stakes.
There's too much lustrous-hued loitering and too few martial-arts set pieces. This isn't another disposable B movie, though.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Has a mixture of bloodletting and exultation that would make Sam Peckinpah sit up in his grave and howl with pleasure.
That lawn with its scraps of a ruined life is a setting both satirical and poignant, and Will Ferrell gives a performance of Chekhovian depth.
A giant notch up is Hiddleston, who'd make a good Edmund in King Lear: You register the chip on his shoulder rather than the villainy.

This supernatural comedy isn't just Allen's best film in more than a decade; it's the only one that manages to rise above its tidy parable structure and be easy, graceful, and glancingly funny, as if buoyed by its befuddled hero's enchantment.
I've never seen a film in which what was actually onscreen seemed so irrelevant.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Will you find it ridiculously sublime or sublimely ridiculous? Don't be afraid to find it both.
Arthur might have stolen this one were it not for a cast that inspires you to empty out your bag of superlatives.
Amusing and annoying in the wrong ratio, maybe 30/70.

Michôd serves up Trainspotting-like tricks and narration that is beguiling, if rarely apropos. But the actors are something.
The film is repetitive, top-heavy: Wright blows his wad too early. But a different lead might have kept you laughing and engaged.

Instead of being bombarded by computer illusions, we're allowed to suspend our disbelief, to bring our own imaginations into play. For all the artfulness, the feel of the film is rough-hewn, almost primitive. It's a fabulous tree house of a movie.
In the light of day, it's all very silly and conventional. But of course we're not talking about the light of day.
It's a testament to Saavedra's tough performance that even with a happy ending, you wouldn't want to leave her with your kids.

Von Trier has said he wanted to make a genre horror picture, but he couldn't even come up with a decent metaphor: The climax is out of a Grade C hack-'em-up with people chasing each other through the woods with axes and knives.
The best part is Jemaine Clement as Benjamin's grandiose genre hero, Dr. Ronald Chevalier. Even if you love him on Flight of the Conchords, you'll be unprepared for his genius -- and charisma.
It's all so glancing and superficial that the movie doesn't seem to have a present tense. It goes by like coming attractions. It is, however, a treasury of bad biopic dialogue.
Daniels does everything to hold the melodrama at bay, but there's only so much he can do.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A portrait of one of the world's great companies by one of the world's great vérité documentarians.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The additions are okay; but it's the look that keeps you buoyed up, your eyes roaming the frames, laughing in surprise at the visual jokes and flourishes and textures. It's a dandy's movie, but that adds to the fun.

Any war picture in which the heroine stalls the villain with a quiet, painstaking tea ceremony until the wind shifts direction and the good guys can firebomb the bad guys into oblivion is too ineffably Zen not to love.
Evocative as it is, The Road comes up short, not because it's bleak but because it's monotonous, and because McCarthy's vision is finally as inflexible as his patriarchal hero's.
I'm not sure how Morton made sense of her character's ebbs and flows, but I never doubted her. She's a mariner in uncharted seas of emotion.
If there's a sure thing in movies, it's that if you cast Nicolas Cage in a role in which he goes crazy, he'll rise to the occasion and keep on rising until he seems even loonier than his character.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pedro Almodóvar's Broken Embraces is a lush, deeply romantic noir dense with nods to films past, yet it plays as if it sprung fully formed from the director's unconscious.
Too many films exploit the perils faced by children when the social contract is ruptured, but Mammoth earns its cruel, sensationalistic turns and then some.
Weitz's pacing is so limp you're going to need the electricity generated by a live audience to keep from yelling, "Hurry it up!"

Sheridan pulls you so deep into Brothers so fast that there isn't time for the alarm bell to go off that says: "Warning! Another Traumatized-Vet Movie!" You never catch Sheridan or Benioff grandstanding, only observing.
Clooney -- slim, dark, perfectly tailored -- glamorizes insincerity in a way that makes you want to go out and lie.
The narrative would be ho-hum without the spectacle. But what spectacle! Avatar is dizzying, enveloping, vertiginous ... I ran out of adjectives an hour into its 161 minutes.
By now we've seen so many good, bad, and indifferent Sherlocks that it's almost a relief to get something different, however wrongheaded. And there's no such thing as too much Downey.
Haneke doesn't deign to deliver the genre goods-resolution, catharsis, etc. That way he can crudely spell out his themes and yet still give the bourgeois audience the finger.
The final scenes have a transcendent mixture of hope and sadness. I've never seen anything like Mia's final dance, or the leave-taking with her little sister that follows.

I love this new breed of dirty movie. It goes beyond leering, beyond sexism, to the core tension of a culture that ricochets between Puritanism and promiscuity. And it has in Michael Cera a sterling mascot.
Quite enjoyable, even for those of us who don't follow British "football."
This movie is glorious testimony to the moral power of satire.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Lone Scherfig's direction is glum. We're so clued in to what's really going on that we never share Jenny's authentic excitement at being introduced to art, music, and exotic locales.
Barrymore hovers over her actresses like the nicest, most nurturing den mother imaginable, and on its own, Go For It formula terms the movie delivers.
I found it interminable.
The end of The Cove is as rousing as anything from Hollywood. Manipulative? Sure -- but isn't that fitting?
[A] superb documentary.
When Miyazaki makes films that decry the threat to the natural world, every molecule onscreen resonates with that belief -- a belief that dissolves the boundaries between form and content.
When actors like these are cooking, it's better than haute cuisine.
The movie is an ungainly pastiche, yet on some wacked-out Jungian level it's all of a piece.
To call this the best shrimp-from-outer-space South African apartheid allegory ever made does not begin to do it justice. But it's a start.
The lead actress, María Onetto, holds you through the longueurs.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I'm over the moon about this movie, which smooths out the psychological dissonances in Audrey Niffenegger's fine novel but is still an emotional workout.
The cutting is hyperkinetic, yet Lee is always in synch with the cast's phenomenal energy. He's in their thrall -- and so are we.
Lee and his producer and screenwriter, James Schamus, have turned Tiber's book into a gentle, rather tepid film. Its first half is modest and likable, but it goes on for over two hours.
The movie is unfailingly likable and finally impressive. Goldin doesn't settle for easy answers, and he makes you think that no one should.

Zombie isn't a storyteller, he's a wallower. And because his movies take place in a culture of violence and sadism, there's nothing for Michael Myers to do except echo what's already there and slaughter weaker sadists.
No Impact Man -- the film and the book -- could well end up instruction manuals.
Berlinger doesn't counter Chevron's counter charges with facts and figures. With footage of petrochemical-sludge swamps and babies covered with flaming sores, he doesn't especially need to.

You'll never hear an economist explain derivatives again without thinking of the woman who walks away from the camera, weeping, as her mortgage broker refuses her check, or children's dolls splayed out on the floors of empty homes.
What keeps all this from seeming overmelodramatic is Schneider's huge performance, which is too hilarious. All costume dramas need actors this rude.
The Informant! does raise a fascinating question: How can humans so compartmentalize their psyches? But Whitacre has no stature -- he's just a nut.

So many people risked their livelihoods to put the 7,000-page Pentagon Papers out there -- although its most tangible result was the creation of Nixon's plumbers unit. We have not celebrated Daniel Ellsberg enough. Let's begin.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is something rare, a boisterous American comedy with the power to trigger philosophical disputes -- even, if taken really seriously, fisticuffs. One can hope!

John Krasinski's adaptation of David Foster Wallace's ... Brief Interviews With Hideous Men works only in spurts, but when it does, it's enough to remind us how much deeper our dramatists could drill -- and of the magnitude of Wallace's loss.
As picturesque period biopics with too many symmetrical compositions go, Anne Fontaine's Coco Before Chanel is surprisingly intimate and nuanced.
A Serious Man is not only hauntingly original, it's the final piece of the puzzle that is the Coens.
Moore relates a half-century of fraud in singsong narration that makes him seem like Mister Rogers with 200 extra pounds and a Che Guevara T-shirt instead of a cardigan. But what a figure he cuts.
For all the Saturday-matinee heroics, the movie is dreary and monotonous, the vision junky in more ways than one.
Nichols has a genius for making landscapes and everyday objects resonate like crazy, for nailing the texture of dread.
The movie has its evocative moments, but it's so rigged on the side of anti-intellectualism that you'd never guess that Tolstoy's late work inspired Gandhi and Martin Luther King.
Steve Buscemi cuts so droll and heart-wrenching a figure in Hue Rhodes's deadpan road movie Saint John of Las Vegas that the plot -- shaggy and inconsequential as it is -- gets in the way.
Presents itself as an ethnographic meditation on the first year of life but is better approached as an "oooooh" and "awww" fest...
Casino Jack is audience-friendly without turning into a Michael Moore-ish clown show.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I'm not wholly clear on the link between a jellied green thing wriggling along a tree branch and the oneness of life, but Shinto Buddhist ruminations sound good in almost any context, and the film is entrancing.
It seems that the hunger for celebrity is so fierce that people will exploit anything -- even their most embarrassing moments -- to attain some measure of it.
Robin and Marian are played by a scowling Russell Crowe and a grim Cate Blanchett, who has the face of a wooden squaw stained by decades of cigar smoke. I can't remember a more un-fun-looking couple.
Holy Rollers fuses a somber, old-world palette with a jittery urban unease -- a good mix of tones. It's also wonderfully acted.
It's smoothly written and smartly paced, and Michael Douglas is riveting.
Given all the weighty colloquia, Agora has remarkably few bad laughs, and the CGI re-creations of ancient Alexandria are so detailed I wanted to freeze the frame and linger on the city's layout.
The most depressing thing about Sex and the City 2 is that it seems to justify every nasty thing said and written about the series and first feature film.
Survival of the Dead almost never snaps into focus. Even its oxymoronic title doesn't work. It feels marginal, like an extended footnote.
For all the horror, it's the drive toward life, not the decay, that lingers in the mind. As a modern heroine, Ree Dolly has no peer, and Winter's Bone is the year's most stirring film.
This is a thoroughly exhilarating, thoroughly depressing portrait of the agony and ecstasy of celebrity.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This wistful little film is at just the right temperature.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The gags are all of a piece, right up to the forlorn yet enchanting finale.
Restrepo is, on its own terms, a stunning piece of work, but to get even more from it you should buy Junger's book, WAR, which expands on the footage we see.
The title, like Nicole Holofcener's Please Give, is one that trails you out of the theater and gives you something to brood on.
The journey is thrilling -- even if, on some level, you know that these kids are going in circles.
A remarkably flaccid effort -- much lamer than its predecessor, The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, which was pedestrian and sleazy but hit its marks.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I wanted to surrender to this dream; I didn't want to be out in the cold, alone. But I truly have no idea what so many people are raving about.
Solondz conjures a world that's rotting away from the inside, in which only the children -- freckle-faced Dylan Riley Snyder and Emma Hinz -- weep over the loss of moral authority.
[A] frustrating, borderline exploitative, madly entertaining documentary.
Salt is a senseless blast.
Ward plays Reagan as not just engaged but swaggering and overexcitable -- a fun revisionist performance. But this is Kusturica's movie.
Though it's not all it could be, Anton Chekhov's The Duel is convincingly--yes--Chekhovian.
Mother and Child is suffused with grief and loss. It's also suffused with compassion and insight.
It doesn't come close to the emotional heft of those two rare 2s that outclassed their ones: Superman 2 and Spider-Man 2. But Iron Man 2 hums along quite nicely.
The director forces into our mouths what he forces into the mouths of his female characters. The movie stinks to heaven.
The effect is to clobber you with lines that were already clobbersome and needed no extra emphasis. It starts to feel less like a thriller than an actors' workshop.

It's campier than its predecessor, but its gung ho union of black, white, and Asian gangs against reactionaries who'd destroy them is a virtuosic assertion of punky Parisian multiculturalism.

The music ties together all the pretty pictures, gives the narrative some momentum, and helps to induce a kind of alert detachment, so that you're neither especially interested nor especially bored.

Shutter Island is a long slog. The sad thing is that Scorsese could have connected emotionally with Lehane's narrative.
Burton, bless him, knows you can't CG a soul.
The first half of The Yellow Handkerchief is the half-movie of the year, and the rest isnâ(TM)t bad -- just more sentimental, more ordinary.
Calculated to enrage and pulling it off like gangbusters...
In patches it's agreeably lurid, but it's otherwise ho-hum.
Anyway, I cried. A lot. What can I say? I'm a sucker for kids on ventilators.
It's only the adrenaline-inducing techniques that conceal the lack of imagination.
The movie, a near-masterpiece, is a monument to intoxication: of sexual conquest, of military conquest, and, most of all, of cinema.
Greenberg would be a heckuva movie if we could just get Greenberg out of there.

Egoyan is an expert at isolating people, but he's less sure of himself when it comes to how they connect. So what happens to the character of Chloe is the worst kind of surprise, the "Huh?" that throws you fatally out of the movie.
This is an extraordinary film.
It isn't a train wreck -- a train wreck would be memorable.
Narrated by Rhys Ifans with the dryness of a dessicated toad, Exit Through the Gift Shop is both an exhilarating testament to serendipity and an appalling testament to art-world inanity.
Kick-Ass is a compendium of all sleazy things, and it sings like a siren to our inner Tarantinos.
In three or four scenes, they get a rhythm going, but the editing is smash-and-bash. Shawn Levy is not a director who honors performers' rhythms.
David has honed this script for 30 years, and every word he utters is momentous. Handsome Harry transcends its somewhat melodramatic narrative.
An engagingly high-strung comedy about lack of empathy and the gnawing guilt that can attend it.
Caine makes a grave, soulful vigilante avenger, and first-time director Daniel Barber gives the film a dank, streaky, genuinely unnerving palette.
A take-this-job-and-shove-it movie about the crushing malevolence of the corporate environment, it's on the verge of being really good.
What a tightrope this movie is.
Leaves of Grass is part goofy drug comedy, part shocking bloodbath. It's a riot of tones and genres, but unlike that other recent hybrid, Pineapple Express, the parts add up to something larger.

It's tempting to praise The Ides of March as a realistic depiction of how low we've sunk. But that would mean accepting the second-rate writing and third-rate melodrama and incredible shrinking characters.
Polley has gone meta-exuberantly, entertainingly, with all her heart.
Black is good at giving his heroes a morbid, self-hating edge and even better at coming up with hateable villains.

The best thing about Baz Luhrmann's much-anticipated/much-dreaded The Great Gatsby is that, for all its computer-generated whoosh and overbroad acting, it is unmistakably F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby. That is no small deal.

Baumbach has a hard time letting go of the notion that drama means building to humiliation. When he does, though, Frances Ha is beautiful and surprising.
Much of the material is out there, but Gibney has a talent for creating a one-stop shop for anyone who wants to experience the full scope of this ugly, scary story.

movie_review_blurb: Before Midnight counts on our previous investment to keep us riveted. We are.

A loopy comedy-drama every bit as mercurial as its protagonist.
A Serious Man may be the Coens' most personal film, but the humour's too oblique to truly trouble the funnybone.
By using such a typical family, it's a film most will be able to relate to, making it an inspiring, uplifting and, at the end, deeply moving mini masterpiece.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [Bright Star] may have inspired some beautiful poetry but, here, provokes mere yawns.
An eerie, intelligent drama lifted into the realm of must-see territory thanks to Péter's gently nuanced performance, plus a haunting soundtrack.
There are amusing moments, but you'll need extra-sensory powers to spot the plot.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While produced by the Wolf Creek team, the comparisons end there since it's more a humdrum hybrid of Cape Fear and Fatal Attraction, let down by few surprises and even less tension.
The real mystery, mind you, is how a film this dreadful ever got made.
A fresh spin on the vampire myth resulting in a wildly inventive and blackly comic horror. Pity it's got more padding than the average fat suit.
Too much jaw, not enough gore.
A comedy deserving to be buried up to its head in sand, drizzled in cooking oil and then left to fry until crispy.

As an exercise in wringing every last penny from Jackson's legacy, the movie may be a success. But if you're looking for a tribute to the man who once took pop to its absolute zenith, this most certainly isn't it.
Get Carter meets Death Wish in an absurdly violent but lean and tense Aussie revenge thriller.

Veteran journalist Lynn Barber's memoir of a teenage romance makes a pleasing transition to the big screen. Yet, while it's well acted and tautly paced, you never quite shake the feeling you're watching a two-parter on BBC2.
While you long to root for 9 and his pals, it's hard to emotionally connect with such under-developed characters.
Alongside football hooliganism, mad cow disease and Joss Stone, the modern British crime movie may be the export of which we're least proud.
A stop-motion masterpiece sure to delight both children and adults alike.
Never letting up for a moment, you should go see - but prepare to be shocked.
This documentary is also as well made as anything released all year, blending hard facts, cold scientific reason plus the thrills of a Hollywood spy movie to terrific effect.
Like a dodgy old motor, this smutty comedy about car salesmen roars with life to begin with but putters to a stop all too soon.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Its high production values - not to mention the world's cutest poisonous spider - can't paper over a tepid and drawn-out plot.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Maddeningly slow and relying too much on shaky handycam footage - probably an economy measure - it's a promising debut from filmmaker Marc Price.
While George A Romero certainly won't be losing any sleep, failsafe ingredients - gore, guts and hotties making out with each other - make this a movie bound to appeal to teenagers everywhere.
A violent, egocentric but nonetheless fascinating character, it's a film to watch in horrified fascination.
The tunes are so bland it could be the same song on a loop, while the performances are spirited but nondescript.
Sticking closely to the conventions of the Evil Child movie genre, there are few surprises (or even scares) as we saunter towards that absurd ending. Just about worth a punt on DVD.
While mostly a straight-up doc, the film's enlivened by the occasional surreal flourish.
Fans of good old-fashioned storytelling will find plenty to enjoy, although the less patient may feel the film's title yawnsomely accurate.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Combining awayday punch-ups with bedsit brooding, the tortured relationship between the lads is generally lifeless. Things aren't helped by the film's sheer gloom, as if a layer of dust and grime lies over the camera lens. Missable.

Drag Me To Hell really is an unmissable experience, the sort of film that those with nerves of steel will want to see again and again. Scary, electrifying and very, very funny, you won't know whether to laugh or barf.
Beyonce's latest movie contains more laughs than the entire output of Jim Carrey, Will Ferrell and Eddie Murphy. Just one problem - Obsessed is meant to be a thriller.
There's nothing here we haven't seen before, the action is laid on thick and fast with plenty of explosions and car chases, making this Big Dumb Fun of the first order.
Enjoyably gruesome, and with some timely comments about the recent craze for cyber-bullying, here's a horror perfectly pitched at its teenage target audience.
A sheer slog to sit through, Fireflies In The Garden might have worked if it wasn't so damn po-faced and the script actually had something to say about how families work.
While not the most believable of screen couples, the pair's acting chops mean you won't notice that too much while the plot chugs along at a reasonable pace, helped by some occasionally amusing gags.
Prepare to gnaw you knuckles to the bone with this nerve-shredding French thriller that poses the question: How far would you go for a loved one?
A compelling and compassionate stranger-in-a-strange-land drama, it's a film brimming with insight, integrity and life. I reckon we're looking at one of the films of 2009.

A movie that has the same effect as a handful of Mogadon. It's so utterly dull they ought to give out prizes to anyone who keeps their eyes open to the end. Personally, I resorted to two carefully-placed matchsticks.
A big-hearted, earthy and highly amusing comedy, it's compassionate, feelgood fare of the very first order.
Lewd, crude and exceptionally rude, the gags come thick and fast.
A pulse-pounding visual spectacle, given its bloodline this is the very least we expect. But when things aren't blowing up, T4 sags - and sags badly.
It's not quite as good as the unfairly maligned first instalment but, for parents, this is a foolproof way of filling a slot over the Bank Holiday weekend.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a cerebral, smart and downright surreal trip into the far reaches of the mind. I'm still having trouble working out whether it's a work of genius or a self-indulgent pile of guff.
A relationships drama with almost nothing to say about relationships - except that they ain't easy - the only memorable thing about this is a supporting turn by former footballer Eric Cantona.
It doesn't hit home quite like it should, but director Eran Creevy deserves credit for delivering something better than the usual Brit gruel.
The trouble is a twist ending that even a brain-dead centipede will see coming a long way off.
Not glorious. Not good. Just plain old-fashioned duff.
Even if you're not a superhero fan, Wolverine won't disappoint since, alongside some gloriously over-the-top action scenes, it's an intelligent, brooding movie.

The End could be criticised for being one-sided (none of the victims get a look-in). But that's missing the point, for at heart it's really a portrait of a long-gone era. In all, it's the best British crime film in years.
It's all good, clean fun but bland, corny and forgettable, too.
Alas, it swiftly ditches the pithy asides as it hurtles towards its treacly ending.
Witty, poignant and very touching, this is the British comedy of the year.
Overall, it makes for an entertaining, if uneven, couple of hours, although non-Trekkies may not find it the intergalactic go-see they'd hoped for.
There's little in this period piffle to engage or entertain.
Filled with backstage tears and onstage triumph, the film neatly captures the sheer awkwardness of being a youngster. Go see.
Little Ashes is an arthouse film filled with bare bottoms, full-frontal nudity and gay passion. You can practically hear Pattinson's army of girl fans weeping into their popcorn.

While there are punch-ups aplenty, it's less concerned with bruised knuckles and more interested in the bruised personalities of its protagonists, making for a thoughtful, if rarely electrifying, movie.
There may be a decent thriller here, but it's buried alive beneath turgid pacing and ream upon ream of dry-as-dust dialogue. Oh, and Ewan McGregor's in it - rarely a good sign.
Bums and bosoms are in abundance, although there's not enough plot to go around, meaning you'll feel every minute of that two-hour running time.
A chilling exploration of how our love affair with seafood is devastating the world's oceans while pushing species after species to extinction.
Predictable, pointless and pathetic.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: So depressing, life-sapping and unrelentingly nihilistic, words have yet to be invented to convey the sheer awfulness of this so-called thriller. A contender for worst film of 2009.
Big, loud and definitely not clever, it's a giant, lumbering idiot of a movie that, were it not for all the explosions, would send the most devoted action fans to sleep.
While it's an occasionally unsettling piece - and comes with a big-name cast - the story never goes anywhere.
Predictable rom-coms can work if the comedy and chemistry are there. Alas, both have gone AWOL. There's a dry and silent desert where the jokes are meant to be.
It's ploddy, affected and ludicrously nasty but, for all that, Lars von Trier's new movie could well be the best horror film since the genre's 70s heyday.
Cracking along at a fast pace with a plot full of twists and turns, it's a first-rate thriller and one bound to get the Hollywood remake treatment very soon.
