movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The linear A-to-B storyline gives the film a TV movie feel, with an overdose of melodrama not helping matters.
Tony Scott has made a film that, for sheer fun and breathless tension, leaves the summer's other actioners parked in the sidings.
The crude humour is as unfunny as it is ill-judged. Set to become a favourite of bad movie clubs everywhere.
The plot lurches joylessly from A to B, while the bored-sounding voice cast - Nicolas Cage, Penélope Cruz, Sam Rockwell - might have delivered their dialogue down a phone line.
The whole thing's about as enjoyable as a holiday to Guantanamo Bay. Less a movie and more a two-hour finger wag.
While visually gorgeous, there's little to engage the heart with few surprises within the linear storyline. Meanwhile, Tautou looks a lot like an actress who is out of her depth.
It's big, it's dumb and its cast won't be winning any acting awards, but for all that, the film delivers a two-hour blast of fun sure to delight the kid in all of us.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While [Heigl] and co-star Gerard Butler give good performances, the film's the same predictable fluff we've all seen before - and seen done better.
A movie guaranteed to enchant all. Mind you, with a cast this cute, they couldn't really fail.
Like a feud between Dannii Minogue and Cheryl Cole, you don't care who wins, but it's fun to watch. Alas, the preceding 80 minutes aren't. Great title, lousy film.
A kind of anti-road movie, the first half is a genial rural snapshot but, when that bypass opens, the wheels come off and things take a turn for the surreal and boring.
Actress Melissa Leo rightly earned an Oscar nomination for her part in this downbeat drama.
A romantic comedy so dull, so humdrum, they should give out free espressos at screenings.

Burma VJ (Video Journal) is as gripping as any Hollywood thriller - and as heartbreaking as any weepie as we watch the celebratory mood that briefly blossomed in Rangoon give way to appalling violence.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A music film best appreciated with earplugs firmly in place, it's not just the unholy sound that's a turn-off but its inability to tell us anything interesting. The result is dry, unilluminating and, frequently, ear-splitting.
Telstar is a rambling, chaotic mess that's got missed opportunity written all over it.
An indie comedy that's been kooked to a crisp. Wearing its quirkiness on its sleeve, the whole thing's just too self-consciously strange to engage.
While there's a good leading performance, after about half an hour you may notice your ability to give a damn also disappearing.
A touch hard to tell what's going on at times, the film comes into its own towards the end as it portrays with shocking candour the genocide that still reverberates in Eastern Europe to this day.
Ice Age part three - a competent water-treader which use a cast of cutesy animals to disguise their lack of ambition.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Shot in pin-sharp high-definition, this is one amazing-looking movie, where even the most ordinary scenes crackle with energy and suspense. As with Heat, Mann's made not just the crime drama of the year, but possibly of the decade too.
A horror with a sense of its own absurdity, it's a cult classic in the making.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This illuminating doc looks back on the Philly singer's life and times. It reveals a vast talent who lost his way through a combination of drugs and bad business decisions.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A very satisfying, if emotionally draining, experience. Needless to say you should take a large box of hankies - plus a bottle of water so you can rehydrate afterwards.
Comprised of jokes that wouldn't amuse a five-year-old, and looking as if it was knocked together over a weekend, Year One delivers about as many laughs as I Spit On Your Grave.
It's a film so achingly average it almost deserves an award for mediocrity.
One of the funniest things you'll ever see.
As an in-your-face way of confronting ageism, it certainly does the trick, although I'm still feeling a bit queasy having just watched a granny drop her bloomers.
While Soul Power is bound to be compared to the Oscar-winning Ali/Foreman documentary When We Were Kings, it never scales the same heights.
It's all very slender stuff and very hard to care about the characters, most of whom whine rather than speak their lines. All in all, it's a life that should have stayed private.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One space odyssey you're unlikely to forget.

It's so dull. While some actors have praised the movie for its accurate portrayal of backstage life, if you haven't trodden the boards it's much harder to get caught up in the A-to-B dramas facing the troupe, or Richard and Sonja's affair.
Like one of those Cosmopolitan cocktails, it's guaranteed to leave women everywhere with a warm, fuzzy glow. For men, it's like all your hangovers came along at once.
The Box is based on a 10-page short story and, while it was successfully adapted for a one-hour episode of The Twilight Zone, there's not enough for a feature, let alone one lasting two-hours.
He's survived six sequels, a grudge match with Jason Voorhees and a terrible TV spin-off, but this remake may finally finish Freddy Krueger once and for all.
As far as time-travelling farces go, file this under John and Chev's Sucky Adventure.
The best thing you can say about Furry Vengeance is that it's kid friendly -- provided, that is, the kids are under five and a touch slow.
Like Das Boot, only on caterpillar tracks, it's tense and claustrophobic, with the soldiers not gung-ho beefcakes but scared and doubtful young men who'd rather be anywhere else.

Packed with interviews with his family and friends, some fine animation and plenty of highlights from his shows, it's an illuminating and often moving affair although not quite as funny as it should be.
It's not just the subject matter of impossible love that recalls Brokeback Mountain, but the same aching sadness and pathos.
The film's attempts to not just humanise but to make us like the bombers undermines the comedy.
Ravishingly beautiful, immersive and with terrific performances from the two leads, it's a real gem.
Cop Out marks a new low which is really saying something given that Smith's the man behind Mallrats, Chasing Amy and Jersey Girl.
As a police procedural, it's a generally dull affair. As an exercise in silliness, it elicits a fair few laughs. But whether the joke's on Herzog or on us is anybody's guess.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An hour and a half of globetrotting, things blowing up in slow motion and not a whole lot else.
An edgy and ambitious crime thriller that feels like a homegrown Tarantino movie.
A rerun of the first film only with less tension, more gore and characters who behave a bit more stupidly.
While Johnson's as fun as ever to watch, he struggles with a weak storyline, lame gags and enough syrup to melt your fillings.

There's simply nothing good about it. The special effects are ropey, the plot creaks, the performances are indifferent and - worst of all - it patronises the viewer with dialogue that explains what's about to happen at every turn.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a movie -- it's a piece of product.
Maybe it's time for Hess to go back to Napoleon Dynamite for a sequel. Although, on second thoughts, perhaps he should leave well alone.
While it's quite watchable, The Last Song doesn't feel like a film that's been made so much as assembled from standard teen movie clichés.
Beautifully animated, genuinely touching and with a terrific climax, it's the perfect family film.
Unlike most Hollywood teen product, here fulfilment comes not from what others think of you but from what you think of yourself. In short, it's Girl Power reinvented.
As an example of how not to make a movie, Repo Men deserves to be studied by film students.
Subtitled and with laughs of the subtlest kind, Ben Hopkins has crafted a deliciously funny cautionary tale on the perils of greed and how globalisation can be a heartless mistress.
movie_title: The Market: A Tale of Trade (Pazar: Bir Ticaret Masali) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The result is certainly Polanski's best film in years and one can only hope his current legal woes - facing extradition to the US over his 1977 conviction in an underage sex case - don't detract from a thriller that oozes intrigue and Hitchcockian menace.
Despite the genial banter of Steve Carell and Tina Fey, it's a comedy with so few laughs it could be prosecuted under the Trade Descriptions Act.
Aside from being not all that funny, Judge's droll-ish observations on the small-mindedness of corporate America never hit the mark while there are too many go-nowhere plot diversions.
A film that'll make you laugh out loud -- and then make you want to wash your hands.
While it never quite manages to shake off the E4 vibe, it's good to see Grint stretching his wings.
It's not a bad idea, but just as you think you're watching a biting consumer satire, the plot instead descends into melodrama and soap operatics.
While there's a terrific battle near the start as the Romans are ambushed by the locals, the realisation soon dawns that this is a deeply average chase movie.
Get past the togas and its somewhat stately pace, and here lies a movie with a timely message about the perils of religious intolerance.
Given the strength of part one, the sequel is not just a terrific failure but a terrific disappointment.
Recalling one of those exploitation flicks so popular in 70s drive-ins, everyone involved deserves a pat on the back for producing such a fearless British movie. If only it was better.
It's a slow-burning Austrian thriller with no stars, no special effects and, by the looks of it, almost no budget. But sometimes a little goes a long way.
Overall, it's better than the original -- although that's not saying much.
It's not in 3D, you won't have heard of the cast, and I suspect the budget was in the low five figures. However, this tender little gem is as good as anything you'll see this week.
Stylish, sweatily seductive and boasts career-best performances from the leads. It's just let down by a plot that runs out of steam 40 minutes before the end.
It's not half as bad as it sounds thanks to the likable, grounding presence of Baruchel, plus Nate Torrence as his chubby pal.
What should have been yet another unnecessary, not-as-good-as-the-original is actually miles, miles better.
A pedestrian Australian drama that's big on scenery and long, meaningful silences but short on story.
It's a violent and truly scary film and definitely not one for the kids. For grown-ups, though, it could well be the ultimate superhero movie.
The sheer imagination brought to the screen -- not to mention the tunes -- make this a film j'adore.
[Lacks] the balance you'd expect in a documentary.
While it's not a particularly imaginative movie, it's a great-looking one...
That rarest of things, a big-budget actioner that's almost impossible to enjoy.
Plotwise, this is a slow dance indeed, with the players partnered-up with club-footed clichés and some deeply one-dimensional characters.
It's a reasonable enough romp, but Tom Cruise with a gun still makes me uneasy.
If you're a kid whose summer holidays are starting to drag, this should kill a couple of hours. Just do your folks a favour and don't make them come along.
Outta sight!
The novelty quickly fades since -- you guessed it -- the story's just not there.
[A] slice of self-important nonsense that's actually pretty funny, although probably not in the way Shyamalan planned.
Cribbing desperately from The Lord Of The Rings, Reign Of Fire, and especially Beowulf, it's a snorgasbord of awfulness.
With its idyllic scenery, neat metaphysical twist and subtly-conveyed message, it's a weepy guaranteed to fill tissues.
I doubt we'll see better all year.
It stars former pop queen Tiffany, who topped the charts in 1987 with I Think We're Alone Now. Visit a cinema showing this and the chances are you'll know what she was singing about.
While essentially a larky comedy caper, the film's undertones of lost opportunity and growing old strike exactly the right emotional notes. It makes for a tear-jerking finale of the very first order.
It's one of those films whose fun set-up is terrific, only to be offset by the muddled plot. Still, there are some decent laughs amid the mess.
Although slick and occasionally tense, it's also downright predictable and occasionally boring. In fact, top Gere it ain't.
It's hard to convey the sheer awfulness. And that's not just me being a grumpy bloke confronted with a chick flick.

Are you a movie star nobody takes seriously? Are you fed-up with being cast in dumb comedies? Do you crave the respect of your peers? Then call Noah Baumbach, a director with a knack for extracting good performances from the unlikeliest of places.
While rough and ready, this is a documentary that makes us come to care very deeply for these lost souls, even if you suspect all they need to do is move down to Foster's.
movie_title: Shed Your Tears and Walk Away (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is mostly plain hilarious.
It has a noticeably 80s retro vibe, while the sheer inventiveness of the slayings paper over a very thin and familiar storyline.
Ladies, here's a chick-flick best enjoyed with your eyelids actually glued together.
If we all loved the first film, enjoyed the second and were disappointed by the third, this fourth and final entry ends the Shrek series on a satisfying high note.
Very much a slow burner, the tension is ratcheted up to near-suffocating levels, while Huppert and co-star Christopher Lambert give flawless performances.
Bright, breezy and just a little forgettable.
Chiselled from the same block of unhappiness as The Ice Storm, Thumbsucker and just about every other movie made by a depressed baby-boomer, it's yet more well-acted retro anguish.
Unlikely to light your fire, or anyone else's.
In a decade dominated by the three dreaded Rs of remakes, reimaginings and reboots comes a truly original blockbuster.
It's a surreal little film with an intriguing Freudian subtext and a haunting blend of magic and gritty realism.
Look for your kicks elsewhere.
Much better than you might expect.
What director Louis Leterrier serves up is a simple quest movie enlivened by some respectable if rarely spectacular special effects.
It's beautifully shot, nicely acted and about as dry as comedies get. In fact, it's so dry it might not be a comedy at all.
A sensational and very moving documentary shot undercover in Zimbabwe. The result deserves to be seen by everyone.
Already drawing waggish comparisons to The Apprentice, a more suitable comparison for a film this drawn-out and sterile might be Eight Characters In Search Of A Plot.
Daybreakers takes the undead in an entirely different direction, melding smart sci-fi with a timely political subtext.

[Serkis] outdoes even himself with a blistering portrayal of rock 'n' roll star Ian Dury that's sure to be one of the performances of the year. Sweaty, wide-eyed and maniacal, it's a turn that deserves to put him in serious awards contention.
A witty satire on TV news? No. An inspiring lesson about following your heart? Nope. The worst comedy you'll see all year? Oh yes.
The problem is a ho-hum storyline that feels as if it's been strapped to a rack and stretched to breaking point.
What might be the feelbad film of the year makes an early but convincing claim to be the film of 2010.

Winstone is in typically ferocious form, alternating between a heartbroken husk and a snorting bull, while Hurt spews foul language through a set of ill-fitting false teeth. Not terrible then, but not sexy - and certainly no beast.
While the current trend in documentaries is to take stories and wrap them into neat little packages, Crude runs merrily against the grain.

Brothers is a film that fails on almost every level, coming with no meaningful message about the morality of war, saying nothing about sibling relationships and with the worst case of miscasting I can recall.
An emotionally draining but soul-stirring classic.
An underwhelming heist-gone-wrong movie that, inexplicably, has avoided going straight to DVD.
Owen is sensational, providing a sensitive, soulful presence that lifts the film, making for a touching and inspiring trip to the movies.

Despite an insanely visceral opening sequence in which limbs are severed amid fountains of claret, we're all too soon left with a tedious police procedural, sprinkled with the odd fight scene that confuses more than thrills.
Delivering his killer one-liners with a gently raised eyebrow, Clooney impresses at every turn and is fast becoming one of Hollywood's subtlest comedy actors.

Meyers steers a middle course between saccharine and sentiment with her latest, a warm, witty and wise rom-com focusing on the mating habits of fiftysomething Californians. Think Sex And The City for seniors.
Like sitting under the dentist's drill for 100 minutes, there's not a single, solitary laugh in the whole damn thing. In fact, it's a film so bad you actually start to feel sorry for the stars.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Spread is as fluffy as you can get, while you wonder how anyone could fall for someone like Nikki who dresses like a cross between Julian Clary and a far-right thug. Ghastly.

While pretty much a cut-and-shut of every animated movie of the past decade, this sci-fi comedy should achieve blast-off with the under-10s. For adults, however, this is as solidly so what? as you can get.
It's fatally undermined by the lead, Sasha Grey, a real-life porn star who absolutely, categorically cannot act.
The effects are spot-on, little Max Records is ace as the story's boisterous nine-year-old hero while the film mostly avoids the treacle that mars so many kids' pics.
Uninspiring and, crucially, not all that scary. There are no attempts either to explore the killer's motivation and none of the original's black humour.
Jarmusch gives us a film designed to test the limits of our patience.
Very much horror-lite, here's a movie crying out for more claret to ramp up the sense of dread. Still, when dealing with the awful life-or-death decisions the survivors face, it's grimly effective.
Avatar truly is something else, a wondrously-detailed visual extravaganza quite unlike anything you've seen before.
An intelligent, low-key look at male sexuality which is sensitively handled. What a pity, then, that the ending's such a let-down... or an anti-climax, you could say.

While revealing almost nothing new about Lennon, and sticking rigidly to biopic conventions, it's just about worth catching thanks to Scott Thomas, who's spot-on as the arch but affectionate guardian.
With an unengaging plot, flat jokes and shameless product placement, Alvin is a late contender for worst film of the year.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: St Trinian's 2 isn't just appalling, it's like scouring those final, last-gasp instalments of the Carry On or Confessions Of... movies looking for a laugh.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is alive with cinematic magic, played out in an expertly-recreated capital full of grime, grubbiness and occasional grandeur.
Some great numbers and stunning set designs are let down by a failure to make us care about Guido's plight.
A Mexican drama that, while nice to look at, is deeply boring.
While there's little to hate, there's almost nothing to like in a film this anodyne. The jokes aren't funny, the performances are middling and the storyline predictable.
A celebration of music and friendship, and a document of the vacuousness of Cool Britannia, documentaries don't get any better.
movie_title: Blur: No Distance Left to Run (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Although entertaining, if workmanlike, for the first hour or so, it gets too carried away with its conspiracies - plus Gibson's faux Boston accent is just terrible.
Somehow all the trauma never overwhelms the characters who feel real, particularly Precious herself whose silence conveys more inner sadness than a million words.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The issue of race is delicately handled, though, leaving you to hum along to Randy Newman's excellent score, laugh at the screwball interplay between waitress and prince, and drink in the terrific animation.
A troubling portrait of a country shaken by repossessions, exploitation and the rich sucking the life out of the poor.
While the two leads try their best, it's a losing battle with a plot this hackneyed, a script this underdone and some woeful supporting performances.
Burton doesn't just hit the bottom of the barrel but drills through the wood and starts tunnelling. Its only saving grace are the arresting, if familiar, visuals.
It's hard to see why the target audience would want to sacrifice two precious hours watching their own soul-sapping routines played out on the big screen.
Despite the religious trappings, Legion is an old fashioned shoot-'em-up with satisfying gunfights, a pacey plot and barely a dull moment. Dumb fun.
Rather than recalling the master of suspense, it brings to mind a straight-to-video cheapie you'd find in Blockbuster circa 1992.

It's all been done before, of course, and Case 39 is let down by too many of those jolting boo! moments, ropey special effects - check out a badly-animated hornet attack - plus a plot even casual horror fans can predict.
There's no doubt that Marty's still got it.
Old Dogs is a milestone in the [Travolta's] career, the moment when he trumped Battlefield Earth to make the worst film of his life.
I'm actually yawning as I type this.
The results are always less than hilarious.
A cult comedy classic in the making.
While the performances are passable, the plot is much less impressive as it journeys into dark and increasingly improbable waters.
More intelligent cinema-goers -- or perhaps just those who like their bloodshed well done -- will love every minute, relishing the jet-black humour and drinking in the Tom And Jerry-style violence.
It recalls Guy Ritchie's back catalogue but, thankfully, without the self-consciously frenetic camerawork. The result is slick and enjoyable, but has a whiff of déjà vu.
Another cynically violent, casually racist action movie that even Michael Winner would disown.
Boasting plenty of gore in some suspiciously well-lit caves, fans of the original will find little to complain about.
This loose-ish remake, on the other hand, is slick, fast-paced and as bland as a bowl of tofu.
If you've seen Lorenzo's Oil, you'll know how it goes, but you're advised to tone down your expectations.
A characteristically skewed but cerebral look at a dysfunctional family in a movie much easier to admire than actually like.
A film that works thanks to characters who aren't mere ciphers but come with deep, if hidden, emotions.
79-year-old Clint Eastwood delivers yet another tub-thumping classic - a sports drama that'll have all but the most cynical cheering from their seats.

A masterclass in psychological horror. Funny, terrifying and with a central character to be both despised and pitied, here's a movie that once seen is very, very hard to forget - not necessarily a good thing.
The whole thing's a terrible mess and Cera's star, once rapidly rising, is now almost in freefall.

Welded together with parts from similar but superior fare such as WALL-E, Iron Giant and The Jetsons, the much-loved Animé character flies into cinemas for a toon that should just about keep the kids amused.
Tom Ford delivers the surprise of the year with a startlingly beautiful and sorrowful meditation on grief.
Sappiness overflows in a rom-com possessing little humour and all the romance of a bouquet of garage roses. The intention is to put a warm, fuzzy feeling in our tummies. Often it feels like nausea.
While the Hogwarts saga may be getting long in the tooth, at least it has decent characters and a sense of humour. This has neither.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the déjà vu there's plenty to enjoy, and not just for kids, from an earnest environmental message to animation that comes alive when seen in 3D.
No bones about it, Jackson looks like he's spent so long in front of a computer he's forgotten how to tell a story.
While you can't quite shake the film's Channel 5 matinee feel, star performances lift Crazy I Heart above the ordinary.
A movie with an important message and is an impressive debut from Morton.
A movie you can admire but rarely enjoy.
Robert De Niro's latest would-be weepy, Everybody's Fine, may remind you of About Schmidt's less-interesting brother. In fact, the title says it all - it's neither good nor bad, just deeply OK.
Filled with Jeunet's zany humour, fans will be impressed, although beginners should start with Amélie.

Having observed Seth Rogen's latest comedy, may I report that it's not very good. And if that seems like a tedious pun (even by my standards), that's because I've just sat through an hour and a half of them.
It's a movie that only sci-fi nerds are going to enjoy.
The fact that it doesn't feel like a vampire flick at all makes it one of the best of its kind.
There are far better ways of keeping the kids happy.
What we have here is one of those very long, very slow dramas that might just have worked if the inevitable twist ending had been worth sticking around for. But it isn't.
The funniest thing I've ever seen in my life.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Little Children is a movie that defies easy categorisation. It's not quite a drama, not quite a love story, not quite a black comedy but rather a little of all three rolled together.
You'll be shaken. You'll be stirred. Heck, you'll be blown away.

Both actors put in terrific performances while the film captures the grim, grinding cycle of dependence just perfectly. But for all that, it's very hard to get excited about a film with so little to say about [such] rich topics.
Don't know about you, but I've seen enough weird women with long hair and heard enough of those screechy violins and atonal sound effects to last a lifetime.
... a film that aims for the lowest-common denominator and falls even shorter.
Sure, Night At The Museum isn't about to win any awards for originality, but this is a flick that exhibits a fine sense of fun.
Grabs you by the throat and never lets go.
The Covenant looks less like a movie and more like an extended boy band video -- and with about the same amount of depth.
The movie's flat-footed nature means it's unlikely to put a spring in the step of anyone over the age of 10.
Sweet, sentimental and sickly.
None of the cast are going to win Oscars for this, but then they're not meant to. Instead, all involved expertly keep the plot moving forward towards a reasonably satisfying ending.
Something hackneyed, trite and boring, you mean.
A couple of years ago, this might have been something special, but with so many talking animal films out there, it just ain't.
Comedy doesn't get much blacker -- or more brilliant -- than this.
The result is simply spellbinding.

Almodovar infuses proceedings with a horrible sense of self-satisfaction and also has a disconcerting habit of lots of lingering, leery shots of his lead actresses' bodies, including a pervy close-up of a teenage girl's groin.
Slow-moving, tasteless and totally devoid of ingenuity or charisma, this is a gross one-joke monstrosity - and that joke wasn't very funny in the first place.
Not Yet Rated is a doc that anyone with even a passing interest in movie censorship, sorry, classification, should seek out.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is the first shocker in ages where you actually care about what happens to the victims.
... as humorous as diphtheria.
The hunt for the best comedy of 2006 ends, I suspect, right here.
Movies about moral choices work if we can relate to the characters' motivations, but that never happens here.

Some of the jokes here are funny. Most are not, while the characters are simply too silly to make us give two hoots about them. Worse, the movie collapses under the weight of a ton of syrup in the second half.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Seven days that shook the Monarchy to its very core are explored in this fascinating insight into the Royal Family following the death of Diana.
Presented by former US Vice President Al Gore, this documentary is a cool, clinical examination of global warming. And if you thought the repercussions were years off, think again.
The Canada-set Snow Cake is clearly meant to be Weaver's movie, and people with first-hand knowledge of autism say it's the most convincing depiction they've ever seen.

A film that boys aged 12 to 15 are going to lap up thanks to endless shots of Valance and her curvy co-stars in their swimsuits. But with a plot even flimsier than the bikinis, there's nothing here for the rest of us.
Really, there are only so many fart jokes a person can take.
It's a reasonably entertaining movie, but it comes nowhere close to the sheer, heart-pounding terror of the ultimate 9/11 film, United 93.
Crackling with energy, featuring great actors sinking their teeth into the meatiest of roles and a plot that bubbles with tension, this is Scorsese's finest film since Goodfellas.
We can only hope the next instalment will have a little more fire in its belly.
There's the odd giggle, but nowhere near enough to keep things going.
The film as a whole is missing something, with much of the problem lying with the cast -- including Barry Pepper, Jamie Bell and Adam Beach -- who are seriously bland.
It seems certain Whitaker will get that Oscar nod for superbly conveying Amin's weird mix of buffoonery and cold-bloodedness.
It's a bit of a McMovie.
Probably the best family film you'll see all year.
Self-pitying and saccharine, this big whining ball of dross drags itself across the screen for two interminable hours, climaxing in a twist ending that comes with neon road signs attached.
Apart from a few nerve-jangling moments at the start and some snazzy digital effects, this is about as pointless and unnecessary as sequels get.
Occasionally moving but mostly dry.
Rubbish.
Everyone's favourite arachnid returns in his slickest, smartest and darkest movie yet.
Give your money to charity. Throw it out of the window. Set it on fire. Just don't waste it by paying to see this.
With its chirpy score, lovable characters and Festival Of Britain flavour, Grow Your Own would have bedded in nicely as a TV movie. On the big screen, it starts to wilt.
With shades of Psycho and The Birds, Vacancy sure isn't up there with The Master's finest work but, given that we haven't had a decent horror all year, it's a pleasantly creepy surprise.

GEORGE BUSH loves to lecture us about how his war on terror is all about preserving freedom and spreading democracy. What he doesn't tell us is how for the past 50 years, the US has covertly tried to crush both in a bid to control South America
The film gets three stars because it's such an impressive production - and of course the soundtrack kicks - but it'll still probably leave you feeling strangely cold.

Although Lucky You was made nearly two years ago, it seems Warner Brothers didn't quite know what to do with it, hence it being quietly slipped out in a quiet week between blockbusters. Maybe they hoped nobody would notice.
It flunks because it's one of the daftest, dullest films I've seen in an absolute age.
KAPOW! The world's most boring superheroes return to lull us back to sleep in a sequel that could put the makers of Nytol out of business.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Just imagine, if this movie was really good, it'd get five stars (2 + 3). Instead it gets a two. Which adds up to very little.
Unlike the original, this version is never sure whether it wants to go to the dark side or not.
For a film with such high Oscar hopes, you'll leave the cinema wondering what all the fuss is about.

Using the kind of snazzy flashbacks, blood fetishism and moronic villains that were so in vogue oh, let's see, about 10 years ago, the action revolves around an assortment of rival hoodlums all gunning for police informant Buddy 'Aces' Israel.
May have a slight TV movie vibe to it, but Gardner's story is so stirring and so incredible that it really doesn't matter.
While there's some serious sag between the action scenes, this is a blockbuster with brains and the kind of film to make us all think twice on our next visit to the jeweller.
Meandering, maudlin and totally missable.
Plenty of jolts and some pleasingly spooky scenes, with the tension ratcheted up to fever pitch, but then it all falls to pieces with a badly fumbled ending.
Although a little contrived in places, and with some dialogue that probably looked better on the page, this is still enjoyable fare that proves there's plenty of life in the old dogs yet.
So, this is a passable, often funny rom-com that'll make an awful lot of Friday-night daters very happy. But it really is high time Grant tried something different.
More resembling a gory TV movie than a real film, this will give you nightmares for all the wrong reasons.
Would have been much better as a 30-minute TV show, with not enough of a plot for a full film.
Becker, who made the first instalment just about passable, is bland here while Alessandro Nivola, who plays his best pal, looks rightly bored.
Most of the problem is that everything feels very familiar, while the movie's moralising tone grates very quickly.

The film that Hot Fuzz reminded me of most was The Boys In Blue, in which Cannon and Ball played rural bobbies suddenly confronted with a real crime to solve. As you can probably guess, it wasn't much cop. And neither is this.
As the movie progresses, we're presented with one of the best portrayals of the innate awkwardness of first love I can ever remember seeing.
With what's going on in Afghanistan today, 9th Company is nothing if not timely.
Touches are just enough to earn The Good Shepherd a third star. But De Niro might want to stick to acting in future.
Bookended by the terrible tragedy that befell Ai Qin and her friends, this is raw, heartfelt stuff - and enough to make you choke on your salad.
Christian Bale proves yet again why he's one of Britain's best actors in this nightmarish, nasty but unforgettable thriller.
You've never seen anything like this before due to some simply astonishing animation.
The young star is such a little cutey-pie and the plot so cleverly manipulative that, whatever its faults, you'll still have a lump in your throat throughout.
This is a near-perfect period drama.
Incredibly, the movie was made for just 2m but, thanks to the brilliant special effects, manages to be visually dazzling and totally gripping.
Every time [Alba] dives into the ocean, you expect to see her bobbing back up to the surface like an old plank.
Let the adjectives roll  this is the most thrilling, exciting, magical kids movie Ive seen since, well, since the last Harry Potter film.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: [A] haunting and highly-intelligent thriller.
I'm sitting here shakey of hand and bulgey of eye, trying to convey just how pitiful this film is. Yet no words I can think of do justice to this dross. It is just awful.
Serenity blasts George Lucass recent prequels into the ether thanks to some rip-roaring action scenes and a knack of not taking itself too seriously.
You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll love every minute.
The result features special effects that will make your jaw drop.
Heavy-handed, self-important and way, way too whimsical, Merry Christmas never hits home emotionally.
Two hours of non-stop laughs of the most politically-incorrect kind.
Oh, Woody. Oh Woody, Woody, Woody. What were you thinking? Or, being brutal, were you thinking at all?
Gripping, intelligent and amazing to look at, here, at last, is a combat film that's not to be missed -- even if there's no combat in it.
Give this anarchic British comedy a shot and you'll be laughing from start to finish.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The saving grace is Dillon who delivers a tour de force performance.
It's long been said that films have the power to inspire violence in the viewing public. Revolver is one such movie -- a piece of work guaranteed to send you into a violent frenzy.
A fast-moving treat.
As a Friday night DVD movie, this is passable. As a multiplex movie event, it never leaves the runway.
The animation is crisp, if a touch generic, the voice cast convincing and the story wholesome without cloying too much.
movie_title: Tinker Bell and the Great Fairy Rescue (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Prepare to be blown away because George Lucas's latest space opera is an absolute belter, recalling the old magic of The Empire Strikes Back and banishing forever painful memories of the last two Star Wars prequels.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As an undemanding Friday night popcorn flick, this is right on the money.
While the first hour promises something very special indeed, the build-up is squandered once the two brothers take flight with not enough sense of danger or urgency to hold your attention.
Heroin really screws you up. And this deathly dull drug drama will do the same  if you manage to get to the end, that is.
Steven Spielberg has delivered the blockbuster of the summer, a stunning sci-fi spectacular thatll blow you away. Yes, I know Im gushing, but War Of The Worlds really is that good.
A disturbing, sad and blisteringly funny cautionary tale, I reckon this is the documentary of the year.
Incredibly, Marshall is now being talked of as the great white hope of British horror. Now that is scary.
Sounds bad, doesn't it?
Far and away the funniest film I've seen all year.
A movie worth catching, mostly thanks to Depp who lights up the screen as the deliciously-dotty confectioner.
This is a futuristic thriller about cloning, which is ironic given that The Island is a clone of half a dozen much better sci-fi movies.
Don't, whatever you do, expect to Be-entertained by this feeble rom-com.
After about 20 minutes, youll start wondering just how many times were going to see our two moronic leads doing handbrake turns and going whoooo-hooo. I counted at least 30.
With some serious editing, this could've been one of the comedies of the year. As it is, it's strictly one for the lads.
Poignant, powerful and unforgettable.
The first hour will test the patience of all but diehard fans of the genre, flipping randomly through time before things settle down for a final 50 minutes examining the ethics of revenge.
Paltrow stars as a woman who may or may not be around the twist. Having named her real-life child after a piece of fruit, that's what I call inspired casting.
Zathura is one of those rare movies that should appeal to kids and adults alike thanks to a great little storyline, neat special effects and a genuinely likeable cast.
As a comedy, it doesn't quite gel. As a musical it doesn't have much more luck, but as a showcase for Chappelle's talents, Block Party works just fine.

There are plenty of impressive gunfights and some wicked martial arts sequences here, but the film is most likely to be remembered for its emphasis on free running, a dizzying physical technique in which the cast sprint, leap and roll through the city.
You might well need a bottle of rum to get through that two-and-a-half hour running time.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Stay with it and you'll discover a devastatingly powerful blast at red tape and an achingly moving examination of what we will all have to face one day.
Many happy returns, Superman, you've been away too long. Unfortunately, you deserve a lot better than this.
It's never less than entertaining and the chemistry between our two leads, whatever their personal circumstances, really holds things together.
Beneath those whiz-bang, state-of-the-art graphics lies a paean to nostalgia we've all heard before.
Just like Pixar's latest, the good looks are let down by a weak plot.
Good looking but tedious.
A highly-influential TV show winds up as a decent but flawed movie and the hunt for a truly great 2006 summer blockbuster continues.
The good intentions are there and the film is expertly structured. It's just that it's hard to get that excited about batteries.
As you watch Jaa's mastery of his art, you'll have to master the art of laughing while your jaw's hanging off your head in disbelief. You've never seen anything like it.it.
There are so many things wrong with Lady that there just isn't enough space to go into them here.
It may be a tad too scary for the very young but for everyone else this is a frighteningly good movie.
It all seems very workaday.
Despite the Manhattan dating scene stuff, the PG certificate means there's not much sex in this city, but more than enough raunchy undertones to keep teenage girls happy.
Probably more one for arthouse fans, Lady Chatterley lingers in the mind not because of all that nudity - and there's a lot - but because it's so beautifully made.
A film that's good looking, thoroughly engaging and very, very funny. Better still, it's a movie that will delight all age groups and not just the ankle biters.
Lordy mama, the thing's just unspeakable.
This year's Catwoman, a disaster of truly seismic proportions.
George Clooney is emerging as one of America's bravest, boldest filmmakers. And with this highly-charged political thriller, he's also emerging as one of its very best.
United 93 stands as a towering, unforgettable testament to the bravery of the people who died that morning.
Touching, funny and sad.
[A] distinctly dull offering.
After discovering his girlfriend has been murdered, a high school geek attempts to unravel the mystery in what may be the best teen movie you've ever seen.
Worth a one-night stand, but certainly not a trip down the aisle.
A total joy.
Sure, some of the acting's excruciating and the dialogue is dire. But heck, as a big dumb action movie, it delivers by the bucketload.
Beautifully made it may be, but The Wind is a movie that engages the head while never troubling the heart.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The result is the hippest comedy of the year.
Smart, challenging and timely look at the world of internet grooming.
An Unfinished Life isn't going to win any prizes for originality, yet despite the derivative feel - and some hokey melodrama - it's still a solidly entertaining film.

A movie that's trying with all its might to be an earnest, poignant relationship drama, yet it fails at each and every turn thanks to zero chemistry between its leads and the complete absence of a coherent plot.

I don't know about you, but I stopped playing with my cars when I was 10 and you never escape the feeling that the characters in this knackered Nissan of a film have never grown out of messing around with their brrm-brrms.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In short, it's an absolute louse of a film -- 94 minutes of unimaginable, unspeakable awfulness.
Knocked Up really is the comedy of the year.

It may be too ponderous for some, and an appearance by Anjelica Huston as a snake-oil peddler near the end is a touch too surreal, but if you're a fan of Westerns the way they used to make them, you'll be mesmerised.
Less a movie and more a sustained panic attack, Sugarhouse is so unrelentingly violent, it's like being beaten with a housebrick for 90 minutes.
Frost/Nixon is absorbing and watchable but, like the earlier film, still feels like a TV movie with delusions of grandeur.
Go along not just to see an actor at the top of his game, but to witness an uplifting, inspiring true story.
Packed with wry humour, decent performances and with a deep understanding of what makes our relatives so wonderful and exasperating at the same time.
The film wrings the last drops from the franchise, with that Romeo and Juliet - or that should that be Romero and Juliet? - plot twist making for a flick likely to delight horror fans.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is hardly a horror classic because it takes so damn long for anything to happen. And when it does, the ideas aren't built upon, leaving you with the feeling the script is two or three rewrites away from a final draft.
Jean-Claude Van Damme escapes the pound-bin for a clever action-hero satire.
No gimmick in the world can save this froth.
In all, it's not as stupid as most teen films, but is still only likely to be enjoyed by 17-year-olds who haven't seen Juno.
Tokyo Sonata is a subtle and multi-layered affair that aims its guns at globalisation, the Iraq war and social alienation. But, boy, does it take a long time to make its not-so-astonishing point.
The punishment doesn't end there, with anyone who hands over good money to watch this dreck also likely to feel the pain.
With a plethora of incredible stunts and gunfights, plus the inevitable Mexican stand-off, it all adds up to a fistful of fun.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An all-star cast breathes life into a so-so romantic drama that, aimed squarely at unlucky-in-love women, stands up admirably alongside flicks such as Sex And The City.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A sun-speckled slice of froth that's very watchable, although it reveals little new about the mysteries of the human heart. It may be Allen's best film in years - just don't expect Annie Hall.

The animation isn't up there with Pixar's finest but still looks great, while the story is engaging enough for kids and adults alike. In short, it's the puppy's privates - and do try to catch it in 3D if you possibly can.
It's as if someone's taken the American Dream, lashed it to a table and cut it open to see how it works. An uncomfortable process, to be sure, but an awfully compelling one, too.

Uninspired by a true story, the first 20 minutes before the collision are entertaining but, after metal hits flesh, you can almost hear the premise creaking as it's stretched to feature length, resulting in some of the dullest moments I can remember.
I have the uneasy feeling I may be the only critic on planet Earth who isn't going to be sprinkling stars over Slumdog like confetti, but I bet you 1m we'll see better this year.

It's as crude, tasteless and offensive as all the above suggests, although it comes with a smattering of medium-sized laughs, making it a trip just about worth taking if you're a hormone-pumped adolescent.
It doesn't disappoint -- just don't expect the brilliance of Casino Royale.
Ghost Town really is one of those movies that reminds you just how life-affirming a night at the cinema can be.
It's only Williams who gives the film any life but, in the face of these odds, even she's helpless to save it from a one-star rating.
The message, I guess, is that incarceration dehumanises both prisoner and guards alike. Here it also serves to exasperate audiences.
Illuminating, heartfelt and often very, very funny, here's hoping we don't have to wait so long for his next movie.
Like many Christmases, the whole thing leaves you stressed, exasperated and longing to leave for home.
An Albanian immigrant is forced into an impossible dilemma in a bleak Belgian drama relieved only by a strong performance from its leading lady. Everything else is pretty soul crushing.
A send-up of Hollywood and its stars, this is the best film industry satire since The Player. Funnier, too.
Add to that some unimpressive CGI and a bizarrely abrupt ending and you have the day your buttocks went to sleep, your brain melted and your will to live evaporated.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The word offbeat doesnt quite cover it and its a touchslow to begin with but, really, if you dont fancy having your soul crushed byKeanu and co, do check this one out. Funny, warm and sensitive,its got gem written all over it.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Filled with the prerequisites of talking animals, an appealing young heroine and some heinous villains, all the ingredients are there, although an overly complex plot makes for an altogether middling experience.

It's a neat microcosm of the conflict, although a touch manipulative with the sympathies lying a little too heavily on the side of the Palestinians, with Salma a stoic, saintly presence and her neighbour merely an arrogant bully.
Imaginative it ain't but, in all, it's an agreeably girly accompaniment to a box of Maltesers. You might also want to take along some earplugs.
A solid film that rouses simply because the story is so incredible, while Bond star Craig is a charismatic presence throughout.
While better than it should be, if you listen hard enough you can actually hear a barrel being scraped between the gags.
It's a slow-moving affair with wooden acting, duff special effects and some woefully unfunny comic moments from Tim Curry as an undersized chef. All in all, the thing's severely lacking in magic.
An engagingly noisy documentary about the middle-aged members of a failed Canadian heavy metal band.
This terrifically tuneful movie offers a fascinating taste of musical history, with Beyonce just fine as Etta James.
This second part of the Che saga is beautifully presented but annoyingly rambling at times.
Prepare to be floored yourself as the retired boxer delivers an emotionally devastating and nakedly honest confession about his life, times and crimes.
It's a passable, if overlong, piece of fluff. But you'll have completely forgotten about it less than an hour later.
The voice cast has been well chosen, with everyone delivering their lines with just the right mix of satire and seriousness. It all makes for a horrifyingly humorous hour-and-a-half.
It's not an exploration, it's a smart-arse going into situations just to confirm his own prejudices.
Riding Giants covered much of the same ground in 2004 - and did it better.
The subjects of Iannucci's ire aren't exactly hard targets while the movie has so much fun shooting those barrel-bound fish, it forgets to bring anything terribly revealing to the table.
A buddy movie and a gross-out comedy rolled into one, it's an enjoyable and clever flick, even if it arouses more gentle titters than full-on belly laughs.

With its sermonising about the importance of being strong in the face of marital adversity - not to mention a sappy voiceover on the nature of suffering - the film feels more like a lecture than a drama.
The point is how does a "good" man get seduced by evil? Thing is, the movie's so muted and keeps viewers at such arm's length, you cease to wonder.
It's a hyperactive, relentlessly violent and po-faced mean S.O.B. - and I guarantee you'll 3/4 every minute.
17 Again is meant to be a comedy but remains mostly mirth-free.
Solid but uneven, it's made watchable by the leading man's performance.
There are decent special effects, and Johnson can play it tough while also being a kid-friendly presence.
As far as car chase movies go, it's right on the money with great action scenes, terrible dialogue and some seriously sub-par acting.
Faced with the choice of watching Dragonball: Evolution again and perishing in a fiery apocalypse, I'd take Judgment Day every time.
A moving, thoughtful and complex look at the nature of lovesickness, our star gives the performance of his life.

All in all, the Coens do what they do best - not just by giving us a movie a million miles away from No Country, but by laying to rest the ghosts of The Ladykillers et al with their first genuinely funny comedy in 10 years.
Tense, intelligent and quite moving, it's a meaty thriller filled with characters painted in refreshingly complex shades of grey.
This enjoyable but uneven biopic is a TV movie with ideas above its station.
This rival to the other chick flick of the moment, He's Just Not That Into You, is a fabulously frothy and fun fashion film.
Gran Torino features a grand performance by one of the greatest ever movie stars - it's as if Dirty Harry had never been away...
I'm pretty sure this is his best effort in years.
Groundbreaking cinema it ain't, with the story unfolding exactly as you'd expect. But fans of the corn director Frank Capra used to cook will find it a dish to savour.

Franklyn is an ambitious sci-fi film that squeezes every penny from its 6m budget and throws it onto the screen to create a terrific futuristic cityscape. Kudos for that, yet no amount of good looks can hide the fact it's almost unwatchable.
Paranoia abounds in this slick but stodgy drama recalling the conspiracy thrillers so beloved of 1970s cinemagoers.
Less spine-chilling and more eye-drooping.
Raw, challenging and, refreshingly, with no cheesy ending, this is a classroom drama Hollywood could never have made.

What makes American Teen so compelling is the way the four are presented. At first they seem like stock stereotypes, but over the course of the movie, we gain a powerful insight into what makes them tick.
The film's so stodgy that you quickly lose any interest in the National Socialist-baiting pair, making a long film seem much, much longer.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The horror dial's turned down to mute in a British fright flick about a dead rock star haunting a recording studio. While there's the germ of a good idea here, the execution is just terrible.
Sorry to say it, but you can't help wishing Lynch - daughter of esteemed director David - had extended her 16-year wilderness period, because Surveillance simply sucks.
The unfilmable has become the unlovable.
Yet another queasy entry into the ever-growing Queensploitation genre.

I've discovered a set of letters predicting when a catastrophically bad film is about to occur. They are NICOLASCAGE and, once again, the man who's given us more turkeys than Christmas is party to another shocker.
Flitting back and forth in time, it's too confusing to entertain, while Wood and Thurman look nothing like one another, making for a disjointed and often dire experience.
State Of Play's portrayal of the fine art of hackery gets it just right which, welded to a cracking storyline, makes for a first-rate movie.
Anyone over the age of 12 will need ProPlus to avoid the same fate.
This lame supernatural horror screams straight-to-DVD, with little in the way of scares, but yawns aplenty.
Also featuring a small turn from Matt Damon, it's a piecemeal, muddled affair that, were it not for that big name at the top of the credits, might never have been made at all.
Quality actors Joaquin Phoenix, Mark Wahlberg and Robert Duvall do their best to breathe life into a deeply average cop thriller/family drama.
The animation is fine, the plot accessible enough for youngsters and it clocks in at a snappy hour and a half.

Kicking off as a traditional 2-D animation before transforming into live animation when we hit the Big Apple, the film's title doesn't quite describe the film's likely effect on adults, but girls aged six-12 are sure to love it.
Trying with all its might to be endearing, the magic is simply missing. Hoffman is unbelievably annoying as the lisping Willy Wonka wannabe, while Portman looks uninterested.

I Am Legend feels like a work in progress, the sort of movie you can bet will get the director's cut treatment when it's released on DVD. In the meantime, we have a film that doesn't make sense and boasts dire special effects.
While quite possibly the stupidest thing you've ever seen in your life, this documentary exploring the world of air guitar enthusiasts is a riot from start to finish.
The third of the film given to the boys' childhood adventures is excellent, both kids fully convincing as pals who'll never part.
Dreary with a capital D.
Unfortunately, the scenes between the sex and violence, while beautiful, will test your patience.
The film itself may be uneven, but it's worth catching for Hoffman alone who gets to deliver some of the funniest lines to grace a movie in years.
About as riotous as gassing yourself during a wet weekend in Worksop.
Hoffman's reliably superb while Albert Finney, as the lads' father, is as good as he's ever been.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Light-hearted but no comedy, dark but not depressing, a Cockney caper that's never close to larky, it's a back-to-basics Brit flick that tells a good story with a minimum of pretension.
It's a hodge-podge of Enter The Dragon and Blades Of Glory, yet infinitely worse than either. In short, a film about bouncing balls with the bounce of an anvil.
Thoughtful without being particularly thought-provoking, heartfelt but not always emotionally engaging, it gets my thumbs up due to some beautiful, haunting shots of America at its wildest.

After Rendition, The Kingdom and Babel skirted around the issue, here, at last, is a film brave enough to question the whys and wherefores of the War On Terror. As such, it's not just an absorbing movie, but an extremely brave one, too.
Insanely violent, ludicrously gory and probably as much fun as you'll have in a cinema this year.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Atonement is an awesome achievement - I urge you to see it as soon as you can.

You'll laugh a bit, but not much, while your interest in the storyline will hover between mild interest and vague indifference. Needless to say, all memories of this movie will evaporate on contact with daylight.
Fans of British geezer films would be better off checking out I.D. - this is best enjoyed after a night at the pub on DVD.
Sure, it's not going to break any box-office records, but this is a poignant, thoughtful film that deserves a wider audience than the handful likely to see it.
Death Proof is an out-and-out dud, a film so profoundly dull, so relentlessly misguided, so criminally self-indulgent you almost feel bad criticising it. It's like kicking a man on crutches.
Topical, worthy and well made, A Mighty Heart fumbles the ball due to a complete dearth of tension and a flat-as-a-pancake performance from Jolie.
Pronouncing Adam Sandler's latest comedy anything but a disaster of Chernobyl-sized proportions is beyond me.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Evening is a film about regrets that doesn't say an awful lot, but somehow holds your attention with the scenes between Redgrave and Streep sure to bring a tear to your eye - or at least your mum's.
Despite all that's going for it, you can't help thinking this movie could have been so much better.
As funny as losing a finger.
An extremely gory but never completely gripping horror.

There's some nicely written dialogue in this remake of a foreign movie, but it's all extremely unsatisfying thanks to a so-what? ending and the script's inability to make us warm to its two principal characters.
The Lookout drags itself into four star territory thanks to the startling turn from Gordon-Levitt - a name to, ahem, look out for.
A solid, engrossing affair intercut with footage from the time, including live coverage of that famous day in July 1969 when Armstrong and Aldrin first walked on the lunar surface.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If it wasn't for the presence of leading lady Jessica Alba, Good Luck Chuck would be lucky to get even a DVD release.
In keeping with the title, this Silence Of The Lambs wannabe contains not a trace of originality, but should appeal to those who like their thrillers with a side order of gore.

A big-name cast including Nicole Kidman, Jack Black and Jennifer Jason Leigh wrestles with a storyline containing industrial-sized quantities of misery and a plot that leaves too many loose ends hanging.

Semi-Pro is beyond resuscitation thanks to about three decent gags throughout. On the rollercoaster track that is now Ferrell's career, this is close to a new low. And after turkeys like Bewitched, that's saying quite something.
See The Dark Knight and you're guaranteed an exceptionally dark night at the cinema. You'll also see the finest superhero movie in years -- no joke.

With a budget of perhaps 100, half the movie involves people having their heads ripped off with the rest devoted to porn stars jiggling their plastic boobs before being shot in the head. Someone please shoot me, too.
In all, it's a magnificent ride and certainly one of the finest films of the year.
Anderson serves up an unashamedly guilty pleasure that hits every note, particularly when the racing starts.
When it works, The Foot Fist Way is among the most painfully funny comedies of the year. Alas, there's just as much here that doesn't quite hit home, making for a lot of dead air between the gags.
One for arthouse fans only.

While not without its charms, and aiming a well-placed dig at American voter apathy, the jokes don't work, Costner looks hungover for real and the corn count is way, way too high, particularly during Bud's big speech at the end.
A nasty, grubby, pointless little thriller that hardly warrants a single star.
Pacino looks half asleep throughout, no doubt concentrating solely on his cheque, while the script is a catalogue of clichés and contrivances.
Someone once said the only thing worse than nuclear war was Evelyn Waugh. Maybe they'd seen this.
While nice to look at, it's also a very tedious slice of magical realism lacking in tension, suspense and, indeed, magic.
The only fears this will invoke will be the realisation of an empty space in your pocket where eight quid used to be.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cheap and cheerless, it all resembles a supermarket own-brand version of similar but much superior fare such as A Bug's Life, making you wish for a plague of spiders to put them out of their - and our - misery.
A kind of Devil Wears Prada for blokes, the humour in this brilliantly funny media satire springs mostly from Sid's oafish manners and refusal to suck up to celebrities.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Every banality is trotted out right on cue, from the makeover montage to the awkward first date, to the usual hoary old moral about being true to yourself, making this one bunny due for the casserole pot.
The word formulaic doesn't quite cover it, but our two leads just about hold their heads above a tidal surge of sappy plotting, contrived dialogue and choppy editing.
Thought-provoking stuff.

There's lots of shooting, grenades exploding and things going bang and, even if the film gets bogged down by some needless religious mumbo-jumbo, the whole thing looks great in a grimy, Blade Runner kind of way.
But flashes of inspiration aside, Tropic Thunder just isn't that funny and looks like something that was more fun to make than to actually sit down and watch.
Mendes (best known as Will Smith's love interest in Hitch) is enjoyably poisonous, making Live! just about worth catching.

Making a film usually involves a script, a director and a budget. Miss Pettigrew, on the other hand, is so unbelievably frothy, it looks as if it was prepared using merely a bucket of warm water and some soap flakes.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of getting something special, you're left with the impression the last few dollars are being wrung from a franchise that should've been put to bed 25 years ago. Still, kids should enjoy it.
The central character may be a spin on Borat, and many of the jokes a touch familiar, but the whole package is so unbelievably silly, you'll find yourself laughing for at least half the running time.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Playful, offbeat and with a decidedly droll sense of humour, Hellboy II's a richly rewarding superhero film with moments of gleeful comedy that films like Get Smart can but dream of.

Imagine being locked in a car with Charles Manson, Idi Amin and Osama bin Laden. The worst road trip ever? Nope. That honour belongs to Martin Lawrence's latest so-called comedy, which parks itself neatly between the words appalling and god-awful.
Sweet, poignant and with an undercurrent of wickedly funny humour, it's not just a total joy but one of those rare films that can be savoured again and again.
A less than heavenly time is guaranteed for anyone who parts with their hard-earned to watch this formulaic period film.

The film's makers clearly aren't big on originality, taking an old concept, asset-stripping a bunch of better movies and hoping nobody would notice. Given the few people who are likely to pay to see Babylon A.D., they might just get their wish.
Clearly influenced by slashers such as The Texas Chain Saw Massacre and The Last House On The Left, there's a decent sense of claustrophobia in the first hour.
A middling movie that provides just enough laughs to keep you watching, the whole thing feels two or three rewrites short of completion.
Kingsley is likewise on form and hits home with some terrifically world-weary one liners, while director Jon Levine brings a refreshing inventiveness to the film.
The only reason to see a Nicolas Cage movie these days is to have a good laugh at his latest wig.
Not a comedy, more a medical affliction, Disaster Movie's symptoms include apathy, regret and eventual despair.
RocknRolla is two hours of more of the same, accompanied by the usual soundtrack of mockney accents and gunfire. Listen closely and you may also hear the sound of time being called.
Our movie of the week - which isn't saying much - arrives in the shape of this atmospheric slice of Americana about an arranged marriage deep in the heart of rural Minnesota.
Given its cast and source material - Elinor Lipman's highly-regarded novel - it all makes for a highly disappointing experience.
It's an A-grade cast all right, but there's no escaping that this is a B-movie.
Kids will need to be positively subnormal to enjoy a film this dreadful.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Almost flawless except for one thing -- it never connects emotionally.
Despite the glum subject, Coogan and Dench raise plenty of smiles as the unlikeliest of couples.
If nothing else, Robert Rodriguez's Grindhouse homage manages the herculean feat of making us feel sorry for Mel Gibson.
The stars lack sparkle, the story is rote and workmanlike and the action unexciting.
Not since Knocked Up have the horrible and the hilarious made for such winning bedfellows.
It's not just the ancient Roman city that gets burned to the ground here - careers are also convincingly incinerated by Paul WS Anderson's pitiful excuse for a historical disaster movie.
There are gunfights and car chases galore, but none of them are especially exciting since the film's characters are so lazily sketched.
It's warm, witty and wise.
The characters' faces have the expressiveness of shop mannequins and the scenery looks as if it was created by a low-end PC.
There won't be any awards but, for the first time, Arnie is actually acting here.
The first question you'll ask yourself while walking out of The Canyons is, "What were they thinking?" The second may be "Were they thinking at all?"
Music and mental illness collide in a comedy-drama that's weird but not always wonderful.
Not just a solidly enjoyable and exciting flick - with not one second of sag - it's also a strikingly beautiful piece of work.
Boasting spectacularly shoddy animation and gags that wouldn't amuse a dim-witted five-year-old, this is one to be thrown out with the junk mail.
Disney's solid fantasy earns extra points thanks to both a sinister turn from Angelina Jolie and an understanding that fairytales are meant to be scary.
Calling After Earth the worst film ever made may be overstating things, but it's a disaster zone of Chernobyl-esque proportions.
The film (cough) paints a compelling portrait of a true eccentric with a vast gulf between his dreams and his powers.
The problem? The stars -- both dancers, rather than actors -- struggle with bland dialogue. The drama comes too late and it's hard to care about the unconvincing pair.
It's an odd film but an entertaining one.
It goes from exciting to exhausting mighty quickly and the final act.
If you were to take dashes of Bourne and Bond, season with Mission: Impossible 4 and pour the lot into a mixer, the result would look a lot like this watchable but derivative spy movie.
This blackly comic character study set in the hotbed of New York's early-60s folk scene fails because there's zero character development.
Stallone looks like someone who chooses his next project with the aid of a blindfold and a dartboard.
It has an awesomely talented cast ill-served by a script that doesn't know whether it's a comedy or a drama. Still, it has its moments.
It's the sort of drab thriller you'll probably walk out of.
The film suffers from the same problems as last year's On The Road, namely an undue reverence towards its characters.
What might have been a guilty pleasure is anything but thanks to badly-staged action scenes and a script that resembles a tick-list of action-flick cliches.
The acting is uniformly shocking, the storyline a cliché and there's a dearth of laughs, always a problem when your film is billed as a comedy.
This family-friendly animation gets off to an amusing start but soon flies off into la-la land.
It's an odd mix of bawdy comedy and blatant heart-tugging -- you'll be cringeing one moment and sniffing the next.
Gordon-Levitt is on top form, as is Johansson as the type of girl who only takes her gum out to eat.
It's an exciting watch and even slicker than the first film.
It's a heart-warming tale simply told.
It all adds up to not just a document of the time but a blueprint for today's activists.
What we have here is a blockbuster with brains, and explicit references to the Normandy landings of the Second World War are both knowing and well done.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Not since Goodfellas has America's dark, criminal underbelly been explored with such verve.
The gags in this follow-up to 21 Jump Street are wildly hit and miss, but its sense of glorious self-referential goofiness proves to be infectious.
There's a palpable sense of dread instead of just the usual cheap boo! moments.
Eisenberg is in characteristically intense form, while Sarsgaard and Fanning are solid supports.
Although this is brought to us by the makers of Coraline and ParaNorman, the earlier films' knowing, child-aware sense of menace is nowhere to be seen.

Anton Corbijn's new thriller is perhaps the best so far to tackle the War on Terror, thanks to an ingeniously twisty, and deeply cynical, storyline plus a towering performance from Philip Seymour Hoffman ...
A simplistic, featherweight cornball.
[A] powerful and intriguing film.
Liam Neeson is a cynical gumshoe tasked with finding out who killed a kidnap victim in this enjoyably nasty thriller, adapted from Lawrence Block's book.
Police Academy 6: City Under Siege has long been regarded as the worst ever cop comedy. That questionable honour, however, is now under threat from this criminally unfunny satire.
Young adults impatient for the next instalment of The Hunger Games will find plenty to enjoy in this thriller based on the Lois Lowry novel.
An absurdly violent but humourless and surprisingly dull action thriller ...
This holiday is about as much fun as a wet weekend in Chernobyl.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly a very clever and always watchable whodunit.
The late, great Labour maverick is examined in an engrossing and affectionate documentary bound to be lapped up by audiences from across the political spectrum.
Oh for the days when a vampire had fetid breath, feasted on virgins and could turn into a bat to terrorise villagers from his castle.
A shapeless and aimless film is padded out by a trite coming-of-age plot involving Nathan Gamble as Sawyer.
The concept of this real time thriller is, of course, extremely silly, but it keeps you entertained.
Moretz is very much a star on the rise. Alas, there are bound to be potholes along the way -- and this dying teen tearjerker is one big enough to snap axles.
It's little surprise this is largely a terrifically enjoyable experience -- one that'll please both fanboys and the public at large.
French writer/director Luc Besson has created a cottage industry of female action heroines with big guns and small skirts.
Approaches the tragedy suffered by six families and turns it into a vanilla drama that, if weren't for the big-name cast, would look more at home as a Channel 5 matinée.
[An] uneventful and overlong drama.
You can practically feel dirt accumulating under your fingernails as this pleasingly unpleasant neo-noir unfolds.
Best described as a noble failure.
Boyhood is one of those extraordinary flicks that'll remind you just how life-affirming a trip to the cinema can be.
Fans of Once - or, indeed, anyone with a heart - will be swept away by the gentle, sweet-but-sad story.
Funny, big-hearted and - as you'd expect - a visual feast, this a family film in every sense and one to be lapped-up by both kids and grown-ups alike.
Deserves to be scraped from the lawn, bagged up and dropped into the wheelie bin.
Even as a straight-to-DVD release, this would fail to pass muster.
A near-perfect mix of action, humour, imagination and wondrous special effects.
The lads plumb fresh depths but hit new comedy highs in this second TV-show spin-off.
For the first 10 minutes, director David Michod's down-and-dusty Outback drama looks like a winner. And then the wheels come off.
This week's talking-animal toon is bad enough to cause an allergic reaction in anyone above the age of five. Everyone else is advised to take along two peanuts, one for each ear.
The long silences and overdone symbolism make this feel like a hodgepodge of Mud, King of Summer and just about every other American indie film.

The acting is a washout, the dialogue thunderously bad and even Michael Fish could accurately forecast the ending - but when it comes to special effects, this eco-thriller whips-up one heck of a storm.
Despite having all the ingredients for an enjoyably glitzy piece of royal camp, it's formidably dull.
It's wider in scope than the first effort but just as funny.

The effects are exhilarating, even in these jaded post-3D days, and there are enough action set-pieces, humour and character development to distract from a plot that isn't exactly sci-fi's final frontier.
The film nails its 70s setting, but too much of the comedy is based on people falling over or shouting.
The lesson to be learned is that [Scorsese] should stick to what he knows best, for Hugo won't appeal to anyone, least of all kids.
[A] haunting, thought-provoking film that, while lacking Independence Day-style action, brims with atmosphere and intelligence.
[A] multi-stranded, over-earnest piece of schlock full of puddle-deep morality, product placement and zero laughs.
This is enjoyable fluff and the perfect antidote to long winter nights.
movie_title: The Well-Digger's Daughter (La fille du puisatier) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: As you'd expect with DreamWorks, the animation is smooth and the 3D impressive, particularly when Puss and his partners in crime ride a giant beanstalk up into the heavens.
Although the humour is patchy, when the laughs hit they hit hard, slyly sending-up holiday season conventions...
A comedy with fewer laughs than measles.
Aside from the in-laws threatening to stay until the New Year, one of the worst things about Christmas is a new Alvin And The Chipmunks movie.
If you're about to enter the world of The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo for the first time, this is a terrific place to start.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: M:I4 proves to be a sugar rush of pure, unadulterated entertainment. Even with a running time of two-plus hours, there's not an ounce of fat.
Streep may be a hot Oscar favourite but you need more than a star turn to make a good movie, and The Iron Lady isn't likely to please anyone in Britain.
War Horse is perfect material for the world's foremost purveyor of cinematic sentimentality. Think ET with hooves.
Our planet is ravaged by aliens in yet another sci-fi calamity so bad you'll be cheering on the invaders.
A scene where [Fassbender's] on the Tube checking out a woman, who just happens to be wearing a wedding ring, is chillingly clever.
Another flashily unorthodox update, although the story's not quite as riveting as last time.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A film approximately 48 times worse than the original.
The French are starting to have a monopoly on whimsical romantic comedies and, with this piece of amiable fluff, it's business as usual.
The themes of paranoia and isolation are the same as Carpenter's film, but the effects aren't a patch on the original.
John Hurt, wearing a Captain Caveman outfit, pops up here and there to give advice.
It's the worst Nicolas Cage film ever. Which is saying something.
British to its fingertips, from the cast to its terrifically droll sense of humour. Oh, and it's also pretty wonderful.
It's pretty much Withnail & I in a tropical climate, but far less fun.
It's not a costume drama in any real sense, with blusters of wind standing in for dialogue and, frankly, sheer boredom subbing for Brontë's look into the riddles of the human heart.
The film is full of familiar scenes of ghostly goings-on, which lead to an unshocking shock ending.
The plot trudges from A to B with zero surprises, while the excitement goes from the middling to the mind-numbing.
Appearances from TV soap favourites Martin Kemp, Gemma Atkinson and Billy Murray reinforce the suspicion that the film's real home is on the small screen.
movie_title: How To Stop Being A Loser (2011)

movie_review_blurb: However disquieting the film (based on the story of Australia's worst serial killer, John Bunting), it's also - inconveniently - awfully boring.
It's downbeat and has little to say about the grieving process, and while Gandolfini and Leo are memorable, Stewart is not.
The narrative is bogged down in detail, meaning Colin's infatuation arrives and departs too quickly and without much insight into his mental state.
