The mark of a truly great sports movie is one that appeals to people who don't like sports.
Required viewing.
The performances and themes of this psychological drama are all in five-star territory, it's just a shame all the good work is let down by a seriously drawn-out plot.
Crowbarred into the standard haunted house chills is a supposed twist that feels like Shutter Island written for drunk people.
It feels a little stagey, but this is the film Wall Street 2 should have been.
This isn't just the best action film since Bourne, it also exudes the sort of flair and cool of a 60s Bond movie. A class act.
Given that the man is among the most controversial figures of recent US history, making a film this tedious really takes some doing.
Apart from some nice period detail, Her Madgesty's second attempt to direct a film is an abysmal failure. The dialogue is wooden at best and the performances risible.
It dips into the style, excitement and vibrancy of the sport and recreates the 70s atmosphere with a real sense of the period outside the crash barriers.
The film could almost pass for an episode of Breaking Bad, but it's redeemed by its moody tone and Eve... who gives her best performance to date.
There's an over-reliance on Wiig's gift for ditzy, put-upon characters, although her charm wears thin, while the script veers between sit-com humour and pathos.
A deliciously dark and richly entertaining comedy drama, it's as enjoyable as anything this year.
Aside from the script's lightness of touch, it's the characters' small quirks and tics that bring the film to such vibrant life.
The plot is one-track, the cast minimal and the pace leisurely. But it's a real pleasure to experience space in a movie without an alien in sight.
Their fish-out-of-water antics leave a nasty taste in the mouth rather than a smile on the face.
Dyer has even less presence than usual.
A sad tale well told.
This is a film that can't shake off its theatrical roots and the pace too often lags.
The explicit segments are only half the story in this rewarding, beautifully-acted French film about the trials and tribulations of young love.
It's a slow-moving but lightly charming story that brings back memories of the delightful Julie Andrews classic movie.
This remake of the classic 1976 horror film can't match the original, but this is still a great Stephen King story about hormonal confusion and religious fervour.
A Christmas Disney animation with a cheeky wit, this musical adaptation of Hans Christian Andersen's The Snow Queen is thoroughly enjoyable.
Big, bloated and bound to take a billion at the box office - yes it's a Peter Jackson film.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Diana can only be described as a fabulously awful film.
Bad boy meets good girl, families get in the way and tragedy follows before the emotionally-contrived ending.

Given the critical spanking that greeted the last Wolverine film, you may be wondering what the steel-clawed superhero is doing back on the big screen. It's a question that isn't answered by James Mangold's X-Men spin-off.
Thrilling, great looking and with a refreshingly comical tone, this is everything a summer blockbuster should be.
[Jones] fulfils her promise as one of our most exciting talents in this wonderful little drama.
As is typical with Payne, awkwardness abounds leading to some moments of excruciating comedy.

While candidly exploring the hard lives of the characters and their families, the film earns an extra star from some inspired moments of magical realism, with one scene involving a child, a fire engine and a Bob Dylan tune that'll make your spine tingle.
Mesmerising.
Go see. Squirmingly funny.
Quite why Brian Taylor and Mark Neveldine, the directors of the brilliant Crank, got involved is anyone's guess. Perhaps their tax bills were also due.
Not funny, just creepy.
While there's little rom, with no discernible chemistry between Rudd and Aniston, Wanderlust scores better when it comes to com.
This grim offering isn't just terribly unfunny and mean spirited, it's also very boring.
Like the very best junkfood, Battleship has no nutritional value whatsoever but goes down easy. I just hope the film is meant to be a send-up.
Bleak, black and brilliant.
Enthralling, explosive and often very funny, Skyfall doesn't just exceed expectations but shatters them.
Directed by Bill Condon, who helmed the last instalment, the film's an adequate end to the story but not much else.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A bafflingly bonkers grand folly, it's weirdness on a grand but mostly unfathomable scale.
Much like his last film, Tron: Legacy, writer/director Joseph Kosinki has created a good-looking but unengaging experience.
Just as things get interesting, attempts at characterisation are shredded as Snyder unleashes the big guns for a finale ripped straight from the Michael Bay 'more-is-less' school of filmmaking.
The story tends to meander but the kids' ups and downs are delicately observed and the performances, especially from Roberts, are never less than believable.
[It looks] like a piece of unsubtle propaganda, no matter how much mud it's caked in.
The effect is less spine chilling and more eyebrow drooping.
Bradley Cooper and Sienna Miller dish up a thin stew of streaky ham and overcooked corn in this horribly predictable drama about a fiery-tempered chef's attempts to earn a third Michelin star.
It's not big and it's not clever, but this excess-all-areas dark comedy is, mostly, a guilty pleasure.
There's plenty here we have seen before... and seen done better.
Steven Spielberg teams up with Tom Hanks for an engaging spy-swap espionage thriller that, while set in the 1950s, has plenty of resonance today.
It's the film's intelligent and amusing exploration of family rifts and relationships between women that make it a genuine must-see.
When an actor starts using the words passion and project in the same sentence, you know it's time to run for the hills.
A noble failure.

Pleasingly, this isn't a film that takes itself too seriously, with the seriously cute BB-8 supplying plenty of humour with his electronic beeps and chirps and no end of playful references to the original trilogy crammed into the 135-minute running time.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It all makes for a ferocious but flawed film - but I'd certainly buy the video game.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Electrifying, enthralling and utterly essential, here's a drama that engages both head and heart with the best David versus Goliath story since Erin Brockovich.
While the clueless catwalk star is as enjoyably moronic as ever, the jokes aren't there.
Deadpool may not be the best superhero film ever made but, boy oh boy, is it the gutsiest.
A bracing, resolutely old-fashioned matinee movie enlivened by some sensational special effects.
Prepare to be entertained, shocked and offended in equal measure.
While the filmmaker's delightfully idiosyncratic touches are here, there and everywhere, they never quite gel with the storyline.
Mendelsohn is so watchable as a big-hearted but self-destructive loser, you can't take your eyes off the screen.
Forget the campiness of the past, 007 is the suited-and-booted menace originally envisioned by creator Ian Fleming.

While the special effects are as good as anything you'll see in a cinema this year, some of the performances are end-of-the-pier awful and the storyline's a crib sheet of at least half a dozen much better fantasy flicks.
The last M:I film, 2011's Ghost Protocol, remains the series' high point because it was so consistently engaging. This time, we spend much too long in government back rooms discussing politics.
A lean, mean action thriller let down only by a deeply predictable ending.
There's a great half-hour show rattling around in here somewhere, but the rest is padding at its very dullest.
The film's well-worn concept is re-energised with some ingenious plot swerves and a last-act shock right up there with Gone Girl.
An object lesson in how not to create a superhero origin story.
An entertaining and refreshingly old-fashioned adaptation of the espionage drama that ran from 1964 to '68 and made stars of Robert Vaughn and David McCallum.
All in all, it's as funny as a camping trip to Chernobyl with Charles Manson as your tent buddy.
This involving set-up soon gives way to tired gangster clichés, culminating in a crude and over-the- top bloodbath.
For fans only.
You can almost hear the gears crunching as this bizarre movie misstep careers from spy thriller to stoner comedy and back again.
Jaw-droppingly intense ...
The gags are as coarse as the subject matter, but generally very, very funny, and there's an extremely neat twist.
Aside from appearances, there's not much here to engage with.
Like the book upon which it's based, Robert Redford's latest is a film of small but continual pleasures - an amiable amble that's almost impossible to dislike.
Amid the humour, there's plenty of heart with the relationship between the two leads feeling totally real and the depiction of Milly's illness sensitively handled.
As Caesar probably never said: I came, I saw, I slept.
There's plenty here to intrigue and eventually terrify thanks to a script that keeps us guessing about what really has unfolded above ground.
This is an arch, icy film whose visuals more than once recall the tonal styles of Stanley Kubrick - but it's also a movie that seems to take pleasure in distancing itself from its audience.
No amount of crash, bang or wallop can conceal this confused and ungainly storyline.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: By definition, a romcom should be at least a touch romantic and amusing but this manages to be neither.
Like all good fairytales, the message is secondary to the mystery and the feelings of disquiet it so effortlessly stirs.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: When you go to watch a Roland Emmerich film you know what to expect and here the director of 2012, Godzilla and The Day After Tomorrow delivers perhaps the dearest B-movie ever made.
An amusing comedy drama featuring a striking turn from Michael Shannon as Presley, despite using a huge amount of artistic licence.

Provided you treat this as strictly disposable popcorn entertainment, there's plenty to enjoy here, particularly some terrific special effects. But a classic to be enjoyed time and again it most certainly is not.
It's ironic that a film about a forgetful fish should be so forgettable.
Greengrass (also the co-writer) has done what he does best, delivering two hours of pure, unadulterated excitement.
The songs are strong, the acting impressive and the finale defiantly feelgood.
Suicide Squad continues with more of a whimper than a bang, lurching from one so-so set piece to another with the occasional token gesture towards character development.
Funny, heartwarming and glorious to look at, it's as if the technology has finally caught up with the story.
Efron is reliably amusing, but the gags (most of them very, very rude) miss as much as they hit.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mix magic and monsters with Muggles and the result is the movie we've all been waiting for since Harry Potter hung up his wand.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Once again, Captain America delivers a delightful surprise and jostles with the first Iron Man film for the title of the best Marvel movie ever.

In between all the crash bang and wallop, there are also some truly odious villains, with Vader as sinister as he's ever been and Australia's Ben Mendelsohn clearly relishing his role as the human-cyborg's psychotic chief enforcer.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Slick, smart and audacious, it's a film that anyone in their twenties who owns a Nintendo will be queuing around the block to see.
McCarthy gives a terrific performance in a film that, even charitably, can only be described as so-so.
You may find yourself pummelled into exhaustion by this rote rise-and-fall melodrama.
The best superhero flick of the past few months, delivering a ninja-kick to the recent adventures of Superman, Batman and Captain America.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While this is strictly for kids, it's bright, bold and soon, er, flies by.
Here's a great-looking, emotionally engaging and enormously entertaining movie guaranteed to delight kids and adults alike.
As comedy sequels go, this proves to be as amusing as getting a lump of moussaka stuck in your throat.
Here's a hero impossible to dislike with Egerton delivering a memorable turn. All in all, the movie walks off with a respectable bronze.
With largely improvised dialogue, thumping techno score and pulsing under-current of danger, this is rough-and-ready, rough-and tumble stuff that belies its amazing technical artistry.
This fright of a fairytale could put the makers of Nytol out of business.
Sci-fi, superstition and deep daftness collide in a high-minded but exasperating drama that feels three times longer than its already hefty running time.
This film shouts its message loud and clear, but it's still a nail-biter exploring a thoroughly topical subject - and Mirren and Rickman are terrific.
Not just confusing, predictable and mis-sold as a feminist film, the calamity that is Jane Got A Gun is hobbled by the dullest of plots.
Wading through cliches and unlikely plot twists, Elba's physicality and sheer screen presence cement his status as one of our most exciting talents.
This adaptation of Charles M Schulz's much-loved comic strip will similarly delight little ones, although it proves much too bland to entertain the over-10s.
One of Marvel's rare missteps, lacking the joy, excitement and sense of anything being possible that's always been the studio's hallmark.
The trouble isn't that we're meant to feel sorry for a listless investment banker, it's his road to salvation that's so deeply unconvincing.
Wobbly, uneven and dodgy, the best thing about this film is Zac Efron . And that's a sentence I never thought I'd write.
It takes some doing to turn a story about the man who sold millions of records before dying at just 29 into such a listless experience, but, against all odds, the makers have managed to do just that.
Sweet, honest and, most of all, richly enjoyable.
Director Shane Black may have surprised with The Long Kiss Goodnight (1996), Kiss Kiss Bang Bang (2005) and the first two Lethal Weapon movies, but his latest is a shadow of past glories.
It isn't the new Ocean's Eleven, but a sequence involving a sports car dangling from the side of a skyscraper is well done, while Stiller and Murphy raise a few laughs.
An animated masterpiece, one of those rare movies that will speak to kids and adults alike.
While boasting all the dazzling special effects we've come to expect from the Iron Man, Captain America and Thor series, this is Marvel in modest form - and small turns out to be beautiful.
Compelling, compulsive and excruciatingly funny, you can't take your eyes off the screen.
It's not a particularly interesting journey - although the scenery is terrific - and the movie's flow is constantly interrupted by some jarring flashbacks, with Laura Dern playing the hiker's mother.
Although the hectic genre-swapping action should keep you marginally entertained, you'll be able to guess precisely what's going to happen long before it actually does.
The only things likely to ascend during the Wachowskis' latest sci-fi soap opera will be your eyes, which may actually swivel in exasperation up and over, allowing you to see your own brain.
It doesn't scale the same heights of the studio's Wallace and Gromit movies but is guaranteed to delight the children.
Taylor-Johnson has made a film that is both sexy and stylish.

Eastwood is still making great films, with the 84-year-old's recent resumé including such historical treats as Changeling, Jersey Boys and Invictus. But, unfortunately, this isn't one of his finest moments.
A sense of dread envelopes every scene thanks to combination of Mitchell's slow, measured tracking shots and the stunning score from Disasterpeace.
The makers were aiming for a how-we-date-now rom-com. Instead, they've made a film that might have seemed hip 10 years back but now seems dated, cold and cynical.
While not without its charms, Marigold 2 is a pretty naked cash-in.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With Aniston on this form it's almost good enough to banish memories of The Bounty Hunter, Wanderlust and even Just Go With It.
It all adds up to an entertaining first half hour or so before the plot begins in earnest and the fun factor starts to droop.
The dialogue is simplistic but the film is atmospheric and fitfully entertaining, thanks largely to the charms of Visser and Sharlto Copley, who plays Chappie via motion capture.
Unfinished Business may be the best Judd Apatow comedy that Judd Apatow never made.
There's lots of charm, from the looks Ben and George give one another, to the easiness of their shared company.
Much like his earlier directorial efforts, Gone Baby Gone and The Town, Affleck delivers a blockbuster with brains that's populated by nicely rounded characters.
12 Years A Slave is a powerful, moving and intelligently unsentimental tale that is engrossing and memorable.
The spare scenario may not sound inspiring, but Locke's attempts to keep his life from unraveling during a series of telephone calls make for a suspenseful and impressive experience.
Jake Gyllenhaal delivers on the promise he showed nine years ago in Ang Lee's Brokeback Mountain.
I confidently predict Timothy Spall will be lifting a Bafta, if not an Oscar, for his brilliant performance as 19th-century painter JMW Turner in this affecting biopic.
It might make economic sense for Lionsgate Pictures to carve the novel in two but it means this movie is all built-up with a distinct lack of excitement.
It's more a case of dude, where are the laughs as the hit British comedy series returns for a third, unwelcome installment.
What does it all mean? Not very much, I suspect, with the cast sombrely delivering lines about trust and frailty while starring broodily into the middle distance.
Paddington isn't just the film of the year, it might actually be one of the finest family films ever made.
Calling it unfunny doesn't quite do it. It's as if the writers set out to make a movie to actively offend anyone with a sense of humour.
Any movie about one of sport's most intriguing and heroic characters is never going to be dull.
Sparks fail to fly in an original but meandering and uninvolving drama, starring Agyness Deyn as a young woman prone to increasingly dangerous epileptic fits.
The third and final instalment in the all-conquering series has got everything -- an engrossing story, a near-overdose of thrills and spills, and a cast of uniquely memorable characters.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A self-indulgent and generally tedious luvvie comedy where smug has been substituted for smart. It's a bit like those mediocre films pumped out by Woody Allen in the 90s.

Like most of Anderson's films -- and Gustave himself -- the film is rather pleased with itself, but its exuberant humour and pacy plot keep it accessible while Fiennes delivers his funniest role ever.
It's a well told but somewhat unexciting and placid little movie that, despite the star wattage, you'd expect to catch on a Sunday afternoon on BBC2.
This is an intelligent and classy film, part sci-fi, part horror and part thriller that shows just how good an actress Johansson can be when given the chance.
It looks and feels like utter cornball but the sheer commitment of the stars makes the whole thing deeply watchable.
Never once veering into heavy-handed sentimentality, it's a film to break your heart.
Shailene Woodley stars in a mystery thriller/coming-of-age drama that earns its third star from a kicker of a twist ending.
It's dull enough to make you yawn but too loud to let you fall asleep.
Take the story of a young maths prodigy, add three notable performances, subtract any of the by-the-numbers mawkishness you might expect, and the result is X+Y, a small gem of a Brit flick.
It's a hilarious, couldn't-make-it-up journey into one of film's strangest chapters.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [A] by-the-numbers thriller.
The finale is even more visually stunning and comes with a neat twist you probably won't see coming.
As a slice of slick male wish fulfilment, bow-wrapped with a G-string and served with an extra helping of hedonism, it's everything fans of the show could've hoped for.
Despite dealing with weighty themes such as ageing, death and the gap between Holmes' public and private personas, there's plenty of delightful humour to enjoy.
There are references to Leon, Kill Bill and Se7en, plus a whole lot of Japanese men in sharp suits -- leading to a distinct whiff of déjà Woo.
It may be a documentary but Going Clear is as incredible as anything Hollywood could dream up.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The shadow of Woody Allen looms large over this frothy ensemble comedy, but not in a good way.
Bright, breezy and brought to life with some impressive 3D, make no mistake, Minions is going to be one of the biggest hits of the year.
The story never veers far from the standard road trip template but, like they say, it's not what you've got, it's what you do with it.
It's a film that takes an awfully long time to say not very much but, boy, is it beautifully shot.
If 2010's Kick-Ass was a one-two sucker punch of glorious goofiness, the follow-up is a more thoughtful superhero send-up.
Given the brilliance of its forebear, you can't help wishing for something better. By cutting out a good 20 minutes, it would have been twice as funny.
Murder, mayhem and madness are unleashed in this absurdly enjoyable spy caper that David Niven or perhaps Patrick Macnee might have made in the 1960s.
It's as if Disney has taken some very traditional ingredients and blended them to come up with a new flavour entirely.
I confidently predict this will be the funniest film of 2015.
It's well acted, nicely plotted and solidly entertaining until the wheels fall off in the last half hour.
The upbeat message, of not letting go of dreams and facing a bright future with confidence, is hardly original for a kids' flick, but it's certainly unusual for a sci-fi movie.
The humour is razor-sharp and the spirit of goodwill that infused the first film is alive and well while Rebel Wilson, as the group's plump heroine, is as funny as ever.
Much like the last film, the dialogue and the action suffer from a keen sense of lifelessness.
The film's real fault is its 'hero', a glum, sour-faced sociopath who it's almost impossible to root for.

The story is as enchanting as ever, the handsome cast doesn't miss a beat, while the costumes and set design are wonders to behold. But the movie's sheer flawlessness turns out to be a flaw in itself.
[An] occasionally hilarious and constantly filthy comedy featuring more penis references than a PhD in human biology.
What's missing is any sense of excitement.
If you gave a 15-year-old boy $250million and told him to go away and make a movie, the result would probably look like this.
It's a lean, mean and extremely violent B-movie that's already being confirmed as the first part of a franchise in the making.
It's a surgical strike against US foreign adventurism and a devastating take-down of its "warheads-on-foreheads" policy, as well as a very moving a study of a soul in torment.
Flush this one away.
It's a gentle and warm-hearted film, and its biggest strength is its pithy examination of how us Brits are regarded by our European cousins.
The fact that this film prompts not a sob but a shrug is a tragedy all of its own.
A gimmick is stretched beyond breaking point in an initially clever but ultimately exhausting horror film.
Loud, daft and explosive, it's a B-movie right down to its fingertips.
Ironically, this romantic drama about a woman who can't grow old creaks along like a centenarian with chronic arthritis.
Noisy, explosive and visually spectacular but depressingly hollow.
The story of these two make-it-up-as-you-go-along chancers is as fascinating as it is unbelievable.
A catalogue of constant clichés which never let up, while Butler's lack of acting chops succeeds in sinking every scene.
The plot, setting and supposed twists are all mightily familiar but it's worth a punt due to Tom Hardy and the late James Gandolfini.
Hoffman's directing debut delivers a film so weak I could barely remember what it was about as I left the cinema.
Comes with horribly uneven performances and vastly unappealing characters acting in ways nobody ever, ever would.
Hilary Swank and Sam Rockwell certainly throw themselves into in this true-life crime drama. But Conviction wouldn't look out of place as a Channel 5 matinée and sits uneasily on the big screen.

Slick, sly and ever-soslightly subversive, The Green Hornet is an irreverent comedy bound to annoy comic-book purists - usually a good sign - and sure to delight everyone else. Think this year's Kick-Ass.
While the film is near-perfect, it's a tribute to Portman that she outshines everyone else as the frail, brittle ballerina who is slowly but surely losing it.

With Duvall's performance, a fastpaced script and a Big Speech near the end, this is practically a love letter to the Oscars, although its melancholic tone and hit-and-miss humour make for a middling affair.
Clearly director Ron Howard (Cocoon, Frost/ Nixon) was striving to make a black comedy drama, but instead has created a film that's merely cynical and depressing.
Not since John Cassavetes' startling Faces has there been a more fearless examination of a troubled relationship than this searing drama.
A film that ambles along agreeably and features fine performances from co-stars Diane Keaton and Rachel McAdams.
The sexual violence caused the British Board Of Film Classification to demand 43 seconds of cuts. A shame they didn't cut the rest.
While it's not up there with Carpenter's greatest, there are jolts enough.
With a spring in its step and a song in its heart, Tangled is undoubtedly one of Disney's most uproariously enjoyable movies in years.
If there existed an award for pointless, dreary and depressing movies, Biutiful would sweep the board.
Well, I guess the winning streak had to end sometime.
It's got a starry, up-for-it cast and an epic, decade-spanning storyline. Crucially, it's also worthy but a bit dull.
A slathering, rabid beast of a movie, Neds is a hellish trip through 70s Glasgow as seen through the eyes of a teenage ne'er-do-well.
With the hunt for natural gas likely to be heading to Britain, it's a topical film, although the point could have been made in less time.
While the supporting cast of James Caan and Vera Farmiga are in top form, the leading man looks like he's dosed up on Valium.
A slow-burning but satisfying comedy that goes for gentle humour rather than belly laughs.
While providing a fascinating insight into one of history's bloodiest reigns, what shines through is Sambath's ability to bury any vengeance in favour of journalistic impartiality.
While gunning for the same empowering vibe as Waiting To Exhale, enduring this miserable effort from Tyler Perry is more like praying to expire.
This sci-fi actioner is insufferably dismal, depressing and dull. The story is inscrutable and viewer-alienating. The special effects are unimpressive and the 3D underused.
Quite possibly the most boring film of 2010.
An unsettling, unconventional and delicately-handled piece quite unlike anything our film industry is pumping out these days.
A comedy without laughs centred around the most excruciatingly annoying 'hero' ever to grace a cinema screen.
There hasn't been a movie this fabulously awful since Showgirls.
Is it real? When a film's this good, that becomes secondary.
Little Fockers is a film light on plot, bereft of laughs and featuring a cast who look as if they want to kill themselves.
Like a health warning on a packet of cigarettes, the words Jack Black on a movie poster have become synonymous with life-threatening unfunniness.
A movie of utter, unspeakable, hideous awfulness. A movie that makes you want to prise open your brain and scoop out all memory of having watched it.
It all adds up to a very special film with a near-perfect mix of pathos, humour and well-observed period detail.

It'll come as little surprise to anyone who follows Cage's career that he's picked yet another dud. Yes, after Knowing, Bangkok Dangerous, G-Force and Next, the follically-challenged actor has done it again.
Continuing the unlikeliest of career renaissances that began with 2008's Milk, James Franco steps up to the plate yet again in this electrifying true story...
This boy doesn't need therapy or happy pills but a large slap round the chops.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the best efforts of all involved, trying to prise laughs out of How Do You Know is like trying to make concrete float.
If you've ever seen a spy thriller, you'll know where it's all heading, with the final twist particularly unsurprising.
Bale, looking rail-thin and wideeyed, has the Oscar nomination and Golden Globe win, but it's Wahlberg who's the more memorable in a less showy role.
Rabbit Hole doesn't entertain, inform or even stir the emotions.
It's a Hammer horror all right, but not in a good way.
Unfunny and unpleasant, it's hard to believe these are the people who once made There's Something About Mary.
The movie's message is that by working together, us humans can overcome. A shame the film's makers were not so blessed.
Capitalism has never looked such a cruel mistress and it's refreshing to see the recession's fallout portrayed in such human terms.
An angrier film you're unlikely to see all year.
Sadly, there's little to like here with the comedy plain unfunny and the violence jarring with the satirical tone.
Rango is clever and entertaining. Not for the very young perhaps, but ideal for teens and adults.
Thought provoking and with New York brought to life flash intellige by flashy camerawork, Limitless is cool, funny and intelligent.
This is no Manhattan or Annie Hall, and while it's true Woody Allen isn't as good as he used to be, neither is anyone else.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Not since The Catcher In The Rye has there been such an acutely observed tragi-comedy about the horrors of being a teenager.
It's no surprise Michael Connelly's devilishly clever 2005 novel makes for a devilishly clever film, full of unpredictable twists and turns, and some memorable one-liners.

Take Braveheart, Gladiator and Apocalypto, leave them to simmer in an iron-age pot and you've got The Eagle, a sword-swooshing slice of historical action that's plenty entertaining, if a touch familiar.
Packed with car chases and shoot outs, this isn't subtle, but there are some unexpected twists and surprisingly well-rounded characters, particularly Thornton's detective.
Some killer tunes plus a genuinely believable turn from Glee star Paltrow make Country Strong a show worth catching.
Bearing more than a passing resemblance to Slumdog Millionaire, it's every bit as heartwarming.
This is fun for an hour before plumbing hitherto unknown depths of silliness.
Featuring interviews with the man himself, his enemies and one of the hookers, this isn't just a fascinating yarn but a, cough, penetrating character study.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A game cast including Helen Mirren, Russell Brand, Ben Whishaw and Tom Conti can't save this listing interpretation of the Shakespeare play.
Like rerecording Sgt Pepper or rewriting Hamlet, this second adaptation of the Graham Greene novel feels mostly redundant.
What's to like? Not much.
Ferguson takes a scalpel to the banking industry and peels away the layers to reveal the rot inside. Essential viewing.
An enjoyable fantasy romp that conjures up the same sort of magic that comes from Hogwarts.
If you're over 15 and semi-intelligent, you'll want your money back.
Anyone with a funnybone should avoid what will surely be the worst film of 2011. Until the next Martin Lawrence movie, that is.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You'll need caffeine on an IV drip to survive it.
If you have less fun in a cinema all year, I'd like to know.
Ungodly.
What the hell is going on with James Franco? The erstwhile Spider-Man star is rapidly turning into cinema's Renaissance man.
A ferocious, uncompromising drama that feels like a shot of gin before breakfast.
A Revolutionary Road-style sequel exploring the couple's woes five years down the line might be interesting and give Portman a chance to shine. Perhaps they could hire an actor for Kutcher's part.
It amounts to an amiable enough way to kill a couple of hours, but that's about it.

He sure isn't the obvious choice to play King John, but US-born Sideways star Paul Giamatti pulls it off in this bleak and bloody drama examining the terrible vengeance he visited on his enemies post-Magna Carta.
Now here's a curio - a film that flits between Wales and Argentina and features a small turn from songstress Duffy. And it's a complete gem.
If the 3D is passable and there are some moments of tension, Sanctum has big problems.
A smug, selfpitying sleepwalk through celebrity culture, it might make her Hollywood pals smirk, but it will likely make you snore.
It's poignant, well acted and occasionally funny, but a little formulaic, too.
movie_title: The Be All and End All (2009)

movie_review_blurb: With its linear structure, nostalgic glow and distinct lack of surprises, Secretariat seems to have wandered into cinemas after leaving its TV movie hitching post.
It all adds to the growing suspicion that Mark and Jay are two of the most exciting filmmakers working today.
After a string of largely mirth-free months at the multiplex, this might well be a late entry as one of the comedies of the summer.
It's a heck of a lot better than director Nick Moran's last movie (Joe Meek biopic Telstar), but could have done with tighter storytelling and better casting.
Movies don't come much duller than this.
It might not be the blandest rom-com youve ever seen, but its sure within striking distance.
It's good to see Williams trying something darker than usual, but it's a pity the whimsy is laid on so thick.
While it mostly avoids rom-com clichés and is grown-up enough to deal with sex frankly, it's also deeply vanilla and is saved only by an obvious spark between the two leads.
While I'm not sure quite what the film's trying to say, I'm sure it's a cinematic landmark.
With believable characters, a real sense of terror and that terrific whatwould-you-do? plot, Frozen works on every level. A proper chiller.

Ok, so originality isn't The Town's strong suit and a few crime drama clichés are ticked off as we hurtle towards the finale. But when a film is this tense and this well acted, it's possible to overlook them.
It's a film containing few surprises and plenty of clichés but, nonetheless, is an entertaining way to fill a couple of hours.
There's nothing particularly wrong with Takers, but very little that's right.
You don't have to be claustrophobic to find the entire enterprise thoroughly upsetting.
Jackie Chan came up with this story of a peasant capturing a highranking general some 20 years ago, but it's taken all this time for the project to be realised. Boy was it worth the wait.
movie_title: Little Big Soldier (Da bing xiao jiang) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A movie of picture postcard landscapes and ridiculously hunky blokes, this is very much cinematic comfort food where the answers to life's problems come a little too neatly gift-wrapped.
Dead on arrival.
As far as music biopics go this is conventional fare, while the songs - like the fashions - haven't aged well. But with both women giving their all, you can't fault the enthusiasm.
Based on a comic strip and directed by Stephen Frears, it's another impossibly smug British drama populated by middle-class stereotypes swanning around the countryside.
While there's no real reason for this retread of Sam Peckinpah's controversial 1971 film, even Hollywood can't destroy such a decent story.
A very gory but equally funny guilty pleasure with a keen sense of its own ridiculousness.
I spy a turkey.

Rapace is suitably intense, making her character one of the finest female action heroes in modern cinema. Damaged, prickly, but able to outsmart all the men who cross her path, she's an icon for our age.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Made for a mere $75,000, the film's a wry portrait of an American out of his environment and out of his depth...
Jennifer Aniston finally hits paydirt with a cleverly written rom-com about a broody single woman who turns to the turkey baster.
Frankly, if this makes you laugh even once, I recommend seeking medical advice.
With a plot greased by spit, vomit and blood, it doesn't pack the same sucker-punch as the original but is never less than entertaining. Top dog.
Bright, pacy and often funny (despite an over-reliance on poop jokes), Diary Of A Wimpy Kid never patronises children and should be a hit with pre-teen boys.
Offers little but secondhand platitudes on the dehumanising effects of violence while proving that the generation gap is as wide as ever.
While a touch lean on the laughs, there's just about enough humour to make it worth catching...
Draws on The Blair Witch Project and The Exorcist to supremely creepy effect.
Go to see it and you may ask yourself why did I bother?
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A stylish but desperately uneven French thriller that's clearly trying to be the next Godfather. Alas, it never comes close.
Having already bombed big-time in the US, our search for the biggest turkey of 2010 ends right here.
Money never sleeps, but you might.
It's all deeply silly, but agreeably so with some smart one-liners, tongue-incheek humour and nobody taking themselves too seriously.
Directed by Bernard Rose, it's a cleverly assembled character study with a decent turn from Ifans, a seatof-your-pants plot and some nicely observed period detail.

What might have been a poignant exploration of the effects of bereavement is hamstrung by rotten twists, redundant action scenes and a few too many publicist-approved shots of Efron staring wistfully into the sunset.
Joining the rank ranks of The Hottie And The Nottie, Gigli, Licence To Wed and any film where Matthew McConaughey gets his groove on with a girl is yet another unspeakably awful rom-com.
While it's to be commended for including so much nudity in these prudish times, what a pity more attention wasn't paid to the plot that feels, ahem, threadbare.
A cut-and-paste monster mash with no business whatever in a multiplex. Heck, if you tuned into this on cable on a Sunday night, you'd be cancelling your subscription.
On the evidence of this, his penultimate film, the teenage wizard is getting the send-off he deserves.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An animation for jazz lovers that's every bit as good looking as it is tuneful.
Does the film say anything new? No. And does the story transcend its gloomy premise with a taut narrative? Nope.
While its insistence of flitting between past and present begins to confuse, and the twist ending is trite rather than thoughtprovoking, Dream Home earns big points for its audacious slayings.
A compelling mix of 70s-style conspiracy thriller, courtroom procedural and psychological drama...
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As far as does-what-itsays-on-the-tin popcorn fodder goes, this is right on the money.

Brutal and with a plot that's all over the place, it seems we're taking early delivery of a Christmas turkey.
A loving homage to the B-movies that played in fleapit cinemas in the 70s, replete with oodles of violence, gore and gratuitous nudity.
Ferrell's voicework is spot on, Pitt gamely sends up his squeaky clean image and Fey is a joy as the conflicted heroine.
While Rare Exports is certainly spooky, the plot is too thin to engage while its gratuitous use of the F-word and full frontal male nudity make it a children's film unsuitable for children.
Edwards' neat spin on alien invasion sci-fi movies might just be the debut of the year.
There's nothing intrinsically wrong with message movies like this provided the characters feel real (they don't) and it's handled with a light touch (it isn't).

Originality isn't the film's strong suit and Sammy's adventures never come close to the escapades of Nemo, but the 3D certainly earns some points with the ocean brought to dazzling, spectacular, colourful life.
It's every bit as anarchic as the TV show and the last three movies with the guys egging each other on before collapsing in laughter at the results.
[Leigh's] insight is as keen as ever, resulting in his best film in years.
It's all strong stuff, and about as far removed from a traditional Hollywood all strong stuff, and as far removed additional Hollywood war movie as you can get.
If you thought things could only get better following Killers and The Ugly Truth, you're in for a nasty surprise.
It gets no better than this.
The animation is fine and crisp with some imaginative use of colour, while the 3D really brings the action to life.
It's not quite as bad as Friedberg and Seltzer's usual output, but only in the way that measles is better than mumps.
And the award for this year's dullest film goes to Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow, which also scoops 2010's special prize for navelscratching, absurdly dull uselessness.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One seriously scary movie containing at least five jolts that will lift you from your seat and/or make you fill your tighty whities.
No amount of jazzy cool can hide very large problems in the plot department.
Killer stuff.
This is the best high-school comedy since Mean Girls.
Here's a documentary that's amusing, affecting and life-affirming in equal measure.
What does it all mean? I have no idea, and I wonder if director/co-writer Ruben Östlund did either.
It should come as no surprise that the man who hasn't made a good film in 25 years has produced another dud.
A film with a split personality, it initially intrigues before eventually infuriating.
Only those without a funnybone will fail to be seduced by its sheer verve, wit and charm.
Although this merely reheats 95 per cent of the original, if you haven't seen that, then this is worth a bite.
Thoroughly unsettling from start to finish, Wake Wood will please horror fans with its muted palette, ominously creepy atmosphere and neat nods to the best of 70s British horror.
A more self-indulgent piece of movie-making is hard to imagine.
While it's brimming with righteous anger, it rarely connects emotionally.
The blend of animation and live-action isn't bad and the story moves at a reasonable crack that should just about keep the under-10s interested.

The young characters are played by, among others, Elle Fanning and Joel Courtney. They interact well, albeit in that rose-tinted view of childhood so favoured by Spielberg, who is on production duties here.
It's a powerful and upsetting film with a real tear-jerking finale.
It's not without its moments but all the imagination seems to have been expended on the title.
Despite some heartbreak in the last half, this film brims with humanity and some priceless humour, too.
The plot is hoary and eventually saccharine.
Superb.
Cooper gives a great performance, or rather two great performances, although it's really only Uday's depravity that keeps you glued to the screen.
You'd think a film so heavy on sorcery and swordfights couldn't go wrong, but Conan The Barbarian manages the twin feats of being both derivative and deathly dull.
A kids' flick that's big on eye candy but which has a plot even youngsters will find wearingly familiar.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's not big and it's not clever, but boy will it have you laughing.
Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess embark on the longest courtship in movie history in a weepy based on David Nicholls' gazillion-selling novel.
Last month, I reckoned Horrid Henry was a shoo-in for worst film of the year. Compared to Powder, however, it looks like The Battleship Potemkin.
Both unsettling and provocative without an over-reliance on blood and guts.
Works, and works well, thanks to some terrific droll humour and the best 3D to hit cinemas all year.
Carrey can single-handedly kill a good comedy with his OTT shtick, but this time he reins it in and the film is all the better for it.
This is one smart film from someone with a singular voice who knows their craft.
Films like this stand or fall on their characters and while Webb keeps us watching, he's not featured often enough.
A compassionate, sensitive look at the precarious lives of those off the grid.
Great performances and an intelligent treatment of a hot topic. Profoundly moving.
Expect bigger laughs staring at the roof of your own oven with gas hissing into your ears.

An atonal mix of knockabout humour and out-of-nowhere violence that's so utterly wrong, it might actually challenge The Day The Clown Cried, Jerry Lewis's unfinished and unreleased 1972 Holocaust comedy.
It's a familiar premise and Holy Rollers sprinkles precisely nothing new into the roll-up.
There's no escaping the fact this is a remake of unadulterated rubbish.
So long, Harry. It's been magic.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a life so incredible and so tragic that even those with no knowledge of chess will be enthralled.
Cell 211 is a brutal piece of filmmaking ... but the shock and gore is warranted ...
Unfortunately, much of it is just smiling crowds carrying placards. More anger would have raised the temperature.
movie_title: Just Do It: A Tale of Modern-day Outlaws (2011)

movie_review_blurb: One for the scrapheap.
One Life is a film truly deserving that much-abused adjective of unmissable.
Funny, cute and humane, Beginners is a small gem of a film.
Killing Bono is entertaining for the first hour but then goes off the boil with a couple of ludicrous criminal subplots and too many scenes of the brothers trying and failing to make it big.
It's not as cool as Iron Man, doesn't have the brains of The Dark Knight or the looks of Thor, but it's got enough Ka-pow! to make you relish the inevitable sequel. Job done.
It's a cheap, cheerless and laugh-free disaster zone with a woeful script and the sort of performances you'd be disappointed to see in a school play. In a word...horrid!
While it's got problems, it's a film to whet the appetite for the planned sequel.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Stunning, baffling, pretentious, brilliant - that's Life.
Believe it or not, this version of Fright Night is actually better than the original - packing in just the right amount of laughs and chills from a cast you'd expect to be above this sort of thing.
Director Julian Gilbey takes a forgettable idea and executes it in an equally forgettable way - which leads to a deeply forgettable film.
Some of the gritty realism is hard to take, but the commitment to souls in trouble is heartwarming.
Nostalgic and achingly beautiful, this is Allen's best since Husbands And Wives.
While it plays hard and loose with the facts, this tale of a boy and a bottlenose dolphin is guaranteed to create a tidal wave's worth of tears.
A film that's corny, predictable and disposable. But it's also pretty good fun - after you've had a few.
Dripping in gothic atmosphere, the only problem is it's all too easy to guess who did what.
It's hard to say what it all means, but it looks terrific and Browning deserves kudos for taking on such a revealing role.
The laughs are gentle, Nick is a pleasingly ambiguous character and the anti-materialism message is admirable.
This year's biggest, dumbest blockbuster. Like a hamburger dripping in grease, there's no nutritional value, but it goes down easily.
It's a hugely enjoyable action adventure packed with swordfights, chases, great characters and snappy dialogue.
More likely to cause an outbreak of yawning, heavy eyelids and a compulsion to keep checking the time.
Rammed with speech bubbles, text messages and onscreen status updates, this is a cartoonish car crash.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The whole thing's about as subtle as a size 11 in the ear and leaves you with no real idea about who these characters really are.
Although this is more a psychological drama than a horror in the traditional sense, it possesses an ability to shock that most modern chillers can't touch.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's never quite as clever as it thinks it is, but ace performances from some of Hollywood's brightest talents, plus some tight plotting, make The Ides Of March a nailbiting affair.
It's a plot with intriguing issues touched upon, including mortality, the class system and that knowing how much time we have left to live can affect our judgments.
The old dark house is exactly the sort of place where you'd expect scary things to happen. The only trouble is that the monsters are cute rather than scary.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Probably the only place you can see a 20ft male member bursting out of a cinema screen.
Anderson's take on Alexandre Dumas' swashbuckling characters winds up being as much fun as putting your privates in a guillotine.
I haven't laughed so hard since Bridesmaids.
There may be worse films showing right now, but there sure isn't one quite this forgettable.
A film which busily ticks off plot points while failing to capture the aching, class-based challenges that presumably formed the backbone of Bronté's book.
It's a frequent complaint that some movies are just too damn slow. And this Chilean film feels like it lasts for days.
You'll find yourself laughing, then realise that it's not meant to be funny.
One of the year's most blindingly brilliant films.
At the start, the film is clever enough to send up the whole rom-com formula with Dylan and Jamie neatly mocking the genre's conventions as they watch a video of Sleepless In Seattle.
As a piece of filmmaking it's impossible not to be impressed. Whether you'll be entertained is another matter.
Although only a small film and one that barely runs to feature length, it raises some unique and thought-provoking ideas.
Far removed from the fairytale land of Forks, this time the man with The Chest doesn't transform into a werewolf. But neither does he transform into a credible leading man.

Hold on tight and prepare for the ride of your life.

While this boasts a few laughs, it contains absolutely no surprises.
Not a knockout, but worth a few rounds nonetheless.

A blockbuster with brains, one that neatly examines the psychological toll of living with a long-standing lie and, less successfully, explores how the power of unrequited love can reach through the decades.
British director David Mackenzie makes good use of an obviously limited budget, with the apocalypse neatly suggested by just a few litter-strewn Glasgow streets patrolled by men in respirator masks.
Its unblinking look at sexual violence and degradation makes for exceptionally uneasy viewing, but it's a film that really should be seen.
movie_title: As If I Am Not There (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A Gallic triumph - and one of the edgiest films you'll see all year.

A solid, if tub-thumping, courtroom drama exploring a little-known chapter of US history.
Cedar Rapids is a lot less funny than it thinks it is with a pretty testing childish zaniness.

Possibly the most violent film ever, I Saw The Devil makes Hostel look like a teddy bears' picnic.
Watching Temuera Morrison and Ray Winstone clash is every bit as electrifying as you'd expect, like a pair of roaring juggernauts colliding at 90mph.
Insidious wouldn't scare a nervous dormouse.
Prepare for the ride of your life.
It's a totally critic-proof film. Just as well, too.
Poignant and just the right side of whimsy, it's the movie Marley & Me should have been.

A couple of nice performances and an earnest message about being yourself are kiboshed by a distinct whiff of déja vu.

Beautifully filmed and terribly funny, it's a hoot from start to finish.

A slow-burning but ultimately devastating look at revenge gone awry, with Press conveying a subtle mix of bolshiness and fragility.
If Avatar was last year's best-looking film, 2011's award may well go to a documentary shot for small change concerning sheep. No, really.
Even the most undemanding of children won't enjoy this sickly confection that would have benefited from better one-liners. Or a dose of myxomatosis.
A slick, cerebral and - most of all - dull as hell sci-fi calamity. As far as excitement is concerned, this is like pitching your parasol on the banks of the Sea Of Tranquillity.
An abstract chase movie inspired by the war on terror, it starts well but fades into irrelevance.
The lights are on, but nobody's home.
Weird doesn't quite cover it, but fans of the surreal will find Rubber - drumroll, please - a gripping experience.
A few lively song-and-dance numbers plus the voice talents of Jamie Foxx and will.i.am earn an extra star.
Good looks are about the only thing going for it.
Well worth catching due to believable characters, some great action scenes and a looming sense of threat.
Elicits snores and guffaws thanks to workmanlike 'shock' moments and obvious twists.
A film to be appreciated only by those who think using modern swear words in a medieval setting is automatically funny.
The light melodrama is gently amusing at first before turning sickeningly self-satisfied.
The budget may be small change and it comes with no stars, but here's a documentary with a whole heap of heart.

By Odin's beard, it's a winner.
It's a film that could only have been made by an American. They're welcome to it.

Beastly doesn't quite cover it. Not even monstrous, gruesome or grotesque come close.
Rip-off or homage, it all adds up to an enjoyable stew of a film, even if you find yourself playing 'name that movie' for most of the running time.
A two leftfooted, choreographed-within-an-inch-of-its-life, teen movie.
It's a good idea, but what follows is a long parade of repetitive growling, gunfights and near arrests.
With an all-star voice cast, gorgeous animation and a story that both thrills and tugs the heartstrings, it's as good a 'toon as we're likely to see all year.

Think Eyes Wide Shut with its legs wide open.
Not a good movie, but a brave one from a star in trouble.
A British comedy bad enough to end careers and result in angry - and justified - calls for refunds at the box office.

movie_title: World of the Dead: The Zombie Diaries 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a vulnerable but proud woman who we can't help but like.

You won't see a more absorbing film all year.

A film that informs and outrages in equal measure.

A masterclass in tension.

Disappointing because it's a film from Tom McCarthy, the man who gave us The Station Agent and The Visitor. Win Win is equally humane, but just too cosy and pat.
Founders on the rocks of dull backstory, too many characters and a sense of tiredness.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cmpetently made, but after Mesrine, the recent Carlos The Jackal film and the Mafiathemed Gomorrah, this is one sub-genre that's fast reaching saturation point.
I am giving this film four out of five stars because they made some changes to the storyline, but it is still awesome.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's an hour-and a-half of nothing.

While it's initially hard to care much about characters this privileged, the emotions and situations are ones we can all relate to.
An engrossing look at Irish villagers fighting Shell's plans to lay a gas pipeline through their local bay and common.
Charts the trials of two boys hoping to win a surfing contest to escape the grinding poverty of Rio's Favela.
Stitched together from often blurry footage, it's an engrossing and poignant tribute to one of the sport's legends, even if we know how it ends.
Best watched drunk - that way you might awake with no memory of the experience.
While this amiable romantic comedy ... is sure to please most of its target audience, others are going to leave the theater humming that Peggy Lee classic 'Is That All There Is?'
Vera's technical prowess ends up selling his film short; he smoothes over hard truths even as he uncovers them.

Princesa, like its heroine, is not at all what it seems at first. For its immediately straightforward melodramatics leave in the film's wake a haunting afterglow of a life not easily resolved by a screenplay's third act.

A film for the chastened romantic in us all -- gay, straight or 'for pay.'
... deeply moving and exceptionally gracious piece of documentary filmmaking.

How do you follow-up Pink Flamingos? Not with a work that tries to outdo that classic gross-out comedy, but rather by moving in another direction entirely that's just as subversive, if not more so.
Shot on digital video, with a sharp eye for Los Angeles locales, this is a well-shaped piece of work -- despite its overly earnest characters' penchant for psychobabble.

Though the climactic revelation and resolution is expected, the film is full of fresh and unexpected observations about the cross-culturally complex lives of second-generation Indians living in the U.S.
Incredibly violent yet emotionally compelling.
Not only unfunny, but downright repellent.
Beautifully made and performed, this is a film of considerable insight into both the life of the impoverished and the mystery of human personality.
A lacerating study of sexual alienation.

A thoughtful, well-acted and well-observed (though bleak) look at what some people have to put up with to get through life.

Charged by Rideau's amazingly sexy performance as the most forthright gay character put on screen to date.
