Diesel owns it. He hits us in the eye with the whole pizza pie.
Nothing can upgrade pulp like a bunch of plush British accents.
It's Shakespeare For Absent Dummies, no cram notes needed.
As philosopher Mary Warnock says, with a nod to John Locke, [Doug] Bruce is 'certainly the same man, questionably the same person.' The paradox haunts a remarkable film.
Not just altering history but updating it, this is the best political satire since Joe Dante's The Second Civil War and the strong sections of Spike Lee's Bamboozled.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: 'Coming out' films are now rituals, patterned like dances, and Marco Kreuzpaintner's Summer Storm hits its generic marks.
Don't Come Knocking lacks Harry Dean Stanton and the astonishing emotional trajectory of Paris, Texas (1984), but it reunites Wim Wenders and writer Sam Shepard in a raw, airy West.
Not a special pleader but is fairly special, because Sanders gives it the pressure of straight moral conviction.
This oddball wallow is both tonic and toxic, packaged in Egoyan's dishy style, so capably served by Paul Sarossy's images and Philip Barker's sleek design.
It is surprising to find quite a good Coast Guard movie. But then, it's surprising to find any Coast Guard movie.
A charm parade of serial death in the old, cherishable line of The Ladykillers and Kind Hearts and Coronets, though more cozily pastoral, the film rouses chuckles.
Evening reaches for depth, at times plodding, never cloddish. The lessons about choice and loss and getting on in life have some decent heft, and there is a sunset magic in Redgrave's eyes.
You have to go back to the worst Hanna-Barbera cartoons to find gag material this excruciatingly contrived.
J.K. Rowling has a spirit of plenty. On page and screen, her vision is a deliciously human (not just mythic) triumph of fancy, a spreading of soulful wings to lift us high.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The writers and director Dennis Dugan conspire to be gutsy in a gutless way.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: From Mostly Martha to Mainly Comfort Food -- by way of the Hollywood microwave.
Always dressed and coiffed like perfect dolls, the Bratz reaffirm sisterhood by heading for the mall.
Ultimatum tries to stir sympathy for its indestructible hero. But Jason Bourne has all the charm of a howitzer. He needs some time with the Harry Potter bunch.
If a bit long for a cartoon feature -- probably a sign that its makers fell in love with it -- Ratatouille is the eighth and one of the best Pixar features.
Stardust staggers with end-of-summer excess, seldom winning more than a weary gasp.
What Forman doesn't give us is drama of sure coherence or credibility, but the trappings entrance.
Atkinson is tireless, and a bit tiring. His facial contortions, weird grunts and malaprop moves almost never rest, and his holiday trip to Cannes from Paris is a twit's marathon.
As steeped in Russian flavors as a hot samovar, this fast, compelling story is also oddly Dickensian in its shadowy corners and twists.
Finally even Thornton finds his inner softie, at which point the film, after some OK gags, dies with a mechanical squish.
There is the squishy tension of a problem drama gone soft.
A movie that has only two major scenes for Streep and one for Arkin has talent to spare.
It's a soaper about a doper and a classy widow. Keep that in mind, even if you give way to seduction.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Rush Hour 3 is a traffic jam of clichés that doesn't achieve gridlock mainly because the stars, Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker, are too tireless to quit.
Moments of tension quicken almost unbearably, and no one is immune (the crowds are like nerves multiplied).
There are laughs, good effects, fine beasts and a mood of goofy apocalypse.

Seattle locales, some spry lines and tiny soundings of depth still leave us in the conceptual grip of 'love' as a system of endless bartering and vanity, with impulsive copulation treated as consecration. Oh, boy.
A bar of soap is a repeated element in Georgia Rule, and rightly so. Suds rise in this capably acted fem-drama laced with slap-in comedy.

The movie has some vivid shock touches and the scenes of depopulated London are queasily strange. Still, this is really about a grimly ravaged couple and two kids put through hell. Your idea of fun? Munch on it.

Essentially the movie is saying to its loyal crowd: You bought this stuff before, now take it re-canned. There is nothing really happening but the breezy ricochet of gags, the rote sitcom types, the star voices that are phoning in performances.
Parker Posey is one of the indie queens used feebly by Hollywood, but in the hands of Hartley she is the star needed and right on schedule.
The third film is a startling cascade of climaxes, too long, but to complain about excess in such an exuberant bonanza is like complaining that Gibraltar has too much rock.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An attitude bazooka full of sex, drugs and raw language, yet so high on babies and family values that this must be the first R-rated film for both sleazoid slackers and earnest right-to-lifers.
Mr. Brooks does work up some clammy tension. The script has bite.

This more homespun film doesn't let down its story or the Shue family. Its plain integrity outshines predictability. It is feminist without cant. And Schroeder delivers perhaps the finest young female performance of the year.
Demeaningly patronizing to educators, cheaply dismissive of students, Chalk is a dunce. Erase it.
Paprika is a fertile delta of forms and colors, wildly inventive, shape-shifting, jiggly with fat jokes.
Many districts of the city open to as many directors, each finding vignettes of love or loss.

Plot pieces barely fit, almost nothing is clearly explained, the gizmos and twists are stupid, the wit witless. This movie smokes a fat cigar of assumption, smug that most viewers will need to feel like insiders.
Cartoonishly surging with liquid color, digital waves and jokes that even include gefilte fish, Surf's Up never forgets to have fun.
This Parisian fable is a talkathon, affecting a silly toughness, but the sights are good to see again.
If not entirely a downer, this is no topper.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A recent book on the Nancy Drew mysteries notes that Nancy came along in 1930, just as 'the first tampons went on sale.' News to Nancy in 2007? Her love life remains virtuously naive, and Betty Boop still thinks she's a square.
A grand mural of trauma, with superb colors, a great escape scene and fertile myth-probing about how masters and vassals together forged the hot core of Mexican Catholicism.
This jabbering, photographed pamphlet might spark some discussion, but as a movie it suffocates on gas.
Extravagantly expendable.
Old fox Lumet deals out some flash cutting and time frame back-and-forths that, if not the Tarantino tango, are fairly adventurous.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What is missing is the novel, its strange time shifts and lusciously compiled details and playful, god-like viewpoint.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The grand finish, if not always inspired, feels necessary. In a sustained, imaginative way, this is the best of any movie series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like Tiepolo, Miyazaki is a winged artist who flies in his own space, taking gravity with him. He can put us into a childish stupor of anticipation, then satisfaction. His vision is so free that it captivates.
It's very pretty (plus a song that is like a gumdrop melting in your ear). Girls may enjoy the sweet, rather wistful story more than most boys.
The acting marathon is adroitly blocked and paced by Polanski and impeccably shot by Pawel Edelman.
Through it all, Dujardin has great dignity, is hugely likeable, and pulls off touches of comic poignancy not far from Chaplin's.

The film is richly rooted, with splendid trappings, including pea-soup fogs. For all the pomp and protocol, it's an intimate story about a scared man who must find his voice if he is to rise, in regal stature, above his epaulets.
Here is your post-holiday depression pill: Children of Men. Not to relieve depression. To cause it.
Brad Pitt is at the top of his own game as Beane. Cocky and often nonchalant, he is gnawed by doubts that he tries to cover by grabbing a snack or pitching a grin.
Despite its plodding tactics, the movie is an alarming witness.
Devout fans will have to go. For the rest of us, the best rewards of this show were long ago, in a galaxy that now seems far, far away.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The story is a lurching carnival of budget blasts.
The makers are left, finally, a few cookies short.
A few tart, amusing lines echo the fabled Kind Hearts and Coronets, yet this British movie based on a French farce falls into morbid silliness.
With Walker and cinematographer Dudu Miranda, Muniz has a hawk's eye for the weird beauty of bulldozed hillocks of trash and the catador faces that he chose to star in photographic portraits.
Maturing performances are a bonus, but the show's the thing, and by now it seems much richer than any theme park that could ever be made from it.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is heartfelt but not deeply searching, not Dostoevskian. It's teasing, melodramatic and oversold.
Strong effects, good design, and an exciting use of nature help to empower Stewart and Theron, who inject a rich, double dose of feminism.
The finish, a rush of climaxes, can make you feel zoned at 3 a.m., trying to decide between TV and the wallpaper.
Persepolis feels abstract, never deeply personal, because Satrapi offers only surfaces and push-pin thoughts while sharing here sincere but glib sisterhood with Iranian history.
Anderson is a gambler who likes wild cards.
There may be box-office gold from The Golden Compass, but panning for it while viewing is a real day at the mine.
It's a movie in which everyone wants answers without being able to formulate the questions.
The cast is game, the script is watered nog, the kids push their charm hard, Murphy is often excruciating, Union is pleasant in a sitcom mommy way, and Lance Rivera is a zero stylist.
Not since Election has a female star talent hit the screen with such a sting of arrival.
An amiable but also angry documentary.
It's a free-fall into total plastic. Kids deserve better. Alvin, Simon and Theodore deserve better. But 'tis the season to take what you get.
Atonement, a triumph of adulthood, atones for a lot of shoddy stuff at the movies in 2007.
The movie's energizing strength is intelligence. It is so entertainingly adult.
Coppola has conviction even with the airiest elements. The churn and sweep of time, memory, karma, the whole enchilada of fate, give the story a weirdly compulsive charm.
The movie greedily uses its rich cast.
Afghanistan is a nation tortured by history, but the core feeling in The Kite Runner is heartburning love of the place, its proud people and dusty, rugged beauty.
It would be inhuman not to empathize with the actual man's plight, but the movie is a sophisticated prod, pushing us inside its own Bauby.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The truly disturbing element is the heavy reliance on childhood loneliness, fear and sickness.
The Bucket List gets through its list while rarely seeming a chore. Its two great stars invite us into their company, often amusingly, always humanly.
Had Wile E. Coyote chased Jean-Luc Godard, the result might have been Diva.
The film 27 Dresses only seems like a lobotomy. In fact, this is public surgery to install a new vacuum tube for airheads into the generic chick flick, model 2008.

What's not to believe? A lot. But asking for bolted logic and dramatic structure in such a movie is about like asking former Fed chief Alan Greenspan to open a mosh pit in Miami. Anyway, the money in the bank here is Keaton.
Get into the right and light holiday spirit, and you should be pleased.
As was famously said, we'll always have Paris. Very few, even the makers of Amelie, have Paris quite like Gondry.

It's a dynamic Spider-Man movie. Most of the familiars are back, the additions work well enough, the movie often looks terrific and excess length (about 15 minutes) is just the pad built into these piled-up projects.
No doubt there was hope for a manlier, brinier My Big Fat Greek Wedding. But that had better food -- and better jokes.
It's watchable, but like gorging on every rotten issue of the old Confidential magazine.
Long, belabored, terminally solemn despite some vigor, and numbingly sentimental under a tough surface, this is a serpentine coiling of three modestly connected and episodic stories.
Despite all the sunny, Provencale charms, the plot is a wisp of wee gags, peeps of flesh, mildly charming repartee.

A buddy movie shot with artless rawness, yet highly implicative about the wastage of modern street males and the sort of men cultivated by state agencies to be disposable killers, Harsh Times is a B-film with A-level morsels.
At least N'Orleans got production dollars from this film. What do we get? Lack of originality that starts with the title, used for feature films in 1985, 1988 and 1997.
To call Fur one of the year's best seems a little diminishing -- it's a classic.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: How moved you are by this holiday fare depends, beyond basic human empathy, on your piety (or nostalgia for childhood readings and Nativity plays).
With our help, Borat can move the United States above Kazakhstan on the U.N. laff meter.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [Byambasuren Davaa is] a sure talent, slipping into the life he observes unobtrusively.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Winslet, Black, Law and to some extent the others are often swell. But the script limits are still there, knots in the weave, and you need to be a goner for manipulation not to notice.
Director Edward Zwick, whose movies tend to preen, swell and stretch, pushes lengths past the obvious emotional closure and moral payoff.

This is one of the few American movies to deal with how people live and survive. It admires smart brokers but also feels for the many people down below, and we know that Chris will not claim his 'happyness' by becoming a cold fish in a glass office.
In this crafty version of the E.B. White classic, critters say the darndest things, humans are often marginal (and mom frying bacon is darn tactless), humor and warmth keep bubbling up.
The Painted Veil doesn't have quite the gripping pressure that Maugham built in his prose with such sober, masterly confidence, but it is strong work, honestly done.
[Director Sylvain] White has a good cast but directs the fiercely macho dances in a choppy, video-buzzed manner that breaks up patterns and fuzzes some steps.
It is all so done and overdone, so regurgitated, so late-night TV and what-else-is-new-in-hell.
Apocalypto is a big load of sado.
Many hands, including many writers, applied themselves to Flushed Away (doesn't that usually require just one hand?). The result is committee animation: cute, fast, uninspired, softly consumable.
You can come away feeling bruised and half-deaf.
The movie is a litany of victims and a chilling indictment.
France's Claude Chabrol, venerable (76) chessman of suspenseful bourgeois rot, moves his pawns superbly again, though we see the checkmate coming.

Crime stories have become incredibly generic, and though this is not a pit like Miami Vice, some bursts of good staging and imagery only serve to remind us that Scorsese is a streak gambler who can get stuck with the wrong hand.
The key achievement, in this vividly shot and superbly cast drama, is to make us fear for the slightly contemptible Garrigan but feel mostly for Ugandans, even (a little) for Amin.
Ewing and Grady avoid prodding or sneering, giving Fischer and her young charges nearly all the scenes.
Even more soulless than Tron or The Black Cauldron, Renaissance seems less a vanguard advance than the rococo degeneration of an art movement for trippy nerds.
In this truth game, Capote is an ace and Infamous is a compelling queen, both in play for high stakes with In Cold Blood and Richard Brooks' scary 1967 film of it.

Robin Williams doesn't need to prove he can act, not after The Fisher King, The Night Listener, Good Will Hunting and Mrs. Doubtfire. What he does in Man of the Year seems a long way from actual acting.
Now, they are middle-aged, and (unfair to spoil small surprises here) embedded in life with some learned wisdom.
Tiresomely tireless escapade.
Funny? At times, but mainly sad, seasoned and alive to the test of a summer when a canny new PM met history through two remarkable women.
[Arroyuelo and Camil] are enjoyable, so is Martha Higareda as Claudio's patient girlfriend, though the coming of the band is treated like Jesus returning with the Beatles.
If not so witty as Coppola's Lost in Translation, this is like a funnier and feminine Barry Lyndon.
Flags has the guts to put honest quote remarks around 'the good war" and 'the greatest generation.' It honors the fathers and the lost sons by not simply raising a flag.
It is good for magic to be, in effect, confounding. It is not so good for a movie about magic to be confusing.
Lancingly funny, brash and alive, this hotsie-totsie peeper aches for love, and the gay fire of pre-AIDs partydom.
Julie Walters lets out the stops as this stooped bulldozer, pushing whole hogs of ham.
Concise, elegant, a tad scary, this is a treat for Halloween.
Pan's Labyrinth, like del Toro's previous and related The Devil's Backbone, is a saturated vision, an artist's work. What it lacks is successful unity.
Sometimes you pan a deadpan comedy because it's effectively dead.

Eastwood has at times been a theme-bound and overly praised director. But the laurels really fit this unique double bill. His spare, careful classicism, braced by compelling care for tension and action, makes Letters a great battle movie.

The intended audience must be the fan club for Scarface (Pacino's), anyone who has made a superficial pass at Quentin Tarantino's work, and anyone who felt challenged by Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.
Camp out with Tears, a hoot, and your tent will be wet only from tears of laughter.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's all padded, contrived, gummy with sympathy given or denied.
As Bob Lee Swagger, marksman, sniper, death dealer, Wahlberg in Shooter has his most physically perfect role since Boogie Nights.
Not even Howard's genuine appeal, or his can-do kids, can keep Pride out of the shallow end of the pool.

Tends to bubble along as a plot-boiler. Chris' guilty fantasy about the past girlfriend, just as he works up nerve for some major action, is the kind of twist that one studies screenwriting to learn and then surpass.

On ice, the movie is often fairly funny. Off it, the garish outfits, the genitalia jokes, the beer-slob gags about gays, the women as cheap laughs, even the cute guest cameos start to shiver and melt.
Giddily inventive, cute, charming, even wry.
While a Feydeau farce fits well, and the salute to a Brancusi sculpture is sweet, Beethoven piano passages overload the souffle.

Puerile prop gags slapped in without development, an inane score, dud reactions, Steve Carr's dismal direction, a Magic Johnson phone-in cameo -- it adds up to the question that keeps arising, which is (yep) the title.
Robert Rodriguez bakes a load of stale if bloody pastry called Planet Terror, while Quentin Tarantino fries up a tasty mess of fun with Death Proof.
If you're going to remake (or salute) a Hitchcock classic, it's fine to start off like Disturbia. It is not fine to end up like Disturbia.
The animation is pastiche but impudently inventive, with pop culture eating its furry tail after a long lick.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Must the 13-year-old boy Hollywood seems most eager to please also be a sadist? First came Apocalypto, then 300, now Pathfinder.
Barry Ackroyd's wonderful imagery often gives a sense of vernal moisture, which adds to the sweaty tension.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Movies like this, side ventures of the John Grisham franchise, are meant to entertain with 'substance' that never risks actual depth.
Director Edgar Wright, scripting with star Simon Pegg, winds it up and lets it fly. The result, even hitting its target, tends to splat.
Firehouse Dog has good fire action, an engaging cast and enough vividly shot turns, surprises and bowwow reactions to hold the firm attention of pet lovers from age 5 on up. Go fetch.
The movie lays on gag situations that smack of fillers.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Not exactly a thriller, never quite a chiller, hardly suspenseful, it is, at best, a Sandra Bullock vehicle made of vanishing vapors.
Implausibles become inane in this Godzilla Jr. jubilee, something just right for the DVD cheapie bins.
Calling this a chick flick is maybe too easy. The film is for people who want to leave the house but watch TV without going to a bar or hotel. Bring along a remote and you can be fully comfortable.
Peter O'Toole is surpassingly good in Venus.
With Keaton in devastating overdrive, Moore can barely exercise her own brand of ginchiness.
The film's ugliness is less in its 'artful' death rituals, by now deeply generic, than in asking us to feel for Lecter because of his horrid, warping youth.
Norbit is not a thriller, action film or suspense story. Still, it achieves the assassination of comedy.

An A-list soaper on moral pins and needles, the film is urbanely textured, full of Brit glibness and plush layering. Minghella makes broodingly adult coffee-table movies, and sometimes we wish he'd just serve up the coffee.
Grant happily rummages through his role, Barrymore is splendid with gulps and goofs, and Campbell Scott is an impeccably pompous author.

The adroitly calibrated life lessons include a chill gulp of death, and Terabithia proves to be soulful, even healing. What most delivers is the efficiently just-right cast, the charmed bonding of kid stars Robb and Hutcherson.
Despite limits, the story has traction and grip. As Hanssen plays out his fate, truly worshipping nothing but his own importance, we enjoy the pressures so bracingly incarnated by Chris Cooper.
Factory Girl is weirdo weary, despite some vivacity spooned into it by Sienna Miller as Edie Sedgwick.
Peter Glenville's stage-plank direction creaks badly, but the acting still holds you.

This oddball has something beyond root-for-the-roots sentiments. Thornton, well into his own orbit, is very genuinely appealing as a guy who wires his big dream machine to a loose but glowing screw in his head. Rise up, farm bird.

Often vulnerable, more often inspiring, Gruffudd's Wilberforce not only stirs curiosity but also quickens your conscience. As Fox notes eloquently, he was a great man. One does not have to be religious to believe he had amazing grace.
The movie snakes along with an earthy hiss, thanks to music, Jackson and Ricci's painful availability.
Christopher Quinn and Tommy Walker made this fine and never simply pleading film, its moving subjects including tall, gentle, tireless, prayerful and humane John Bul Dau.
We can pretty well guess some coming deaths, but the combat for a tiny Alsatian town is vividly done.
It is too dumb as drama, even as war spectacle, to be transporting, frightening or sickening. Just numbing.
Basically a vivid meal of characters, plus coffee and wine and one gin tonic, Le Petit Lieutenant keeps true to its brasserie menu.
Jarhead is not a blank, but it never quite pulls the trigger.
Wild Hogs is an oinker. Feeding us slops of dud comedy are stars who ought to know better by now.
Tall, boyish Loic (Pierre Chatagny) is too much a statue even to be called stupid.
This absorber falls below Babenco's Pixote and Fernando Meirelles' churning City of God as a biopsy of Brazilian despair, so carnal in its desperation, yet is well above being a stew of sensations.
A scrapbook of right-now tensions and suspense.
Plain and human and profoundly warmed by the appealing James of Siyabonga Melongisi Shibe.
Andre Techine's film has true feeling for France in 1940, but is too intimate to be called a war film.
The plot has a loose string or two, but the details are lived-in, true, down-home but not corny.
This is imperial impiety, and may it last a thousand years.
Mario has his dad down, and if the acting is often blatant, this does fit the original.
The Day After Tomorrow has pretty good special effects and the body heat of pure kitsch.
A big, marvelous entertainment we can feel proud to love.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: At moments the taste is flat, but this brew has a head on it. It's the strangest Canadian export since Glenn Gould.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The dense visuals are the entire story and the only reason to attend.
Another regulation teen comedy.
Played by Anne Reid in one of the great senior (but not just senior) performances.
The word on this one is simple: Enjoy.
We all have our rigidities, and Control Room may wake you up a bit.
An extremely effective advertisement for Michael Moore's political ideas and gut feelings.
Like a cutout without backing, the star figures being either adorable (if you care to indulge) or very irritating.
The landscapes are lovely, and Huppert rises to her usual high form.
In her first film, Julie Bertuccelli shows a pinpointed eye and a sweet gift for intimacy.
Smacks of upscale student work with a command of atmospherics but a script mixed in a blender of concept doodles.
A compelling mixture of dry humor and even drier -- if you can imagine such a thing -- sentiment.
Dogville is most depressing because Trier promises two more, for his American trilogy. Lars, enough already.
Although director Gary Winick can put a smile on such stuff, and dispose of actors without trashing them, the script is a vapor mist of rinky-dinks.

Denzel Washington is an actor of such magnetic conviction that he could read Schopenhauer to earthworms and probably hold their interest. But in 'Man on Fire' he has to haul around so much guilt and threat and doom that he seems ready to sag from rot.
What dampens the breeziness is the slightly mothballed feeling that this has all been done, before and better.
'Fore!' haunted by 'Bore!'
Parts of it are quite funny. So, go fetch.
Godsend is one of the collapsing duds that should cause not only critics to despair -- not about bad movies, but that the makers believe any audience deserves this.
[McGregor's] best film work so far.
The primal intensity of emotions and settings takes the story well beyond generic elements.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Veteran observers of the small and famous may watch Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen in New York Minute, and think: Pia Zadora, even smaller, but doubled.

If you grew up on goth comics, Saturday cartoons and the endless zap violence of video games, you might hanker for this. But anyone who craves story, not just empowered pastiche, has got to tire quickly.
For a summer epic, this is depth, and the terrible, ordained finish (with that tricky Trojan horse) still stirs us.
When a traditionally good Japanese film gets you in its grip, there is nothing quite like it.
Cute, cute, cute is pretty much the defining description of Shrek 2.
The old (well, only 51) hipster may get you hooked on segments, sure as nicotine loves caffeine, but the addiction is passing.
This is a kid even Art Linkletter would have told to shut up.
It's a vacuum-packed Idaho spud of a world, but funny.
Not so much dramatizing as frisking its themes, Vol. 2 has more story, more emotion, more breath-held quiet times to coax and trigger the tensions.
Good actors can do much, but they can't save a boring movie from itself.
Surges and sags in massive sections.
Winterbottom and his imagists contrived a rich digital polarity, of the sterile stacks of great towers, in a yellow haze of smog and deserts, and the trashy but vital outlands.
As it works out its pattern in an airy carpet of confession and omission, you may find the film adroitly involving. Or, simply, boring.
It's rare for a movie to have so many blooming surprises.
The film seems to have internalized Sokurov's inspiration so far that it becomes a blur of hints and vapors.
Without a Paddle credibly defines the cheap satisfaction you can get from foolish summer distraction.
The key problem of this acting exercise is that we can sense what must come, and sadly it does.
Director Hugo Rodriguez and writer Martin Salinas must have thought they were on a post-Tarantino edge. Their only edge is the razor slicing open the hoodlum.
The film is simply part of a synergized income stream, more deft revenge upon us for having won World War II.
Your eyes may widen even as you yawn.

The wise ones, including biologist Candace Pert, Dr. Joe Dispenza, physicists Fred Alan Wolf and Amit Goswami, New Age seer Ramtha (born name: J.Z. Knight) and others, do speak some wisdom. And when they sound like a bubble machine, you can still smile.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A feel-good gift to moderns, yet why not feel so good? Thackeray, and his Becky, would have relished it.
Like a stream of vapor trails trying to be a cloud, a floating 'thriller' of posed moods and inane jolts that make viewers laugh.
Nicely shot, quaintly romantic, it is tuned to the Australian taste in matey malarkey.
Ace noir title, OK noir movie.
Ellis, up from stunt work (but not very far), hangs onto the whopper moments for dear life, even if cheap laughs outweigh a mother's pain.

The fast, forced plot, which moves up from street grifts to a big score involving rare currency, lives in the amusing and zippered byplay of Luna and Reilly, who achieve a sort of marriage du jour for criminal purposes.
A rather redundant shredder, President Bush's war policy having shredded itself. But in force and focus this sober indictment is devastating.
All is Disney and cute and up.
Not bad at all (the music is a little trite), but where is the incentive to experience it? Less a horror film than a misery spree.
Has the right, Bukowskian approach: Just tell it, just show it, no fancy dancing.
You can hardly fault the details, the resonant silences, the sudden gushers of pent-up feeling.

This Amerindie's horror elements are actually its least interesting aspects; you wish that British director Simon Rumley had stuck with that first half's beguiling look at a new, weird Americana and left the exploitation trappings to lesser filmmakers.
Yen's handful of duels do delight; it's everything surrounding them that feels tired and trite.
To see the actual footage from the Nuremberg trials in such long, extended clips is shocking -- mainly because this footage has been suppressed in North America for decades.
A strong contender for both the artiest drug movie and the druggiest art movie ever made, Gaspar Noé's tour de force of forced perspectives and free-form grief is, in every sense of the word, a trip.
The plentiful pop-doc touches ensure that this wake-up call won't put you to sleep, even if the ratio of spoonfuls of sugar to medicine occasionally seems skewed.
Strange Powers works best when inadvertently capturing the toll of living in the shadow of a genius. When it comes to examining the genius himself, it's woefully out of tune.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's tempting to call this stunning sick joke the work of a true visionary.
movie_title: The Temptation of St. Tony (Püha Tõnu kiusamine) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Edfeldt and his extraordinary lead actor balance the scales by presenting this tragedy as a test of strength.
Little more than a travelogue and a vaguely contemplative vibe.
The movie will make you tap your toes; don't expect much for your head or your heartstrings.
It's as if the filmmakers swallowed the sports-movie handbook and regurgitated every cliché in half-digested form.
Who Is Harry Nilsson is a worthwhile portrait of a genius who made beautiful music, and a case study for how to tragically, epically self-destruct.
movie_title: Who is Harry Nilsson (And Why is Everybody Talkin' About Him)? (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Less a filmed lecture than a deadly dull cine-sedative.
The show eloquently chronicled the end of an era; in terms of doing justice to what the loss meant to New York and beyond, this sappy, sloppy souvenir can barely make it to first base.
[Aronofsky] demonstrates a ... brilliance that few modern American filmmakers can match.
To reduce their story to a handwringer for housewives that's laden with protest-sign sloganeering seems, frankly, unfair.
There's beaucoup simmering sexual tension, as well as the prolific French director's usual thematic preoccupations: death and grief, familial animosity and female awakening.

Blank City is more than just a correlative correction; it's a complementary portrait of how, just like Blondie, Basquiat et al., these wasteland mavericks created their own zeitgeist out of urgent desperation and urban decay.
What is cinema but an elaborate simulation that, in the hands of an artist, mines real truth from fiction? By that criterion, Certified Copy is indeed the genuine article.
After years of animators riding the post-Pixar renaissance and filmgoers feasting on the fruits of their labor, we may have finally hit a collective moment of big-screen-toon fatigue.
Misses the Hughes sensitive-raunch sweet spot, though a game supporting cast hits bull's-eyes on lesser targets.
By the end of this funny, insightful doc, you get a sense of an extraordinary mind that both fueled and fed the zeitgeist. Don't miss it.
Ping-pongs between empathetic chuckles at Helms's charming social awkwardness and putting him through a raunchfest ringer.
Five minutes in, and cowriter-director John Huston has already set the stage for something besides your typical '50s jungle-bwana boogie.
It's as if Araki simply decided to make the horniest episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer ever.
A key transitional work for the cinematic subversive, a seriously damning portrait of maternal martyrdom and, in a killer final shot, upward mobility.
The movie isn't worth the scuffed cowgirl boots it's scooting around in.
Another descent into mediocre Amerindie miserablism.
Biutiful is not a tragedy. It's a straight-up travesty.
The directors' propensity for verbiage and ironic violence fits the story like a fringed suede glove. Welcome to the first stoic screwball Western.
Easily the most gracefully performed grief-porn you'll see this season...
Lanzmann slowly, cumulatively colors in a vast canvas on mass murder.
You need to be one helluva director to pull off using kids' stickers as a climactic plot point; this auteur makes it look like child's play.

[Wahlberg's] modest performance is the one element that feels truly authentic and heartfelt. The role plays to his strengths: a rough-and-tumble earthiness, the ability to suggest a dreamer lurking beneath the exterior of a bruiser.
[Giamatti] makes this mess of a human being seem oddly gallant instead of grotesque.
It's a juicy story, though that doesn't excuse Jarecki from fixating above all else on the tabloid-ready twists and pop-psychological turns of Durst's story.
History is written by the winners, but even after the ink dries, everyone-including the losers-still has to live with it.

This charmless movie thinks it can soft-sell its date-night love story and its media meta-jabs without people feeling they've been bamboozled on either count. To which we can only say good night, and good luck.
Consider it food for thought, spiced with a pinch of cult-of-personality gospel.
Patrick Hughes's bloody, brutal Australian thriller handles its B-movie premise with surprising precision, though the inclusion of several befuddling elements annoyingly puncture the suspense.
Even past youth-friendly adaptations kept enough of the book's bite that you could recognize the Swiftian satire. This update is merely a swift kick to the nuts.
This guerrilla-cinema essay is more than just a look at China's judicial morass; it's a dispatch from the front lines of a dictatorship.
There is a stunning mediation on sleek surfaces that hide social rot and technology hijacked by Big Brother; you just have to bypass the film's creator to get to it.
The promise on display is impressive; consider the film a calling card from someone to keep a very close eye on.
Third times are rarely charms in the movies, much less fourth go-rounds, and it takes more than ho-hum 3-D and video-game-ready action sequences to liven up diminishing returns.
It's gratifying to see Eisenberg move past nerdy-cutie parts; his slim shoulders, it seems, are capable of handling more than Michael Cera's leftovers.
There's no bounty to be plucked from Perrier's Bounty. The treasure chest has long since been emptied.
The big question isn't whether middle-aged romance will bloom, but rather, how much sub-Jarmusch deadpan humor and pathos can you take?
An overall lack of drive drops the pacing from languorous to a slow, stalled crawl, but the journey itself isn't the point here. For once, it's the destination -- forgiveness -- that really counts.
If this is what passes for contemporary art terrorism, we'll opt instead for something truly subversive -- like genuine art.
Don't discount the pleasure of watching a weathered star breathe life into an otherwise banal film.
We like our secondhand vengeance as sleazy and bloody as the next grindhouse fiend, but even an intentional throwback shouldn't feel content to coast on so much déjà vu.
Caan can't seem to play up his strengths. He's a raw talent who needs an editor for his scripts and a strong hand behind the camera guiding him. Mercy gives our guy neither.

Thanks to Scott Crocker's crisply edited balance of scientific backbiting, naturalist noodling and a macro-philosophizing of what this possible rediscovery might mean, what could have been a niche-specific doc becomes something oddly compelling...
A slavish, supercharged riff on Sergio Leone's epic three-the-hard-way spaghetti Western, Kim Ji-woon's all-star spectacle wastes little time in lighting a fire under its unholy trinity's derrieres.

movie_review_blurb: A truly impressive portrait of self-destructive, smooth-talking alpha males, and a testament to an actor who waltzes across that Peter Pan-syndrome tightrope with the greatest of sleaze.

movie_review_blurb: These guys belong in the avant-odd pantheon. They also deserve a stronger, more penetrating tribute.

Every so often, you get the gift of watching an under-the-radar actor bloom into a critical-mass phenomenon before your bloodshot eyes...

The odor of musty, late-'80s nostalgia may still hover around this already threadbare brand, but you simply don't see movies that leave both the curious and the fans who truly care this viscerally satisfied anymore.

In all aspects, The Girl can't help it-this is headline-torn cinema du tearjerking at its most generic.
You couldn't accuse the cast members of being good actors (several struggle to be merely amateurish).
Regardless of whether you're a longtime devotee or not, you'll be left saying, "This is The Sweeney? I've been rooked."
Mildly resonant, if not revelatory.
Everything here, except the action scenes, [feels] sluggish and rote.
The way Ruiz uses such giddy flourishes in the name of looking back on one's life is both thrillingly irreverent and surprisingly moving.
An unsentimental, salt-of-the-earth tribute that keeps the beat in a way that would make this extraordinary journeyman beam.
movie_title: Ain't In It For My Health: A Film About Levon Helm (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Serves as a sideways time capsule, creating a blurry snapshot of an Afro-camp subculture during the era of Christopher Street bar raids and burn-baby-burn rioting.
The result is alternately elegiac and akin to watching a photograph fade in real time.
movie_title: Out-Takes From The Life Of A Happy Man (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Such a nonstop go-for-broke sensibility can be too much of a good thing, of course, and there are moments when the filmmaker's mix-and-match methodology feels tuned to the key of migraine.
Whether this love letter is more preaching to the converted than a corrective is arguable.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Movies genuinely attuned to the nuances of female bonding are regrettably rare; so, it seems, are ones that know how to make good on their promise without breaking just like a little girl.
The real strength of Cohen's occasionally didactic drama ... is in the way the film redirects your focus to the periphery and reminds you of the richness that resides there.
There's a need for redemption here, to be certain, and it has nothing to do with the narrative.
If you've seen any of the playwright's previous forays into XY-ugliness, you can probably skip this one and still sleep soundly at night.

The Attack turns into a listless verbal assault, batting easy back-and-forth arguments on fundamentalist dogma, bomber hero worship, the Occupation blues, etc., that simply rehash the usual talking points.
The movie essentially becomes little more than cool set pieces ... jammed together and interspersed with underdeveloped family-strife scenes.
A character piece should have some sense of a character's who, what and why, right?

[Neville] nails the sense of joie de vivre these extraordinary artists put into every note-a tribute to doing it for the love of the expression over stardom that provides incalculable amounts of inspiration.
The closer we get to a climax (and the more that absurd reversals keep getting piled on), the less effective Dupontel's brutish charisma is in keeping things interesting and afloat.
Quote not available.
It fails as a star vehicle, a recession-era satire, a WTF white-collar-grunt revenge tale, a Midnight Run-style buddy flick, a gross-out laughfest and a bathetic tale of broken souls.
There's slow-burning, and then there's simply slow; the difference between the two has never been so apparent.
A layered look at a man who was a jack of all trades, but a master of one: being George.
movie_title: Plimpton! Starring George Plimpton As Himself (2013)

movie_review_blurb: You'll leave knowing slightly more about the who, what and why of WikiLeaks; you'll also wish the whole shebang didn't fell like such a tone-deaf data dump overall.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: 'Part III' has curiously little interest in being even remotely funny.
Those unfamiliar with Verdi's tragedy won't understand why this production was significant, nor see much of the fruits of such hard work ...
It's both a sly piece of ethnography and a social satire that reads like a cosmic joke...right up until its climax makes the chuckle catch in your throat.
Once Venus and Serena flips through the duo's collection of greatest hits and hissy fits, it settles into a groove of lip service from famous people ...
A whirling tour of one man's wide-ranging thoughts that requires stamina but leaves you rewarded.
Little of the chops and charisma Buckley fils had in spades is channeled; this is still the usual Let Us Now Praise Famous Men karaoke session, wrapped up in some extra-discordantly warbled notes.
You never get over the feeling that you're watching modern actors play frontier-drama dress-up. It's a deathblow.
It's a tribute to Tiesel's ray of humanity that this chapter underlines its subtitle while still getting its unflinching message across.
Seimetz hasn't quite figured out how to sustain long-form tension; by the time this modest microindie noir starts laying its cards on the table, your attention will have already folded.

A sense of existential dread that would make the Russkie novelist beam is channeled beautifully, but for a filmmaker lauded for his minimalist aesthetic, Omirbayev sure loves broad-stroke symbolism and sloganeering.
What starts as a flipped survival tale turns into historical tragisploitation that wallows in its slog of endless suffering.
Part po-faced dramatization, part documentary and all affectless true-crime curio.
Experimental-cinema fans weaned on formal deconstruction and celluloid chaos will likely find their minds less than blown.
If any film could convince people that ACID is the patron saint of tomorrow's Godards, it's this one.
It may be a stretch to call the filmmaker a forgotten genius, but if nothing else, Le Grand Amour makes a case that Étaix was a fertile clown, overdue for a bow in the spotlight.

If the film occasionally bumps up against the limitations of its Spellbound-like template, its refusal to ignore the social issues outside of the classroom proves it's more than simply a novelty human-interest story with impressive knight moves.
A trite story of loosening up.
This is humanistic drama done right.
You never lose the nagging sense that you're simply watching a high-school drama club's production of '40s fatalism chic.
Even [Duris] can't fully salvage a last act that clumsily tries to sell the notion that white-knight altruism is the ultimate creative satisfaction.

Ohlin enhances the historical melodramatics with immaculate period details, but the film never finds the right mix of the epic and the intimate-the personal as seen through the 20th century's Euro-geopolitical turmoil-that it aims for.

No matter how many jokes about impotence, vomiting pigs, deviant movie stars and underground adult-entertainment you shove into a gross-out flick, there are few things worse than strained outrageousness.
Political satire requires a sure hand; this wink-wink attempt at milking the culture wars for comic commentary is downright butterfingered.
Whenever the film focuses more on Jarecki's hand-wringing than deconstructing the war itself, you wish someone would have looked the filmmaker in the eye and just said no.

The arbitrary insertion of black-and-white footage suggests Moon is more interested in channeling a bygone sense of style-when men always wore ties and things were in monochrome, dammit!-than in going too deep.

Kotcheff's beware-the-backwoods thriller takes an unholy pleasure in watching Bond, an actor who always looks as if he's just bitten into a maggot-filled peach, devolve from full frontal dude-ity into a beast.
Tweens might appreciate the sugar-rush ghoulishness; Famous Monsters of Filmland fans and discerning kids-flick viewers may find themselves reaching for torches.
Say what you will about this collection of less-than-feature-length films: There's truth in its advertising.
A paranoid police procedural, a perverse parable about the corrupting elements of power, and a candidate for the greatest predated Patriot Act movie ever ...
movie_title: Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion (2012)

movie_review_blurb: You can feel Chbosky's blood, sweat and tears oozing out of this highly personal project, but that holy trinity of fluids isn't enough to wash away the sense that you've seen this before-many, many, many times.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Plays like the most lyrical after-school special ever; it gives lip service to the teens' anxieties and euphoria while threading in the occasional swoonworthy image.
Even the show's disciples may feel like they've been cheated.
Barta's shorts are available on DVD; you're better off getting a dose of the uncut goods.
The Good Doctor is far more content to creep you out than to offer a critique.
An undercover endeavor that never feels as if much is actually being uncovered.
Markovics shows a keen attention to performers that you'd expect from a thespian-turned-director.
Canet's melodrama has earned the snarky sobriquet "the Gallic Big Chill" on the festival circuit, but that's giving this mush way too much credit.
The novelty of their industry aside, there's little to differentiate this from any other relationship-centered Amerindie.
Filling in the gaps about the who, what and where, much less the why, of it all isn't on the menu.
Refn may have lent his name as an executive producer and his blessing to Spanish director Luis Prieto, but the inventiveness of the original is MIA.
Once the visual touches fade away ... there's nothing to stop the parade of clichés.
Neither blind idolatry nor a definitive portrait; just a major missed opportunity content to loiter in the middle of the road.
This plotless assemblage of sandy-crotch improvisations simply feels cracked.

Everyone from Eric McCormack's caricature of a Southern candidate to Julie Bowen's celebrity newscaster are simply straw men for writer-director Bill Guttentag's argument that elections are a dirty business ...
Outré flourishes don't fully lift the story past the limitations of innocence-lost storytelling.
All but the hard-core Colferphiles slink out embarrassed, feeling as confused and discombobulated as if they too just took an electric bolt to the brain.
An intimate portrait of settling down and finally making peace with one's well-publicized past.
The film's notion that a little understanding and a lot of e-mailing would basically solve the Middle East crisis ... is as reductive as it is utopian.
movie_title: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea (2013)

movie_review_blurb: What, exactly, is the payoff for suffering through such painfully bad filmmaking for 93 minutes?
Rogen and Streisand have a genuinely complementary chemistry, feeding off each other in a way that suggests that, given a halfway decent script, the two would make a better-than-decent screen duo.
The film unintentionally makes the perfect valentine for the OWS version of radicalism: It's righteous, full of rage and cripplingly unfocused.

The interweaving stories of commercialized religion, rancid Americana and alcoholic wretches start wearing thin around the movie's midpoint; by the end, the whole morose endeavor risks becoming downright threadbare.
Watching [Travis] add his kitschy touch to such a witless, faux-edgy movie can only be described as a Travis-ty.
The intent is righteous. The dramatic overkill is deadly.
Sergio Leone's languid, lovely and lengthy ode to Lower East Side mobsters (more specifically, mobster films) ...
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)

movie_review_blurb: It's Cotillard who surprises: Too often cast as eye candy, she demonstrates a facility here for tiny gestures and facial expressions that suggest emotional arcs in miniature.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Remains a primo example that cinema actually traffics in truthiness 24 frames per second.
Mea Maxima Culpa only gets messier the more it tries to iris out to a larger indictment. The central tragedy ends up diluted to a fault.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: What's meant to be a critique of subjectivity in power comes off as narcissistic hoo-ha.
This isn't a film, it's a recording of canned ham-tasty, certainly, but creaky nonetheless.
Revenge may be a dish best served cold, as the novel suggested, but steamy adaptations simply can't be doled out lukewarm.
Its historical import as a peripheral civil-rights document can't be understated.
Flight doesn't quite soar past its narrative limitations. There's plenty of virtuosity to go around here-just precious little transcendence.

Crewdson's pictures are worth a thousand words, so it's not surprising that the sequences of him meticulously choreographing his eerie shots speak volumes. You wish some of that disciplined approach had worn off on his biographer.
No one is better suited to tell this story than Peralta, a documentarian who's both chronicled skating's evolution and contributed to it.
A fairly generic father-daughter story ...

It's only a slight exaggeration to say Kold gives what may be the performance of the year -- one that not only offsets the movie's momentary dips into self-conscious quirkiness but adds a genuine sweetness to the proceedings.
Grafts its heroines' uncouth behavior onto a weak satire of hedonism and high-school cliquery on the festival circuit yet, crucially, forgets the honesty.
Seems aimed specifically at folks who still subscribe to lad mags.
If this is still your bag all these years later and you wish the 1990s had never ended, however, then everyone wins.
The lack of dialogue may skew towards the experimental, but The Red Turtle's humanity is completely experiential in a way that matches the best Studio Ghibli joints.
There may be worse horror films than The Bye Bye Man this year, but there will be none that shows more contempt for its intended audience.
This is what curdled Americana looks like - a Joel-Peter Witkin portfolio come to life and a vision of jus' folks weaned on isolation, madness, and good old Type O.
We have long hoped that there might one day be a sequel. We need to be careful what we wish for.
You realize that the movie is not just a superior model of teen comedy; it may, in fact, be the equal of those beloved Eighties touchstones.
One character farts glitter and another poops cupcakes. You could not ask for better in-movie metaphors.
Every trip through interchangeable Middle American burgs and hormonal exchange between the leads is given a grungy-but-gorgeous reverie treatment. This land is their land.
Most of the movie doubles down on the mania and lacing the sugar-rush sensation with an almost lysergic sense of silliness.
The movie is an extraordinary self-portrait and an existential statement: I shoot, therefore I am.
The Existential Pondering-ometer goes into the red zone. There will be robots.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Filmgoers who've suffered through a summer of superheroes, supervillains and sequels/snarky reboots, we now have something that genuinely casts a spell on viewers.
Tall, dark, and brooding, Belgian actor Matthias Schoenaerts is the man you go to when you need bruised masculinity, International Cinema Division.
Zero Days is ... under attack from little stylistic worms that threaten to turn an otherwise solid doc on the evil that 21st-century hackers do into a hack job.
It's the way that Koreeda handles such quotidian details and detours of this quartet that makes all the difference.
Election Year's only real stance - besides be sure to vote in November - is that America is violence. God bless the U.S.A. God save us all.
An oddball and oddly affecting take on two misfits finding their metaphorical partner-in-crime match.
Tickled is near-impossible to take seriously, even as Farrier and Reeve's Nick Broomfield-esque bumbling blows the lid on a genuinely frightening individual.
Husson's movie is as much a hormonal mess as its characters, but at least it favors heart over hard-ons.
This is something that rhymes with 'blatant Shmoscarbait,' pure and simple, and it will get worse before it gets better.
And how much of the marionette-like tug you feel leading up to that pay-off will color how you view this exercise in big-screen D.I.Y. wish-granting.
You may leave being repulsed and repelled by them. But you will walk out seeing them, for better or worse, as fellow human beings.
Davies gives the book's - and its heroine's - sense of the agony and the ecstasy of growing up a gloriously personal touch.
By the time you get to the money shot of two lovers kissing in zero gravity, you'll either be deep in this movie's pocket or have fallen into a diabetic coma.
This is not so much a horror movie as a lookbook for one - an assemblage of scary-flick odds and ends slotted next to each other with the thinnest of connective tissue.
Back home, these kids might be considered betas by small-town jocks and snooty froshes. Contemporary Color turns them into next-gen Bowies.
Mostly, however, what you get is six characters in search of a cringe-comedy that can cohere around them.

You go expecting a World Cup qualifying round. You leave having just seen a decent enough exhibition match.

This is what it looks like when good ideas go bad. A sequel, naturally, has already been greenlit. Go orc yourself, Hollywood.
Quest speaks volumes about working-class life and the necessity of community, parenting, perseverance, speaking out, speaking up, hope.
There's too much undeniably impressive filmmaking to dismiss Thelma; there's too much uncertain storytelling to actually recommend it.
It's bad. A bit of a full-on Nesbøner, in fact.
Take out the classic-rock soundtrack, and it could be a vintage Hollywood story of competence, camaraderie and derring-do; only its title feels generic.
Walking Out settles into a comfortable survivalist-story groove, albeit one specifically designed to dehydrate emotionally repressed males one sob at a time.
What makes Brawl in Cell Block 99 work so well isn't the violence, however, but Vaughn.
Woodshock is both gorgeous and pretentious in equal measures, and it's hard to reconcile the fact that you don't get one without the other.
It's simply that Dheepan's cultural clashes are richer than its man-vs-thug ones.
Whether it's the "best" documentary of 2017 is a matter of opinion. But it is assuredly the most vital.
As for the people banking on Tupac getting his own Straight Outta Compton-level movie, well - we ain't mad at cha, All Eyez on Me. Just majorly disappointed.
The end goal this time out isn't just to sell a few more toys and Lightning McQueen lunchboxes. It's actually tapping into something deeper than a corporate bottom line.
You will almost assuredly leave The Hero knowing that [Sam Elliott] is a bona fide national treasure.
It's no longer a showcase primarily for the artist. Manifesto becomes a tribute to the actor - and to the process of acting itself.
It's telling that Poitras has assigned that particular name to her portrait of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange.
Long Strange Trip gives you a glimpse into the artists who risked their lives in search of a transcendental moment via the right combo of chords and camaraderie. It's not nearly long enough.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If its clip gets emptied before the characters' ammunition runs out, the film still hits its target dead-center.
The film's heroine is extraordinarily gifted. The film itself, not so much.
'All shell, no ghost' is a low-hanging-fruit diss. It's also apt.
This is harmless filler, the kind designed for long car rides and cross-country flights. It's a cinematic pacifier.
In terms of the female-body politic, it's an art-horror dirty bomb.
Mooney is the main reason to see Brigsby Bear, the sort of indie dramedy that wears its on-the-spectrum quirk on its sleeve.
What Garrone & co. have concocted is a Grand Guignol pop-up storybook, full of metaphorical dark woods and morality plays.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Less fuse, more detonation might have worked wonders.
It's a movie to admire rather than enjoy. You'll put your hands together for the powerful performance---and clap louder once it's over.
The past may never be done with us, but Lord, do we wish Franco was done with our literary heritage.
As you watch these actors, you appreciate the endeavor the climbers went through all the more-and as triumph turns to tragedy, you feel the grief winding its way through your shaken nervous systems.
A first-rate piece of forensic filmmaking.
The cinematic equivalent of a half-baked fruitcake.
It remains a how-to model for making something that fancies itself a slow-burn thriller-until it isn't slow-burning whatsoever.

An ode to a long-lost era of bohemia, an insightful look into male psychology and pathology, a valentine to the art of letter writing and an illustration of how the past is never dead, because it's not even past.
Zaytoun wants to milk a historical moment as a plea for tolerance; its only accomplishment is to channel the forgettable foreign-film exotica of decades past.
It's remarkably fragmented, tangential and all over the place, which may make it the ideal vehicle for portraying the OWS experience.
movie_title: 99%: The Occupy Wall Street Collaborative Film (2013)

movie_review_blurb: You wonder why Salerno thought the man who created Holden Caulfield would be best served by an abundance of sentimentalism, a stock sap-tastic score and some genuinely cheesy dramatizations on a black stage (the director is no Hollywood phony, but still).
The gorgeous cinematography and generosity to Plummer's emotive gifts almost make up for the mumbo-jumboness of it all. Almost.

The stars sell the cutesiness, and the rawness-equals-real go-nowhereness that seemingly infects every conversation in a microbudget indie, with equal professionalism and vigor; if they can't stick the landing in the end, it's because no one could.

While Stephenson and Brewster's big-picture attempt to tackle a sociopolitical issue from the most personal of perspectives lacks the state-of-the-nation impact of [Hoop Dreams], it doesn't mean you won't feel the pleasure of these kids' triumphs.
It's hard to say if Faith works better as part of a whole instead of a triptych's single panel until the trilogy is complete, but the unconverted may find this too much of a cross to bear.
We walk away knowing nothing about what made this revolutionary tick. He deserves a 360-degree portrait. What you get is a mini recap of a pioneer's life-a biOpic shuffle.
Farhani ... almost single-handedly carries the film; the range the Iranian actor displays here proves that she's destined for bigger things. Fans will just have to be patient.
Reducing complex relationship issues to a typical indie-flick blatherathon-complete with performances of varying quality and stilted dialogue-isn't helping anyone.
Do you find insults revolving around the words Marky Mark, churros and/or #YOLO hilarious? How about the notion of a dorky white kid flawlessly rapping TLC's "Waterfalls"?

Nothing works: not the haphazard stabs at conjuring a sweet-and-sour comic tone, not the reliance on people saying horribly inappropriate things in lieu of actual jokes, and not the one-note characters ...

That he [Nick Murphy] can't sustain the level of dramatic tension that Bill Gallagher's script requires (the movie is adapted from the BBC veteran's TV series Conviction) is a bummer, though you still get to bask in wonderful performances.

Elysium may point with a singularly pulpy brio toward where we could be headed. But in terms of how its fictional heroes try to transcend such brave new worlds, it's not showing us a future we haven't seen a million times before.
It's a near-perfect portrait of a domestic tragedy as a master-and-servant psychodrama, one that leaves catastrophic collateral damage in its wake.

A perfect storm of perversity, pre-Persona identity transference, prole pole-positioning and mutually assured psychological destruction, Joseph Losey's masterpiece immediately transformed the director from has-been Hollywood exile to European auteur.

[Viewers] won't find much here besides Langella's typically austere performance, some lazy character sketches (what's up with the one-note shrewish wife?) and the sensation one gets after having watched paint dry, painfully slowly, on a canvas.

Except for two contrasting (pot)shots-a dance-party ship bursting with vulgarians (take that, Berlusconi's Italy!) and night-swimming immigrants being beaten off a boat's prow-Terraferma's second half feels like a slow hike over too-familiar ground.
You'd have to go back to Half Nelson to find such a beautifully organic combo of spot-on performances, tough-love storytelling and tender treatment of deep-rooted emotional damage.
All Turbo does is give Reynolds, Paul Giamatti, Samuel L. Jackson and Snoop Dogg the easiest paychecks they'll ever make, and its corporate overlords the chance to sell a few toys.
The Square offers more than just pictures of a revolution; it lets you into the mind-set of those fighting for their future, and that makes all the difference.

Both Baetens and Heldenbergh do their best to sell the story's ups and downs even when the narrative gets bogged down with science-versus-religion ranting, yet you're still left with a movie a little too reliant on playing clawhammer on your heartstrings.
More than anything, The Wave's ability to sustain tension out of its tired scenario makes it even more impressive than its Me Decade ancestors.
Krisha is many things: a nightmare, a cry for help, a cringe-comedy with sobbing instead of a laugh track, a cracked family portrait, an apology and a valentine.

[In] Jeremy Saulnier's near-perfect nugget of a siege thriller...[g]raphic scenes of carnage are doled out sparingly but unflinchingly, while cinematographer Sean Porter gives each high-stakes encounter...a palpable sense of vintage nastiness.

Drawn, per a disclaimer, from period accounts of strange phenomena and psychotic breaks among settlers, Eggers's impeccably crafted, historically accurate creepshow wears its deep-dive research on its tattered gingham sleeves.
What we have before us is a case study on how to do shoe-leather cinema-and smart, A-list American moviemaking-right.

What this extraordinary work does best is drop us into the mind of an actor beset by insecurities, vanity-project hubris, and that inner critic who simply won't shut up, whisking us up into a dazzling, dizzyingly subjective whirlwind.
At its best, the movie works as a love letter to camaraderie-by-combat.
Imagine a cross between a David Mamet play and a violent UFC bout restaged in a music conservatory. You're halfway there.
It could have been so much worse; we wish it was a lot better.
You'd have to go back to Edward Yang's Yi-Yi to find a movie that approaches marathon-length running times yet still makes you wish it were twice as long.
An airtight demonstration of the maxim that no good deed ever goes unpunished.
Capital ends up being neither a high-stakes thriller nor a cutting commentary on real-world bad behavior. It's just CEO exotica, all dressed up with nowhere to go.
Stuart Murdoch's story of three Scottish misfits who start a band is rife with the kind of giddy thrills and hormonal flushes you associate with being a teen.

It's melancholy, moving and unmissable.
Though the brothers have created the polar opposite of a formulaic ESPN 30-for-30 episode, they don't chart Cooke's rise-and-fall arc in a way that lets you into his story.

Carax does not want to tell you a story. He wants to express, in the purest way he can, his infatuation with storytelling through images and genre conventions, performance and voyeurism, cinema and cinephilia.
For 91 minutes, the pleasure of the Guiteauxes' company is ours. We are ultimately the richer for it.

The one real takeaway here is not that things are tough all over, or that movie stars equate slumming with authenticity; it's that no actor should be asked to do a sexy dance to Crazy Town's "Butterfly." Ever.
Despite the class-conscious genre pleasures, independent cinema's foremost Zinn master feels slightly off his game.

What Reality loses in satirical momentum as it slouches through its second half, it gains in substance by positioning celebrity as the new cracked sainthood.
Intermittently intriguing, wildly uneven.
Infused with its namesake, this gentle tragedy is the filmmaker's least complicated work to date, a streamlined tearjerker that respects viewers enough to not jerk the tears out of them.

It tries to examine the contradictions of recasting a flawed reality through fiction-a significant notion that the film's precious structure and borderline indie-quirkfest vibe often dilute to their own detriment.

Anyone still doubting that the Claymation studio behind Wallace and Gromit deserves a seat at the grown-ups' table only needs to see its pitch-perfect collaboration with author-screenwriter Gideon Defoe...
Wallops its points across with stunning, sickening effectiveness.
Whereas Stoller and Segel did wonders with the formula in 2008's Forgetting Sarah Marshall, a certain overfamiliarity creeps in long before the going gets rough.
For those who aren't burdened by such things, the loopy, off-kilter pace and frontal-lobe frying provide their own unconventional pleasures.
Titillation and tentative stabs at gender studies do not a cogent cri de coeur make. It's simply a provocation that's all hopped up with nowhere to go.
It doesn't seem to display much of a point of view at all.

Whither the filmmaker who gave us such memorable monsters as Patrick Bateman and Valerie Solanas, or such complex females as Bettie Page? Someone has apparently stolen the director's identity and is making movies under her name.
Like its performers, The Lucky One isn't bad, so much as achingly banal, the sort of instantly consumable and forgettable factory-produced love story that leaves you with no impression whatsoever.
No one's asking for a somber account of simian life, but perhaps Buzz Lightyear could keep quiet for a bit and let the monkey business speak for itself.
Genuinely transcendent.
May be more nuanced than the usual Left Behind fire-and-brimstone sermonizing you find in much contemporary pro-Christian cinema, but it still leaves behind a sulfuric stink.

Viewers get ample time to luxuriate in the landscapes while gritting our teeth over Peter Coyote's pseudomythic narration and the sort of WTF meta touches that a first-year film student might find ridiculous.
Schemel is a major rock & roll survivor; Hit So Hard is a minor rockumentary at best, as well as a seriously missed opportunity.
You'll find yourself wanting to immediately go back to the beginning and reassess every conversation, every gesture, every long-held grudge.
There are exchanges, ambiguities and a noggin-scratcher of a final shot that I'm still mulling over days later, but the sense that this ground has been trod over many times has shaken my faith a bit.
The standout entry of the Directors' Fortnight sidebar and the closest thing to a masterpiece that I've seen so far here in Cannes.
What sounds like Huckleberry Finn on the page, however, ends up like a stock melodrama onscreen.
The notion that "love means never having to say you're sorry" sits there bleeding, a stake right through its broken heart.
movie_title: Nous ne vieillirons pas ensemble (We Won't Grow Old Together) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Essentially a mediocre character study dipped in sci-fi conventions and Social Security-age sentimentality.
Phrases are misunderstood! Tolerance for Euro-libertine ways are tested! Tame encounters turn into terrifying humiliations, because the French are, like, so crazy!
Sugar may help the medicine go down, but serving up the glucose in such goopy portions (especially when the elixir is the intriguing part) doesn't help anyone.
The film thankfully resists being either a typical coming-out movie or an ethnocultural curio, but it doesn't offer much insight into the twosome's attraction, platonic or otherwise, to each other.
The bespectacled Ayoade is the odd man out in the group, and his offbeat, eerily cheery reading of every line lends the movie its single aspect of unpredictability.
These images of security, technology run amok and multiculturalism bump up against some serious class issues.
Both de Léan and Storoge give you peeks at the genuine anguish lurking underneath the characters' narcissistic bluffing and porno posturing, even if the script drowns their best moments in verbosity.
Kaige's historical epic favors drama over action (though he doesn't skimp on violence ...), yet everything moves like it's on wuxia autopilot.
You get to acknowledge how one-dimensional the male fantasies of hot nerd-messiah chicks are while basking in exactly the same thing.
My faith that a truly important piece can be gleaned from these tales of costumed champions has been broken.
As a memento mori, It's the Earth feels a little lost in space.
movie_title: It's The Earth Not The Moon (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Only the overstylized, near-colorless cinematography offers any shades of gray (actually, nothing but shades of gray); everything else is rendered in the most black-and-white way possible.

You can see why Tinseltown took the bait, as the filmmaker is dirty and sleek in all the right places, even when he's being sentimental in all the wrong ones (notably in an extended, far too ambitious climax).

This orphan entry in the Duplass oeuvre exhibits lots of their trademark amiable amateurism, but no amount of flabby guys flexing to a Chariots of Fire-like score or random camera zooms will keep their sloppy indie from exhausting your patience.
Ted ends up undermining both halves of its whole, as well as its creator's clear intent to add something a little deeper to his crassness.
Alex Kurtzman's debut feature can emotionally manipulate you before the narrative house of cards collapses and things go from sweet-and-sour to full-on NutraSweet.
As an oblique critique of cultural continental drift, it works better as a cinematic experiment than it does as commentary.
Any attempt to look at deeper-rooted causes behind these assaults is completely AWOL.
A piece of lyrical, sideways social reportage that still connects an astounding number of dots.
The wounded characters eventually slouch toward redemption; the movie they're in, however, isn't nearly as lucky.
This attempt at an Altmanesque ensemble piece feels a little dramatically flat even as it's dazzling your retinas.
The result may occasionally be more of a journalistic scrapbook than a Wisemanian all-points portrait.
Advocates of bad-trip cinema, you may commence cult-worshipping this warped nightmare now.
Only the mighty Fonda cuts through the claptrap; the rest is just a long, predictable trip.
From elderly apparatchiks to cinematic continuity, nothing is sacred, as the director punctures the illusion of "civilized" society and viewer's frontal lobes.
Suddenly, the sneaking suspicion that you've merely been watching an extended PSA for the grassroots organization (Stand for the Silent) starts to take hold.
It's hard to tell where D'Elia's own psychotic cinephilia ends and the character's begins.
Couldn't be more clumsily obvious in its narrative setup or more flavorless in its lo-fi Americana tone.
Simply showing generations of pasty, fat men pounding each other to a pulp shouldn't be mistaken for an in-depth exploration of Gaelic machismo...
The film's turn toward charcoal-sketch notions of good and evil only fuels a simplistic view of historical tragedy in the worst sort of way.

There's such a graceful sense of restraint in how this real-life tragedy is treated, one that filters any potential for ripped-from-yesterday's-headlines sensationalism through a respectful requiem of loss and grief.
The Yellow Sea is far less interested in character than in choreographing pursuit scenes spiced with Asia Extreme levels of violence.
The title is an understatement.
The movie too often resembles a repetitive cycle of tough guys shouting, shooting and shuffling off this mortal coil.

movie_review_blurb: Harrelson's portrayal ... is perilously close to perfect; it's the finest, most harrowing thing he's ever done.
Erratic, occasionally WTF hilarious...

How Ritchie can expertly construct such set pieces as a train-bound assault, then thoroughly ruin every other action sequence with his signature self-indulgent slo-mo fetish and gratuitously stuttery editing, is an unsolvable mystery.
