movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
As clunky subplots and soap operatics start to nudge their way into the mix, the filmmaker seems unable to maintain that early tone and focus.

Anyone expecting an Arabic Army of Shadows will be disappointed; if a muted, moodier approach to the material befits the social-issue subtext, it also severely dampens the tension and pacing that makes these films thrum.
Zhang's mixture of unsparing violence, mawkish sentimentality and garish flourishes creates one uncomfortable aesthetic.
You'd swear Menkes were remaking Frownland in the Holy Land instead of tweaking a literary totem.
Unless you really dig Glee-level displays of high-school drama geekery, you and your date may want to quickly exeunt.
The movie's multitasking creator seems to have bitten off more then she can chew. Her friends should have advised "baby steps."
Don't even try to keep up with the labyrinthine plot and triple-layered identity confusion.
All whimsical tunes and postcard scenery, while piling on enough ogling shots of nubile young women to make Hugh Hefner feel uncomfortable.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: When the lovey-doveyness turns cloying and the atrophied message-mongering creeps in, you wish the threesome knew when to keep their traps shut.
Innocence was lost; so, apparently, was much of the insightful commentary.
While MacLean certainly has a keen eye, the rest of his storytelling facilities haven't quite caught up with it yet.
The tongue is in cheek and the tone is ironic and bleak, at least until the should-we-stay-or-should-we-go climax punctures the mood.
Every time the narrative's underworld schnooks and low-level lowlifes edge their way out of the periphery, a sense of snorting impatience takes over.
Only Kristin Scott Thomas channeling In the Loop's Malcolm Tucker offers a spark; the rest is simply hokum designed to land overly sentimental suckers hook, line and sinker.
All but the most ardent 'toon fans are advised to skip the Animated program, which this year traffics in nothing but Pixarish whimsy .
The film is perilously close to being an exercise in tactile but touchy-feely passive-aggression.
Giant jungle creatures lunge and hiss into the screen, projectiles appear to whiz past your face, and the whiff of vintage cheesiness reeks from easy gotcha! moments.
When Vincent Gallo's crazy-sleazy-cool act is the sole element of realism, there's a problem.
You're mostly left with facts, dates and iconic poses.
Even the title dispenses with unnecessary frills: A man escaped. What more do you need to know?
movie_title: Un condamné à mort s'est échappé ou Le vent souffle où il veut (A Man Escaped) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: Innocence is lost -- as well as 90 minutes of your precious, precious time.
Abandon hope, all ye who expect insight into what made this game-changing gent tick...
Donzelli has, against all odds, crafted a genuinely moving ode to both the tenacity of filial love under extreme circumstances and the toll it extracts.
By the time you realize how stealthy the film's critique has been, you've already fallen right into its trap.
What you don't get is the sense that this pumped-up combat-fatigue chronicle is pandering-or, for that matter, particularly original.

Anatolia wanders into an open-ended verbal bout between the laws of nature and the laws of man, yet the sense of actual musing, much less the mythic storytelling jokingly suggested by its title, dissolves from being to nothingness.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The moment-to-moment textures of Syndromes and a Century are so densely real in their minimalism that they make you suspend all interpretation and simply exist in the present.

This epic film, eschewing dialogue and conventional narrative logic, tells a gripping tale of biological drama through a highly improbable series of evocative images, superb acting and editing, and haunting music.
High Noon reflected the heightened fear of the Soviets in the '50s, now similar to the xenophobia that has been raised and further inflamed by our political leaders.

Time has passed for the Portokalos family, but everyone is exactly the same as the first time we saw them. Such a regressive aspect is just one of many problems that dwell within My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2.

Starring the very talented Bryan Cranston as the titular character, the film is not only a successful character study and biopic, it is also an engaging and entertaining glimpse at a very dark time in Hollywood's history.

The political landscape from which this film was born is apparent almost from the start, and though at times less than subtle with its agenda, it still manages to be an incredibly witty, emotional and entertaining movie experience.
Set in Puritan era New England, The Witch is an atmospherically driven, religion-coated film that is, at times, both beautiful and terrifying.

Starring Saoirse Ronan in a career-defining role (even more so than her first Academy Award-nominated performance in 2007's Atonement), it may just be among the finer historical period pieces in recent memory.

With the same goofiness and self-referential humor as a character like Spider-Man, but combined with the graphic violence most often seen in DC comics; perhaps Deadpool is just the perfect clash of contradictions.
Goosebumps finds that balance, managing to capture not only the charm of Stine's work, but the scares as well, without straying too far in either direction.
In the Heart of the Sea is an all-around disappointment. The film suffers from poor direction, an unfocused narrative, and some very underdeveloped characters.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: By simply presenting a true story in its most raw form, it ends up being an entirely believable portrayal of one of the most important cases of the past 20 years.
Though it is a mostly audience-accessible look at a devastating situation, it also does not shy away from the realities of just how something so drastic can change our reality.
It is at once a thoughtful, witty, intelligent, tense, and emotional experience, as beautiful in presentation as it is delightful in spirit.

Black Mass attempts to be something great; yet, when thinking back to it, it's likely only the acting that will be remembered. The film is riddled with common gangster tropes and underdeveloped characters.
Part sci-fi, part chase film, yet mostly a story about an unusual father-son relationship, Midnight Special is a one-of-a-kind experience.
The film suffers from an uninteresting plot, poorly developed characters, and a rushed, anti-climactic final battle.
Concussion does to the sports film what I was sincerely hoping it would avoid: it dramatizes its subject in such an unbelievable way that it becomes nothing more than mindless propaganda.

With some incredibly innovative action, some deeper, thought-provoking themes, and a plethora of dynamic characters, both old and new, Captain America: Civil War is among the very best of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
Passengers is yet another example of a film that falsely beckons a certain premise in its promotions, yet eventually delivers something far less interesting.

Somehow, The Shallows manages to just surpass the murky depths that most of those films sink to. It emerges as a surprisingly tense and entertaining thriller, though not one without its own set of unfortunate flaws and lost potential.
Whether a follower of the series from the start, or just hopping aboard, it's hard not to get a kick out of Rogue Nation.

Though with the talented Robert Zemeckis at the helm, Allied seldom showcases his trademark focused and proficient direction, which is therefore not enough to raise the film above its many aching flaws.
Though Moonlight employs a stylistic, arthouse approach as opposed to a traditional narrative, it is nonetheless an important one to watch for people of all walks of life.
In a Valley of Violence is a fusion and modernization of old genres, particularly Spaghetti Western, and though not without flaws, it is mostly an entertaining thrill ride.
At times overly violent, and with clunky exposition, Hacksaw Ridge is also remarkably realistic, as visceral an experience in a theater that you are likely to see all year.
Cynical and stylishly alluring, Nocturnal Animals is mostly a memorable success within the neo-noir genre and another indicator of the filmmaking talents of Tom Ford.
For a film that easily could have just been ripe with clichés, La La Land is instead refreshingly different, and is sure to be a hit with audiences as a result.
A Monster Calls stretches into the realms of imagination and dreams, yet it is very much grounded in the reality of life and loss.
Though intimate in scope, Silence has much larger implications; it might just be amongst Scorsese's finest works.
With a convoluted basis and disengaging story-line, Rings fails to instill the same slow-burning, primal scares that made the first film such a memorable success.

Where The Girl on the Train distinguishes itself, though, is in its forthright presentation. With unbearably over-the-top performances and direction, in addition to an unfocused purpose underlying the story itself, it is an almost unwatchable mess.

It has few standout moments and, in addition, doesn't have anything too deep or thought-provoking to say. Yet, if you simply wish to see a gun-slinging Western with some of your favorite actors, it's a least a passable couple hours at the movies.

By showing too much in an unfocused manner, the grounded reality of the Blair Witch legend is peeled back to reveal the very obvious paranormal story at its heart, making the sequel a dull and listless venture to sit through.
Though Sully doesn't push too far outside the boundaries of its genre, it still manages to be a subtle, understated representation of a very grandiose achievement.

It's not entirely forgettable, yet in our current world where even big stars don't sell movie tickets, The Duel had to have something more in order to really be successful. The film is an unfortunate misfire.

Unfortunately, like many dime-a-dozen horror films, Lights Out suffers from an all-in approach, choosing to simply attempt to scare the viewer by any means necessary rather than working on making it genuine.
The Infiltrator just manages to stand out amongst modern films. Bolstered by a strong cast and an engaging, based on true events story, it is a surprisingly enjoyable experience.
Though I still have faith in modern Westerns as a whole, I realize that Jane Got a Gun is one of many that will likely be forgotten in time.
Slow West is the feature debut of writer-director John Maclean. [...] it is also among the more unique modern westerns in the way that it plays around with traditional western tropes and conventions.

Although marketed as a supposedly progressive film about an important topic, it is, at times, almost unforgivably inaccurate. In addition to this, it is easily one of the most excruciatingly dull films I have seen all year.
Alex Garland's Ex Machina is a chilling view of the future of AI, brought to captivating life through the performances of Isaac, Gleeson, and Vikander.
The Evil Within is far from flawless, but it's hard to argue with Getty's devotion to this singularly distinguished work of art.
Though It does perhaps fall short with scares alone, the film delivers in nearly every other way.
Despite being 2.5 hours long, The Square is often bitingly original, and as a whole well worth the watch.
Not many movies really get under your skin like Lucrecia Martel's masterful epic.
As a movie about teaching, though, Madam Hyde works wonderfully. In contrast, the supernatural aspects of the film often feel tacked on and out of place.
Western is not a full-on, triumphant success, but in individual moments the film is just too delightful to ignore.
Last Flag Flying is a pleasant watch as a whole, yet it doesn't quite delve as deep as it could, and ultimately feels somewhat forgettable as a result.
The Dark Tower isn't a loathsome film. It's just not praiseworthy either, with the only highlights really being Idris Elba's performance and some passable action sequences.
Gerald's Game is a mostly faithful, almost entirely enjoyable adaptation of King's novel.
Three Billboards is yet another shining example of McDonagh's distinguished talent as a filmmaker.
Wonder is, in almost every conceivable way, a disaster. It's jumbled, unfocused, poorly acted, and undeservedly sappy.
In an age where 20-year-later sequels are often a disaster, relying too intently on nostalgic value of the originals, Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle stands head and shoulders above the rest.
We may never know exactly what was going on in Tommy Wiseau's mind when he created one of the worst movies ever made, but The Disaster Artist is a valiant attempt at understanding just that.

The film is the equivalent work of an artist, who, though beginning with a solid, well-rounded image...just didn't allow it to find the proper balance. In the end, perhaps The Shape of Water's ambition just exceeded its grasp.

It attempts...to be a wacky science fiction, a humanistic love story with a sci-fi premise, satirical social commentary, and even dabs of race and white privilege discussions. But in the end, it's too loosely spread out to fully succeed at any of these.

With originality, lively animation, and some powerful heart-strung moments, it will make you feel the same way as the five emotions in Riley's head, at least for a time (it's mostly Joy, though, by the end).
With such talent in front of and behind the camera, it's a shame that The Snowman's narrative and structural problems weren't properly adjusted before its release.
The Book of Henry might be brimming with talent, but in the end it's probably better left unread.
Bogged down by generic action and characters, a confused plot, and an overall sense of been-there done-that, The Cloverfield Paradox, after a momentary burst of excitement, will likely fizzle out.
It's the clear and defiant disregard for modern horror tropes that makes It Comes at Night such a refreshing watch.
Spider-Man: Homecoming is neither a full disappointment nor a complete triumph.

Convoluted, messy, and over-stuffed, The Avengers: Age of Ultron also somehow manages to be an incredibly enjoyable ride. Each of the actors bring their A-game, and each of their characters has their own moment to shine.
Although mildly entertaining at times, especially in the beginning scenes when we first see Chappie come to life, the film suffers from an uneven storyline.
Telling the story of a boy from age 6 to 18, and filmed over that same time, it is a beautiful, poetic journey of life, with all of its ups, its downs, and, of course, everything in-between.
If you're looking for a good time at the movies, with absolutely zero thinking involved, then you've come to the right place.

A Most Violent Year is a fascinating, intense, character-driven drama, which not only transports you to the state of mind of NYC in the 1980's, but will also show you just how entertaining simplicity can be.
The Imitation Game is a wonderful adaptation of his story, full of brilliant performances, an engaging directing style, and an exuberant soundtrack.

The Battle of the Five Armies is a lot more of the same, substituting mindless, even dull action at the expense of character development [...] there is just enough here to be passable, and it completes The Hobbit trilogy on a mostly positive note.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Miller has truly knocked this one out of the park. A home run if I've ever seen one, and one that I'm looking forward to experiencing again.

Horrible Bosses 2 is an inferior sequel in nearly every way - it has less laughs, less chemistry, and a much less compelling story, which doesn't even get going until more than halfway through the film.
It is a wondrously beautiful movie, with intense sci-fi sequences, a solid and talented cast, and even some thought-provoking ideas. This is not one to be missed.
It is a wildly entertaining film, from the action scenes, to the sets, to the soundtrack, and in addition, it will likely be known as the comeback role for Keanu Reeves.
Logan is a perfect bookend to Hugh Jackman's years of playing the role. To see him go out on such an exuberant high is much more than anyone could have asked for.
Rather than stretch the capacity of the original's themes, this remake shrinks them down to eye level, becoming a forgettable and ultimately pointless endeavor.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is nearly everything you would have wanted from a Marvel franchise sequel.
The Theory of Everything is the type of inspirational story that is so often told in biopics. It is beautifully shot, emotionally driven, and a masterclass in acting.
In part due to a shoddy translation from book to screen, and little effort spent on expanding its themes in compelling ways, The Circle feels like lost potential.
Director Jonathan Lynn cleverly combines broad slapstick, witty jabs at movie conventions, very dark humor, and wild sight gags into a lively mix that keeps the laughs coming.
Dey's pedestrian direction threatens to drain the fun from even the good stuff, by finding the least interesting way to shoot nearly every scene.
A wonderful surprise.
Smarmy sitcom material.
For boxing fans, it's a must see; and a solid video rental down the road for most everyone else.
What the animators lack in new computer-drawn technique, they creatively make up for with a fine artistic sense.
Stone simply attempts too much in Any Given Sunday.
Sophie Marceau is easily the best female foil Bond has had in years.
Toy Story was the best of the Disney resurgence of the last decade.
Actually nails the epic feel it is aiming for.
Laughably ludicrous.
This deliberately paced (to put it politely) drama, rarely kicks into high gear.
Dull turns to ludicrous, as action and plot twists fly at the audience from left field-- if not the bleachers.
This is one of the recent crop of British movies that relies heavily on whimsy and charm -- but very little else.
A mostly smart, well acted, and very well paced and atmospheric thriller!
Delightful!
The Legend of Bagger Vance has pretty actors, pretty words, and some pretty pictures, but is a pretty dull movie.
Reasonably entertaining.
The Muse will appeal to anyone who has ever tried their hand at a creative endeavor.
With bad acting, hillarious dialogue, and ludicrous plot turns that make this a future candidate for Mystery Science Theater 3000 mockery, The Omega Code lurches ahead in fits and starts.
Chill Factor is as fun as watching ice melt!
Nurse Betty is a touch more serious than Raising Arizona, but definitely lighter than Fargo. Best of all, it's in that league of movie making.
2 hours and 9 minutes of pure moviegoing pleasure.
Everything remotely interesting in this movie is overwhelmed by plot silliness and Basinger's terrible central performance.
An emotionally deep script!
Where else are you going get to see five Santas storm a bargain basement casino with guns a' blazin'?
Manages to get the setting, the characters, and best of all the spirit of Tarzan almost right.
It's the extremely natural performances by the three young actors -- particularly Heather Donahue, who deserves an Oscar nomination -- that brings it all together.
Bowfinger gives Eddie Murphy one of his funniest roles ever.
Unfortunately, the rest of the film is not as well thought out or expertly executed as the shocking conclusion.
The special effects may be state of the art, but ultimately, digital water looks like digital water.
Director Kevin Lima directs at a sluggish pace, gives us a few garish -- but not really interesting -- visuals, and the action scenes are amateur night.
The acting is quite good, with Banderas showing once again the charm and athletic ability he brought to The Mask of Zorro.
Russell Crowe is very good as the prickly, explosive Wigand.
Barely better than the pitiful Omega Code.
A stylish, witty and romantic romp!
Kids under 10 who love the cartoon, are apt to really enjoy this movie. Adults who remember the show with fondness, will find it easier to take than many kiddie matinees they have suffered through.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Director Sam Mendes presents some memorable images, and moments of Kubrick class clarity, but the whole does not hang together.
A.I. will have you leaving the theater shaking your head in disbelief.
This year, a summer would-be blockbuster that neither stinks, nor takes half the day to watch, is actually an improvement over most releases.
A rather tame flick intellectually, going for pop culture jokes and obvious political quotes, rather than the character-driven, satirical allegory of the original.
Funnier and faster paced than the slack Rush Hour.
Another wonderfully warm, funny, adventurous, and fantastic looking effort from Pixar.
A very good movie, and a faithful adaption of the book.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A great looking film.
In the last half hour, mystical ecobabble takes over, and the movie becomes nearly incomprehensible, plotwise.
Get thee to a theater and see what everyone is talking about!
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie that understands the American fighting man.
The best swashbuckler for most of the family since The Mask of Zorro.
... one beautifully made film.
When was the last time you were in a theater and the audience gasped aloud, not because an alien burst though a body, or someone's head exploded-- but merely because a character drew a gun?
The whole family will certainly enjoy The Rookie, but it's a special treat for fathers and sons getting ready for the upcoming baseball season.
This is one of the sillier Bonds, but the actors seem to be having fun, the pace is quick, and there's a lot to look at. At least it's not a bore like Tomorrow Never Dies.
Don't go to this movie if you've recently had hernia surgery, because the expression 'bust a gut laughing' might go beyond metaphor in your case.
Clever, funny, and even has a great lesson.
This movie is simply incoherent on every level -- emotionally, historically and politically.
That rarest of films --- a vehicle for two big stars that is also smart, deep, and well-written.
A clever and adventurous combination of The Princess Bride and Beauty and the Beast.
Ledger is an appealing hero, and the movie is harmless enough.
An uncommonly absorbing movie.
Will undoubtedly run alongside A Christmas Story on cable stations around the Christmas season for years to come as a staple of the Season.
At its best, Thirteen Days is as gripping as a good thriller and as informative as a good documentary.
Quite entertaining, and well worth seeing, if only for Hanks' sensational performance.
While the book has its share of contrivances ... This 95 minute movie rushes over everything so quickly, that the plot holes look an awful lot bigger.
Soderbergh deftly directs Traffic, keeping things moving with nary a jam.
Clooney's dumb version of his usual smart guy act works great, but his partners really steal the show.
Hip, furious, and darkly funny.
Hannibal should make everyone involved ashamed.
Instead of the swelling score and big Drama, Ememy could have used a little Three Kings sardonicism.
Not only terrifically entertaining, but has a great message, as well.
A very funny and likeable comedy of manners.
One of the most popular Westerns of all time, the heroic story of The Magnificent Seven has influenced countless other movies in nearly every genre.
The action-oriented, straight-up good vs. evil, moral- ambguity-be-hanged, Western star vehicle has never been done better than this.
A captivating, thoroughly enjoyable, romantic romp.
One of the world's greatest legends has been reborn as one of the year's greatest films; here's why it's true.
Jamie Foxx helms a warm-hearted comedy. It's entirely predictable, but it's a humorous good time.
It's thematically identical to its predecessor, but "Shrek 2" is still a hysterical knockout of a film. Fun, stylish, and totally irresistible.
Morgan Spurlock goes on an exclusive McDonalds' diet to prove that their food is high in fat & cholesterol. His experiment was as pointless then as his documentary is today.
Will Ferrell's commitment to sophomoric comedy is encroaching on religious zeal: "Anchorman" is Ferrell at his best.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Harry Potter fans, stand up and cheer for Alfonso Cuarón, who in taking the reins for the third film in the series, has finally infused energy and vitality into the franchise.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: "Two Brothers" is a wildly emotional, surprisingly delightful story of persecution, devotion and the triumphant determination of love.
No matter what you read elsewhere, don't dodge this flick; it's by far the funniest movie thus far of 2004.
Speilberg and Hanks make "The Terminal" an enjoyable flight, and not an interminable bore.
"The Notebook" is a story for those who believe that love is the most powerful force in the universe... or for those who merely want to.
"Don't See It" is the kindest phrase I can use to describe this film.
Frankly, I wanted to stand up, shout "Get a room" at the two characters, and do something more interesting... like watching paint peel.
The Ugly, The Bad, and The Good... totally in that order.
This flick attempts to take its audience across the entire spectrum of Hollywood genres in 80 minutes (give or take a few)... bad idea.
Braveheart meets the Round Table in this epicly atrocious version of the King Arthur legend. My advice is to follow the cast's lead and run screaming.
Tom Hanks and the Coen brothers revisit "The Ladykillers"... you'll either love it or hate it... I'm in the first category.
Folks, it's an instant gay classic that's bigger than a beehive... with heart to match.
"The Perfect Score" flunks its way right off the screen and right into the juvenile halls of film gone bad.
De-lovely might be decorous, but it falls significantly short of its own lofty artistic intents... in short, was should have been de-lightful is barely mediocre.
Disney has another hit on their hands with "Miracle"... it's not suspenseful, but it's great entertainment.
"Against the Ropes" has slim, sizzling Meg Ryan in its corner... but the film is a loosely-patched version of about twelve other movies.
If you're smart, you'll skip "Concessions of an Teenage Drama Queen" and buy $10 of stock in Comcast instead.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Gene Hackman and Ray Romano lead "Welcome to Mooseport" right into mediocrity.
Mel Gibson's personal vision of the persecution and death of Christ is relentless, brutal... and brilliant.
"Hidalgo" is a barely entertaining movie; what it does best is prove that Viggo Mortensen has legs
Intellectually demanding but ultimately satisfying, "Eternal Sunshine" plays to the strengths of its cast and well-bred creative team.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: "Scooby Doo" is back with an inconceivable feat: it's a worse movie than the first.
As far as the latest crop of repetitive superhero movies goes, Hellboy is heaven-sent.
Disney's latest epic is a solid, entertaining film - even if it adds nothing all that interesting to the legend of the Alamo.
Anne Hathaway's performance as a cursed maiden in this time-jumbled fantasy is enchanting... but the movie is not.
It's got enough cute love to keep the attention of teenage girls everywhere... but "The Girl Next Door" is too farfetched and contrived to be memorable.
Quentin Tarantino's unabashed revenge epic evolves into a full-bodied, daring climax in Kill Bill Vol. 2.
Sleek, sexy, savage and entirely too serious about itself... that's "The Punisher" in a nutshell... but three out or four ain't bad.
Will Smith is darker, sexier in his latest summer blockbuster... but despite an entertaining execution of Isaac Asimov's robotic visions, it leaves you cold.
Technically dazzling, thematically rich, and filled to the brim with holiday warmth, "The Polar Express" is an instant holiday classic. Climb aboard!
I was rooting for the sharks.
It might feel like a Dan Brown bestseller. But Americans have an appetite for historical mysteries... and capitalizing on that appetite is about as American as you can get.
The movie is present, sexy and fun, but it's probably time to give this franchise - and Snipes' permanent scowl - a rest.
Surrounded by talented performances, DiCaprio nearly pulls off a trick as effective as the illusive world cast by Howard Hughes: it almost looks like he can really act.
An emotionally-potent, visually-arresting picture that makes for one of the most enjoyable offerings of the season.
Damn you! Curse you! Lloyd Webber's caustically commercialized but well-directed musical comes to the screen in a colorful, expensive, thoughtless and overacted translation.
Proceeding from a ridiculous premise, this fish-out-of-water tale manages to create a passably humorous film for kids.
Dear Renée: We like your work. But if you put on forty pounds to recreate the moronic character of Bridget Jones one more time, we're going to take it personally.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Even Samuel L. Jackson's performance can't save this glorified press release from its "been there, done that" fate.
A powerful, stirring, necessary film.
Keanu's back in black, and in a 'hell' of a fun movie... what's not to love?
It's a blast... literally.
Perhaps the movie should have been called "Four Bridesmaids and a Hookah."
Heads out of the treehouse at an abominable crawl, but once the honey starts to flow, it picks up speed and becomes the sweetest film of the series.
It's not a surprising film, but "Win a Date with Tad Hamilton" is irresistable - the first film worth seeing in 2004.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Girlfriend should have stayed dead.
Pierce Brosnan and Salma Hayek attempt to heat up the screen in the action caper "After the Sunset"... but despite effective pacing, the movie barely reaches a simmer.
It's funny, dramatic, even heroic: "The Incredibles" largely lives up to its name. But you'll still leave the film feeling that Pixar left something on the table.
"Ray" starts out well... and then falls into the entrenched paths of just about every other overwrought, over-long musical biopic ever filmed.
Matt Damon and Paul Greengrass have created a fiery, quick-witted film that presents compelling evidence that the action-suspense genre has been "Bourne again."
Demme's visuals are as captivating as Frankenheimer's were in the 1960s... yet the plot of this "Manchurian Candidate" lost quite a bit in the translation.
Thunderbirds are GO! Head for this high-flying frivolity for fun, not brain matter. For kids of all ages, it's F-A-B.
Michael Cunningham's film is an alluring look at how definitions of love, friendship and loyalty are ultimately self-defeating. It's got a few flaws, but a big ol' heart.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx give the movie tension and momentum, and director Michael Mann gives it something most action flicks lack: style.
Without a paddle lives up to its name; it sinks.
I suppose it could have been worse: it could have been longer.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The mythology of "Star Wars" with the stylized flair of 1940s film noir, digitally dreamed and superbly acted. Say hello to what could be the best film of 2004.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The most entertaining part of Christian Taylor's "Showboy" is deciphering fact from fiction... and that's not a compliment.
Made me long for my free nights and weekends.
Filmmaking of least resistance, in which true heroism is exploited for emotional spare change.
Evokes "The Sopranos" under water, its lack of innovation akin to a boulder tied around its feet: "Shark Take" sinks to the bottom and quietly drowns.
Peter Berg's skilled vision and Billy Bob's retrained performance result not only the best football film we've seen in years... but also one of the best movies of 2004.
Its wit is played at the expense of unexpected targets... still, "Team America" is a descent into truly offensive, hysterical satire.
Cute. Waltzes right past "airy" on its way to the Sugarland Express. Keep your insulin handy.
Halle just hacked a hairball all over the summer boxoffice. And it ain't pretty.
"The Butterfly Effect" tries to prove that small actions have big effects... but it really proves that January movies tend to suck.
Brittany Murphy and Dakota Fanning can't rise above a weak script in this riches-to-rags tale; "Uptown" is low-rent.
"Shattered Glass" is sharp filmmaking; one of the better independent offerings for 2003.
It's not perfect (it's a sequel after all), but the latest Lara Croft film is smart, sexy and great summer fun.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This time the Terminator is fighting a girl in this high-tech race to Judgement Day. But save for the ending that sets it up for T-4, we are left wanting more, much more.
Let's end the suspense, shall we? This Sean Connery vehicle is not the summer blockbuster we hoped for.
Even the voices of Brad Pitt, Michelle Pfeiffer and Catherine Zeta-Jones can't save this movie from just feeling "blah..."
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Cameron, Lucy, and Drew are back as the Angels, with Bernie Mac and Demi Moore spicing it up. You'll clap along even as you realize how plain dumb it all is.
Is it too late to vote them off? For once, we don't have to tell you how bad a film is... you knew before they made it.
Helmed by a modern auteur and featuring a stellar case, "Le Divorce" could have been a good film... but ironically it fell prey to lack of direction.
As sequels go, The Matrix Reloaded is every bit a dynamite film. But it's more loaded than reloaded.
It might be spellbinding, but the theming of this indie documentary is mismanaged and it lacks a voice for its subject matter.
As if we needed feature length versions of MTV's "The Real World," served up this weekend is two hours of Cancun hysteria. Is it real? Yup - real dumb.
Joel Schumacher's latest film is a thrilling, suspenseful 90 minutes... and it's great entertainment.
Hillary Swank and Aaron Eckhart lead the latest adventure to save the world from natural forces... YAWN.
Irreverent but perhaps not funny enough, "Bringing Down the House" gives Queen Latifah the chance to shine opposite Steve Martin.
It's insipid, and Will Ferrell streaks through it naked. No, it's not an SNL skit... it's the latest college frat film, and it's marginally ok at best.
The summer has arrived, and with it possibly the best sequel we'll see this year... The X-Men are back, and back with style.
There's bad, there's "so bad it's good"... and then there's this moronic film.
The latest Kevin Costner vehicle is his best in years... and if you can get past the slow pace of the flick, it's a welcome change from this summer's other offerings.
Evan Rachel Wood, Nikki Reed and Holly Hunter give hard-edged, brilliant performances in this gritty coming-of-age drama. A must see!
Sensual, luscious, vibrant filmmaking, and not a single frame of it is tepid or mundane.
Jack Black winds up and throws us a rock and rolling good time in this classroom comedy caper.
Denzel Washington's newest thriller is a lackluster piece; it's all been done before, and far better by others.
Cate Blanchett and Joel Schumacher bring us a brutal, but worthwhile, film.
Cuba Gooding Jr. and Beyonce Knowles bring us a rousing film about a gospel choir... too bad it goes straight to hell.
This rousing adventure starring Johnny Depp, Geoffrey Rush and Orlando Bloom gets off to a slow start, but for summer entertainment this year you won't find a better film.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Gory, unsettling and downright suspenseful, this tour de force from the director of "Trainspotting" has moments of brilliance, but it's just not scary enough.
Look past the ill-conceived story and this camp-y summer fling will have you theatre queens rolling in your seats and dancing in the aisles.
Ellen Degenerous and Albert Brooks lend their voices to the craziest fish ever to talk on screen, and Dame Edna (Barry Humphries) performs a turn as a vegetarian shark!
It's cute, and Jamie Lee Curtis is wonderful as always, but this Disney remake just isn't funny enough. Take your family, not your critical sensibilities.
"Nightmare on Elm Street" and "Friday the 13th" fans... you are going to LOVE this one...
Jeepers, Creepers. Can't anyone make a decent horror film anymore?
Antonio Banderas and Salma Hayek co-star in this continuation of the El Mariachi story... but it's Johnny Depp who steals the show.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Rough-hewn and vigorous, Karim Aïnouz's first feature film tells the story about an illiterate 1930s drag queen... and it's surprisingly good.
This flick explores the subjugation of promiscuous women at the hands of an order of nuns; if you're looking for fun at the movies, look elsewhere.
It's hard to believe that this drivel was based on a book... but Matthew McConaughey and Kate Hudson make it somewhat tolerable at least.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: "Something's Gotta Give" gives us a good first hour... then it just gives up.
It's questionable whether Michael Cunningham's book could ever be adequately translated into film... and this version, while rewarding, isn't quite up to the task.
Steven Spielberg's new film is lighthearted and enjoyable, with just enough undercurrents of human frailty to keep the story interesting.
Russell Crowe proves himself master of the motion picture epic genre once again in a sea-faring picture sure to get you cheering.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Parker Posey and Olympia Dukakis lend their talents to an AIDS suicide film - it has its moments, but the death rattle comes from the genre, not from the central character.
Edward Zwick and Tom Cruise deliver an energetic and compelling film in Last Samurai. It's not a thematically original film, but it's great holiday fare.
The latest Eddie Murphy flick is more like the amusement park ride than Disney probably intended: it's fun for kids, but for the rest of us it's a bit of a bore.
HBO's two-part, six hour epic adaptation of Tony Kushner's "Angels In America" is a tour-de-force of masterful storytelling, with a stellar cast and vital theming.
Adheres to the values of its predecessors - it's brilliant, passionate filmmaking... even if it goes on far too long.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Disney's latest full-length animated feature is a pretty "un-bearable" romp.
Leaves you luke-warm.
It's lovely and entertaining, the type of British film which makes you wonder why the simplicity of the human condition continually evades the grasp of Hollywood.
Ben Affleck's latest action flick comes on strong, but ends up just another action flick without sufficient funds.
Steve Martin plays by the numbers in "Cheaper by the Dozen"... but it's a funny family flick nevertheless.
The latest version of J.M. Barrie's book hits the screen... alas, all we got was a shadow of the tale.
It was a bad enough TV show; moving this puppy to the big screen was a huge waste of space.
In a phrase, "The Company" is like the ballet it celebrates: you're going to have to invest patience and determination to appreciate it's artistry.
Sir Ben Kingsley and Jennifer Connelly provide memorable performances, but this morose film is far too boring and depressing to recommend.
There's not an ounce of meat in this Christmas ham - it's just the usual hollow holiday hype from Hollywood.
Let the suspense end... it's a fantastic film on many levels.
Charles Busch channels Joan Crawford, Bette Davis, Lana Turner and Susan Hayward in the lovingly crafted "Die Mommie! Die!" - this you HAVE to see!
Martin Scorcese delivers an enormous blowout of a film, a biopic of New York in the 1800s... but it's too much bombast and far too loose.
Equally as compelling as its predecessor, and perhaps more technically awesome, Peter Jackson's second Middle Earth chapter is, as expected, very, very cool.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This piece of fluff is nothing more than a wanna-be "Pretty Woman." Pass, please.
How much more of this can we take? Nemesis is a decent film, and Trek fans will love it. But enough is enough!
There is exactly ONE scene worth watching in Rob Schneider's latest pathetic romp... is it worth ten bucks? No way in hell.
Bring your patience to the latest Jack Nicholson film... it's very slow, but very rewarding.
Halle Berry gives a go at the 007 franchise, working with Pierce Brosnan to show us a ripping good time.
It's a depressing reality to face, but the second of J.K. Rowling's boy-wizard books was the least interesting read... and hasn't fared much better on film.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Just in time for Halloween comes Gore Verbinski's chilling-to-the-bone suspense ride... guaranteed to have you biting your nails long after the film is done.
The first five minutes of this film rate as perhaps the best film opening ever... they're worth the price of admission alone, and so we need say no more.
Jodie Foster locks herself into a room for nearly an entire film... unfortunately, she probably should have done that prior to principal photography.
Gwyneth Paltrow portrays American writer Sylvia Plath in this torturous biopic... it's good, but sufficiently interesting only for history/writing aficionados.
John Grisham's latest film has John Cusack, Gene Hackman and Dustin Hoffman at the helm... and they steer this smart, slick, explosive story right into box office bliss.
Quentin Tarantino, Uma Thurman and Lucy Liu take us to the edge of taste, over the cliffs of gore, and right into pop culture sublime.
Richard Donner brings us the latest Crighton film, sending Paul Walker and Gerard Butler back to Medieval times. The book was medoicre at best... this adaptation is insipid.
The curtain on "Chicago" goes up this week, and with it the resurgence of movie musicals... if anyone else can make one this good.
A gem of pacing, humor and fun... for those of you keeping score, that's exactly how a movie should be made.
Amusing to experience, but forgettable... an organic Hollywood behemoth that merely hitchhikes on the fame of Adams' celebrated novel.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's creepy for sure... but it's a dead ringer for every Hollywood horror sequel ever created
Hot: who knew Beowulf took on Grendel in the buff? Zemeckis scores big in this groundbreaking, entertaining, must-see holiday release.
Innovative concept meets gratingly dull plot. Take your 9-year-old, but bring your No Doze.
Burton delivers a less comic, more appealing Sweeney Todd in this Johnny Depp tour-de-force. Frankly, it's bloody great.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: From its subject matter, you;d swear this would have been the most boring film of the year - instead, it's smart, sassy and endlessly entertaining.
Blair Witch meets Godzilla in this hugely enjoyable shake-fest.
A serviceable, hypocritical thriller that would have been an utter bore-fest if not for Diane Lane.
A poetic joy: if you can suspend your subscription to the definition of film Hollywood has groomed us to accept, you'll love this film.
The little-prehistoric-epic-that-could actually delivers an entertaining couple of hours.
From cell block to superhero in a matter of a few years. Can Robert Downey Jr. do it? You bet your metallic butt he can.
Unabashedly seditious in the vein of their previous movies, the Wachowski's "Speed Racer" has serious flaws, and barely enough color and speed to appeal to half of its target audience.
As a continuation of a series that's captured the hearts of two generations over the last twenty-five odd years, it rocks.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that de-glorifies sex into a tool used for career advancement, altruistic joy and in lieu of "thank-you" note? Sign me up!
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Who'd have thought the year's most romantic on-screen duo would be a couple of robots?
The tragedy of "Hancock" is that Will Smith is so damn good in it.
Despite structural deficiencies, 'Stop-Loss' is a riveting assault on the Pentagon's abuse of power during the Iraq war.
Fun from start to finish, Hellboy tries to bridge the gap between fanboys and their parents. And it succeeds -- in part thanks to Barry Manilow.
Occasionally, a film comes around that is so bad it's hilarious. This is not that film. This film just plain sucks.
Please, please don't make a fourth.
Hilary Swank wades through bitchin' plagues and comes out looking hot. Film at 11. DVD at 11:30.
Anthony Hopkins and Ryan Gosling lend taut, entertaining performances to this predictable, but smartly executed, film.
Dunst sings, Maguire stagnates, the script sags, and goo from outer space takes center stage. Here's what else is wrong with 'Spiderman 3.'
Playing a teenage tramp is not the best way to adjust a degrading public image. Georgia Rule.
Shrek returns in a warm-hearted film that takes the next step in his character evolution - and keeps us laughing all the way.
Captain Jack returns for the climactic conclusion to Disney's swashbuckling trilogy %u2013 and Keith Richards notwithstanding, the movie rocks.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Martial arts hysteria, ping-pong wit, and even a bevy of gay sex slaves. What's not to love?
Mr. Brooks proves an unusual, occasionally awkward blend of suspense, drama and camp that's surprisingly fun.
Michael Moore takes on the American health care system with grit, determination, and - believe it or not - subdued arrogance.
The film suffers from a second-half degeneration into CGI battles devoid of human interest - but it's still a high-speed, energetic, must-see action flick.
Suspenseful and dark, this new Harry Potter is a stylish transition of the franchise on nearly every level: its mood, its plot, and most dangerously, its audience.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A fast-paced, hugely-entertaining romp that'll have you dancing all the way home.

The seditious accomplishments of "Chuck and Larry" may be entirely lost on millions of Sandler fans, who will squirm through their laughter and ultimately come to understand what intolerance feels like.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: We're unsure if there's to be a fourth film in the franchise; but if there's not, Jason Bourne's going out in real style.
Smartly done: 'Evan Almighty' is a preposterous, moderately funny film that will warm the hearts of millions.
Remarkable for it's visionary thematic sprawl... and unforgettable for the individual performance of a single actor.
It's ok. Drop your troubles at the door and dance along. After all, it's ABBA. Who can resist?
I laughed until I cried.

For fans of the late Michael Jackson who are hoping that Kenny Ortega's edit of the pop king's rehearsals will slash through the public vilification and help us rediscover his beloved music, this really is it.
In the proud tradition of Roland Emmerich movies, "2012" is incredible in every sense of the word: totally not credible, and yet hugely entertaining.

If you're a romantic at heart who doesn't mind shelling out $12 to watch a couple of adolescent boy hotties strut their stuff, you might as well just go and enjoy the eye candy. 'Cause it's kind of worth it.
A run-don't-walk cinematic experience that, if it won't actually change the medium (as the film's trailers espouse), will absolutely remind us of what's good in it.
Victorian clothing, things that go bump in the night, and Anthony Hopkins in a tiger-skin robe rattling around an oversized mansion, chewing the scenery. What's NOT to love?
A serviceable mystery/thriller that nevertheless feels emotionally scattered and for some, predictable.
Heartfelt, whimsical, well-performed... and pretty damned boring.
Depp and Burton's take on the Wonderland franchise is frivolous and feckless, a charming little pleasure to welcome the warmer weather.
It's a rush, but it's more like taxiing than take-off.

After the anemic Kevin Costner version of years past, Ridley Scott's "Robin Hood" arrives with just the right amount of historical gravity and production largesse; but in giving over merry men for gritty action, the story bears no resemblance to its swash
The best since the original! Dead funny, imaginative and hip %u2013 and if Shrek goes out on this note, it's a good thing.
Jake fans will love his sleeveless arms and long hair %u2013 alas, the rest of the film is hardly as memorable.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Pixar does it again - that is, they take a bunch of animated toys and teach us all about the human heart in an entertaining, magical way.
Nick Cage and Jay Baruchel do their best to deliver more than perfunctory Disney live-action fare, but ultimately nothing can rise above this ill-conceived storyline.
The classic "fish out of water" plot has been charmingly and effectively retooled for Vikings and dragons - in a word, it's adorable.
The brothers Coen deliver a taut, vastly entertaining dissertation on the imbalance of life.
Kinda stupid, kinda funny. It's the ultimate fall film.
I actually feel stupider having watched this film.
We've seen this all before -- but rarely in such an entertaining format. Eagle Eye is like watching an entire season of 24 in two hours flat.
An entertaining film that transcends biopic (for its own good) and offers a Texas-sized parable about politics.
I so wanted to hate this movie - and I was doing well until halfway through, when I actually started to feel nostalgic and happy. Damn!
This movie is great - just not in any of the ways you'd expect.
Put simply, it lacks fangs.
A digital hamster takes on Pixar's industry domination - and kicks butt.
Simple, beautiful, important and grounded. All of which, in Baz Luhrmann's hands, bored me.
Valkyrie is an important film for purposes of partial exoneration of the German nation vis-à-vis the Third Reich; nevertheless, it's a bit of a snore.
Right... 'cause what we really need right now is a movie about the unstoppable inevitability of bank corruption.
A hip, relatively precise interpretation of the popular '80s graphic novel is the film's greatest strength -- and it's greatest weakness.
It might seem awfully mean to critique a nature documentary released by Walt Disney on Earth Day -- but that's exactly what I'm about to do.
The charm of "The Boys and Girl from Country Clare" might be compared to the charm of Ceili music: infectious in its beat, but after a while it all sounds the same.
movie_title: The Boys and Girl from County Clare (2004)

movie_review_blurb: As usual, Meryl Streep steals the movie; but thanks to strong writing by Nora Ephron and delightful additional performances by Amy Adams and Stanley Tucci, "Julie and Julia" might steal your heart.
The real reason Paramount Pictures didn't screen "G.I. Joe" for critics: they were afraid of reviews like this one.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully-entertaining suspense thriller that reinvents and recharges the alien invasion genre.
In this lighthearted homage to the homoeroticism of figureskating Will Ferrell has delivered an unusually funny flick.
This surprisingly entertaining movie defies its formulaic plot and delivers a well-executed tale of team spirit.

A blockbuster that satisfies both the die-hard aficionado and the newcomer to the Terminator brand, with just the right mix of action and self-aware humor to overcome the film's emotional deficiencies.
The first must-see movie of 2007.
As usual, a cool Ray Bradbury story has been translated into a horrifyingly bad film.
The first half plays like the best exorcism film yet produced... the second half plays like an elongated episode of "Law and Order."
Corpse Bride" has the same visual flair and devilish humor as "The Nightmare Before Christmas," but it's a much more charming film.
Brian Grazer and Jodie Foster have delivered a hugely entertaining, if highly flawed, thriller at 30,000 feet.
Slick and sassy, it's not the greatest movie Disney's ever made... but it's closer than we've seen in a while.
As a dissertation on suppressed male aggression, it's a compelling movie. As entertainment, it's visceral but mildly unfulfilling.
Dumb as dirt.
Clooney's second film as a director is ambitious and brilliant, but ultimately proves somewhat dry and inaccessible.
Julianne Moore delivers another hard-hitting performance as a 1950s housewife - and despite being too earnest to be entirely believable, it's a highly rewarding film.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The movie gives us nothing productive - save the unfortunate realization that Orlando Bloom can't dance.
DOOM Fans, rejoice! The movie might not be intellectually stimulating, but it's huge fun.
Despite its flaws, a swashbuckling, frenetic, fun family film.
I'm pretty sure it doesn't get more depressing than this.
Cute, but largely unmemorable.
Hugely entertaining and entirely self-serving, "Domino" is likely to be raped by the critics, and then loved by its audiences.
Spurns a war movie's expected bloody confrontations for a dry, hot exploration into the ability of the human spirit to survive, scarred but whole.
At last - the perfect summer film. Wes Craven delivers a quick, tense high. You gotta go!
Full props for story and acting, even if the slow pace and predictable racial profiling of this thriller half-mires it into the Louisiana swamps it celebrates.
Unfortunately, while the technology used to bring these fearless crime-fighting faves to the screen has grown-up, the producers forgot to mature the script.
Sandra Bullock and Marc Lawrence bring us a sequel that's just as "congenial" as the first movie... and that's a unique achievement.
It's easy to appreciate the artistry of Sin City... but equally hard to appreciate the film.
Go see it -- the perfect antidote to the overly-intellectual horror films we've suffered lately: a scream-a-minute, lighthearted thriller.
Smart moviemaking win out over dumb politics in "The Interpreter," the latest - and thus far the best - thriller of 2005.
In the tradition of Gladiator and Braveheart comes the latest Orlando Bloom epic. Yawn.
Gritty but totally unfocused: it could have been great, it if weren't straddling four genres.
At last ... Lucas brings forth the long-awaited, well-earned kick-*** conclusion to the latest Star Wars trilogy. Fans will cheer!
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's a new beginning for the bat... and a must-see summer movie for 2005.
The script skates between tense and trite - but the chemistry between Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie is irresistable.
Earth goes to war, but Spielberg merely goes back to his aging bag of tricks.
Looks like the sweetest truffle... goes down like a sourball.
"The Dukes" are back... and the film happily hits the right balance between stupid and fun: you know, everything we loved about the television show.
Unfortunately, there's too much deadweight in this listless, unfunny dreck - and it starts with the lead.
Technically brilliant - but pathetically ignorant.
Welcome to Potter in PG-13... hip, heroic, humorous and... dare I say it? Harry's a hottie!
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Aficionados of the comic book will cringe... but hey, it's a fun popcorn flick.
'The Producers' lives on in this whimsical, wonderful romp - a notch better than the original film, and a surprisingly apt adaptation of the Broadway show.
M. Night's self-absorption is approaching the level of irritation -- here it has all the subtlety of a brick applied to the head.
Weighing in on "World Trade Center" is difficult; it's well-crafted, but it's also sluggish and meek.
A stylish, energetic romp of 1930s flair with two platinum-selling artists kicking the tires of Hollywood paradigms.
This entirely average Disney drama sports nuanced performances and little else.
A tour de force performance by Forrest Whittaker makes this Idi Amin biopic a compelling, challenging, edgy film.
A beautifully crafted film that's also egregiously violent -rightfully so.
More swordplay, more swashbuckling, more Jack Sparrow. What's not to love?
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's all about prestidigitation, folks - and Nolan's hugely entertaining film performs the best sleight-of-hand this side of Vegas.
Fortunately, this completely ridiculous plot is somewhat salvaged via the casting of a quality actor. Unfortunately for Denzel Washington, he's the actor.
Wants to be 'Hostel,' but it's just half-witted.
Crisp direction by Bill Condon and a stand-up-and-cheer performance by Jennifer Hudson make this flick a dream.
Eddie Murphy reaches into his comedic closet and pulls out a hysterical hit.
Jonathan Larson's heartfelt story shines through - despite the best efforts of director Chris Columbus.
Follows in lock-step with the book and populates its titular fantasyland with CGI creatures... neither idea was very good.
In the film, Bond must gamble to survive and grow; the producers of this franchise did the same - and in both cases, the chips are up.
Nothing can stop Superman: not bullets, not plot holes, and certainly not mere mortals like the occasional movie critic. A gravity-defying success!
Despite a compelling mission for unearthing the exploitative nature of the term "war hero," this picture has limited appeal.
The plot is basically scrap metal; but for those who appreciate high-paced motor stunts, this heart-pounder lives up to its name.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The most important gay film in a decade - a must see.
Despite its overarching Christian themes, Narnia delivers an entertaining yarn.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: 'It's a Wonderful Life' with fart jokes.
One of the season's most enjoyable films - even if it's a wee bit overlong.
The most intelligently directed film of the year, 'Munich' is a political thriller that sets its stage in 1972 and plays out in 2006.
Harrison Ford returns to the big screen in a mediocre action thriller, a joy to watch but nevertheless miscast in a blatant exploitation of his fan base.
Even performance and plot deficiencies can't stop a husky from emoting effectively on screen. Charming!
Silly, lighthearted, funny - and despite a slow start, ultimately charms its target audience.
Like a moderately exciting amusement ride; occasionally fun, but after years of riding this same plot, the same old twists and turns get awfully tiring.
An over-clever, underwhelming caper that's largely undeserving of its director and cast.
Can Michael Douglas still command attention at the fore of an action film? Yes%u2026 but it's perhaps the only interesting facet of "The Sentinel."
A thrilling third chapter that delves deeper thematically while expanding the universe of franchise characters. Thus far, it's simply the most X-citing film of 2006.
Yes, the plot lacks realism. Yes, Cruise is unrelenting as ever he was. Yes, the action never stops. Which simply means 'Mission: Impossible III' is 2006's first great popcorn flick.
Monotonous, colorless and entirely too serious, the film self-flagellates all the fun out of Dan Brown's story.
Spills blood more political than corporeal, potentially endangering its box office yet certifying its future as the most talked-about film thus far in 2006.

'Titanic' went down to the tune of $600 million, so it's no surprise that 'Poseidon' is now rising from the depths. Action-packed yet thematically barren, it will rivet audiences, if only momentarily.
Dupree sustains its groove for the most part, and in this summer of bloated spectaculars, it feels tight. It may be silly, but it's a pleasant enough diversion.
Alert readers spotting similarities to Willy Wonka should now reward themselves with a handful of Everlasting Gobstoppers.
The Simpsons Movie was expected to raise the bar for animated film -- especially 2-D animation. Unfortunately, it's just another example of what could have been.
Matthew McConaughey is the MVP of We Are Marshall.
[Director Nancy Meyers] hits all the notes of the chick-flick formula -- heartbreak, ice cream, Aretha Franklin -- but she never creates a melody.
Talladega is full of fun moments and funny performances that are more engaging as bits than as a cohesive narrative.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Jared Hess has made another sweet PG-rated movie populated with determined oddballs in surreally timeless settings.
If you ever want to produce an adaptation of a Stephen King story, call Frank Darabont.
When you're more intrigued by the appearance of Richard Chamberlain than the film's final courtroom denouement, you know this union of movie and moviegoer was doomed from the start.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Hitman is another cynical attempt to make some cash off the gaming crowd, but gamers arenâ(TM)t stupid. This is a film thatâ(TM)s made for someone who finds word balloons in comic books too complicated.
This sequel is inferior even to its predecessors (three, if you count the prequel The Scorpion King), themselves poor versions of the George Lucas-Steven Spielberg franchise.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Some of Book of Secrets is quite ridiculous, but in a film that plays fast and loose with history and reality, nothing is impossible.
Jumper is a special effect in search of a movie.
"Zellweger's Lexie isn't some silly sexpot or spoiled simp; she's a thoroughly modern moll."
That Kit largely succeeds is testament to not only its timing but also its craft.
While it's nice to drop in on Scully and Mulder again, moviegoers new to the franchise might have trouble drumming up empathy for this odd couple.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's the finest 97-minute advertisement for Yoda underpants released this week.
It's not that the film is too complicated, it's just unwieldy.
The film slowly and deliberately builds a head of righteous indignation; along the way it becomes a sort of feminist fable.
While the situations are real and the dialogue is authentic, "The Break-Up" is mundane and trite.
Morning Light fails as film or TV. It's essentially a vanity project for sailing enthusiast Roy E. Disney.
And as far as sermons go, it's a good one. You just wish the director had found someone else to deliver it.
More than a novelty and it's occasionally mesmerizing, but without the affectation of dialogue, it hardly rises above after-school special.
The die-hards will dig it, and those who skipped its initial run should greater enjoy their first trip through the cellar door of Donnie's universe.
She's the Man, based on the Bard's changing-room farce Twelfth Night, is a decent little piffle well-suited for boy-crazy fifth-graders.
Continuing on this trajectory, the much-maligned funnyman probably will create yet another generation of fans. And maybe even another generation of haters.
Funny in a sick, twisted sort of way.
Anyone who has consumed more than a handful of detective stories will get the 'whodunit' early on and be stranded with a protagonist who is lagging behind in a visually stale environment.
While the ending is a foregone conclusion, the journey is more clever than cute.
A pretty good amusement park ride.
In the realm of action films, the whole thing works pretty well.
At a too-short 86 minutes, the remake sacrifices exposition and coherence in the name of action. But when the action is lame, what's the freaking point?
A two-hour bludgeoning that smacks more of grave-robbing than resurrection.
A shell game without a pea.
Robots is most like Polar Express. It may represent a new zenith for computer animation, but the uninspired story drags the film into obsolescence.

Parents forced by unruly ankle-biters to spend an afternoon at the multiplex could do worse than Ice Age: The Meltdown (Valiant, anyone?). But if kids could be persuaded to wait a few months for the DVD, it wouldn't be the end of the world.
Never rises above the level of a Friday night network sitcom.
A human rubber band, a transparent woman, a guy on fire, a walking rock pile, and a guy named Doom seem perfectly plausible in the funny books.On the big screen, not so much.
Lacks a creative spark.
Mindless piffle.
Good for Schneider that he was able to bilk a major Hollywood studio out of an estimated $20 million to make this reeking bucket of sewage. Bad for anyone who has the misfortune of seeing it.
This is not a mainstream film. It's an impressionistic, minimalist anti-movie that attempts to discover an existential truth by showing next to nothing.
50? Well, as an actor he's a great rapper. His inexperience shows.
Charlize Theron has her Oscar. Now she has her Catwoman.
The Ringer is often predictable, frequently offensive and occasionally boring, but its heart is in exactly the right place.
So this is what eternal damnation feels like.
Block Party is a true gift.
Instead of smart commentary on the state of entertainment, we're given a mundane, risk-averse romantic comedy.
Notorious is slightly better than the average hip-hop biopic (50 Cent's Get Rich or Die Tryin' among them). But the Great American Hip-Hop Film is still out there somewhere, waiting to be told.
"Captain America: Civil War" is for every little kid who ever bashed one action figure into another while saying "Pew! P-Pew! Kapow-shuh-WOOOOSH!!" In other words, it's nearly perfect.
The camera work is frequently pedestrian, the acting is bland, and the jokes often fall flat.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: "How to Train Your Dragon 2" rises above its animated peers with more troubling themes, outstanding character design and innovative "camera" movements. And it rarely, if ever, takes the easy way out.
Well before it ends, Spectre becomes a cartoonish parody of itself.
The Peanuts Movie manages to nail the strip's comic timing and play its core sentiment -- a childlike desire for acceptance -- to near perfection.
"In the Heart of the Sea" could have worked. But director Ron Howard tries too hard in some places and not enough in others.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The first thing I thought as the credits rolled was that I can't wait to see it again.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: That rare movie that makes you anxious to see the next installment only because it surely has to be better than what you just watched.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Feels like an exercise of obligation, just another item on 20th Century Fox's spring honey-do list: Replace the batteries in the smoke alarms, release another X-Men movie, clean the gutters. Rarely has the end of the world felt so inconsequential.
At the core, this is just another road trip movie, but it bends expectations enough to be cleverly pleasing.
It's a summer movie! Save the serious stuff for September.
It starts with a bang, ends in a yawn and features a whole lot of "What the ...?" along the way.
Fabulous performances and a multilayered narrative tighten the screws into a mysterious and ultimately satisfying thriller.
The Jack Reacher novels are eminently entertaining. If literary snobbery has kept you from picking one up, stop it already. The books' joyous mayhem transcends guilty pleasure.
"Moonlight" is a poetic and poignant story of immense and oppressive loneliness.

What the story lacks in boldness ... is compensated in design and animation. Water, hair and gravity all flow naturally. The sunny island environment radiates happiness. And it does feature some clever moments of slapstick comedy.
Even though the film is much grungier and more realistic than all the previous chapters, this corner of the "Star Wars" universe still is a thrilling place to visit.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even though it's squarely targeting kids and the parents who accompany them, Lego Batman serves as a refreshing palate-cleanser after the dour Batman v Superman and the often inchoate Suicide Squad.
Logan is the violent, brutal and gory R-rated Wolverine movie 40-something fanboys have always wanted. It's most definitely for grown-ups. It's also very, very good.
It's scary and fun and leaves us looking forward to the next chapter.
Ultimately, "Spider-Man: Homecoming" manages to be surprising, uplifting and heroic - all without letting our hero emerge too triumphant.
The Last Jedi, however, opens up some new possibilities. It doesn't provide a ton of satisfying answers, but it creates some interesting questions. And it manages to make "Star Wars" feel new again.
Technically, the film is about as interesting as an insurance commercial.
Despite its change of venue, "Secret" covers all the ground trod in the original but loses any sense of wonder.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Jason Segel is so good in "The End of the Tour" you can almost smell him.
There's still a thrill in seeing all of these comic book characters together in a movie. Even when it's just Ulysses Klaw.
"About Last Night" is dirty, sexy and, for the most part, a lot of fun.
A fun, all-ages space adventure.
Most of it crash-lands.
"Robot & Frank" is so endearing it's easy to forget it's science fiction.
[Its] muddled message and some storytelling cliches prevent "Flight" from being a great film.
Despite a lack of complexity, "Skyfall" is a respectable chapter in the Bond saga.
Daniel Day-Lewis is so good in "Lincoln" he makes a $5 bill look phony.
From the CGI to the subject matter, the film contains several layers of fiction, but regardless of your level of belief, "Life of Pi" always feels true.
"Killing Them Softly" has style and substance but not much soul and no real center.
The film is frequently gorgeous, technologically adventurous and eventually thrilling.
There's no spark between the leads. Cruise and Pike look as if they're just saying lines and occasionally talking over one another.
If there is any justice in the universe, The Hangover will make Zach Galifianakis a household name.
Among the most morally and ethically interesting movies to come along in some time.
A cute if occasionally cheesy love story that manages to tweak zombie lore while raising the bar on Hollywood's supernatural teen romance phase.
In many ways, it's a horror film, as the woman descends into helplessness, and - like the audience - the man can only watch. It's a potent piece of filmmaking.
In a film about people who perform death-defying stunts, the last thing you want to inspire is a yawn.
"Man of Steel" is visually spectacular but, for the most part, emotionally distant. It's just another $200 million superhero movie and another wasted opportunity.
By minimizing the goofy superhero side of the character, Mangold maximizes the action hero. The Wolverine succeeds when it emphasizes the human in superhuman.
"2 Guns" is a smidgen off-target.
It's less like watching a movie and more like eavesdropping on what goes on between a boyfriend and a girlfriend when parents aren't around.
Keeping a hammer-swinging god grounded in a world we can relate to isn't easy, but thanks to good performances, solid effects and great pacing, Taylor and his cast have nailed it.
Though the maneuvering almost descends into tedium at times, Russell has created a dense and operatic portrait in which nothing is as it seems.
"Lone Survivor" illustrates for a new generation the difficulty our young women and men face in fighting an enemy that wears no uniform, marches under no flag and calls no country home.
Director Kathryn Bigelow and her "Hurt Locker" screenwriter, Mark Boal, deftly quilt together disparate events in the almost 10 years between 9/11 and bin Laden's death.
Good casting and the wonderful strangeness of Taymor's vision means that this movie is great fun.
